GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to address systemic GMO contamination risks in honey production, entirely againsting with their opposition to large-scale transgenic crop cultivation.  
GUE_NGL opposes permitting undisclosed GMO pollen in honey as inconsistent with their demand for full consumer transparency on genetic modifications.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's oversight of root causes, overlooking critical aspects like banning open-air GMO cultivation to prevent environmental cross-contamination.  
GUE_NGL condemns the procedural focus on labeling thresholds instead of prohibiting GMO-derived pollen, contradicting their 2013 amendments seeking strict "zero tolerance" policies.  
GUE_NGL insists any solution must challenge EU agro-industrial policies enabling GMO proliferation, which this directive amendment fails to initiate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0530), emphasizing procedural alignment with Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 43(2) and 294, and incorporating input from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0440/2013) and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s opinion. It formally adopted its stance, urged the Commission to resubmit the matter if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring adherence to legislative protocols under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure and the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2012 opinion.

title: Reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags
background: High annual EU consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags and their environmental persistence, particularly in marine ecosystems, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss amending packaging waste rules to reduce single-use plastic bag usage through regulatory measures.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates binding reduction targets for plastic bags as a critical step toward environmental protection and waste minimization  
EPP endorses allowing member states flexibility to implement tailored measures such as taxation or reusable bag incentives without market fragmentation  
EPP emphasizes enhancing consumer education campaigns to shift behavior toward multi-use alternatives while maintaining food safety standards for thin plastic bags  
EPP proposes clarifying EU-wide certification criteria for biodegradable bags to prevent greenwashing and ensure compostability aligns with industrial processing capacities  
This aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to market-compatible ecological modernization through innovation in sustainable packaging solutions

EFD rejects the exemption of degradable plastic bags as entirely againsting with their commitment to safeguarding EU recycling industries from destabilizing market distortions.  
EFD opposes the issue’s failure to address contamination risks in recycled materials, which directly threatens businesses reliant on non-degradable plastic integrity like Chase Plastics.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as incentivizing third-country competitors to flood EU markets with substandard degradable products, undermining domestic manufacturing.  
EFD highlights contradictions between the issue’s environmental aims and its potential to accumulate non-degradable waste stocks due to unreliable material provenance.  
This legislation is inconsistent with EFD’s principles of protecting SMEs from regulatory overreach that jeopardizes jobs without proven ecological benefit.

GREEN_EFA firmly advocates the binding reduction targets and mandatory pricing mechanisms as perfectly aligning with their commitment to systemic waste reduction  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on national bans through its demonstrated success in Luxembourg’s 90% plastic bag reduction via recyclable alternatives  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates for the complete phase-out of non-biodegradable plastics to prevent marine ecosystem collapse as outlined in Satu Hassi’s intervention  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s critical role in addressing the 93.4% non-recycled plastic bag crisis highlighted by Bas Eickhout’s data-driven urgency  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue’s alignment with their manifesto through Claude Turmes’ evidence that economic instruments drive transformative environmental outcomes

ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s binding measures to eliminate 100 billion plastic bags annually, aligning perfectly with their commitment to evidence-based environmental action.  
ALDE approves the directive’s alignment with proven national successes, such as the 80% reduction in plastic bag waste observed in Dutch pilot projects.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical importance of public consensus, noting 90% citizen willingness to support stricter measures as a mandate for swift legislative action.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 4 to mandate biennial public awareness campaigns, leveraging civic engagement to sustain behavioral change beyond economic instruments.  
ALDE urges accelerated post-election negotiations with the Council, ensuring the directive’s implementation timelines match the urgency of marine ecosystem preservation.

SD strongly upholds the binding reduction targets outlined in the issue, particularly the goal to reduce lightweight plastic bag consumption by 80% within five years, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to environmental sustainability and waste reduction.  
SD applauds the inclusion of economic mechanisms such as mandatory pricing for plastic bags, as demonstrated by successful models in Ireland and Finland, which effectively advance SD's priority of incentivizing sustainable consumer behavior.  
SD emphasizes the critical importance of protecting marine ecosystems and coastal tourism industries from plastic pollution, strongly endorsing the issue's focus on mitigating the 8 billion plastic bags discarded annually in the EU.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 by specifying precise thickness criteria for reusable bags to prevent manufacturers from creating thicker single-use alternatives that circumvent reduction objectives.  
SD absolutely agrees the transition towards biodegradable alternatives and stricter enforcement measures across member states, ensuring the directive's goals translate into tangible environmental benefits without compromising existing waste management systems.

ECR rejects the issue's mandatory targets as absolutely rejecting with member states' autonomy to implement tailored solutions.  
ECR opposes the mandatory switch to biodegradable bags, citing unresolved measurement standards and industrial feasibility gaps.  
ECR condemns the Parliament's amendments for undermining the Commission’s flexible framework, which aligned with subsidiarity principles.  
ECR argues the proposal disregards individual responsibility, imposing top-down compulsion inconsistent with liberty-focused governance.  
ECR highlights the issue’s overreach as emblematic of EU institutional overregulation, eroding public trust in legislative proportionality.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0761) concerning legislative measures under Article 114 of the TFEU, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0174/2014). It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts to ensure alignment with legislative intent. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural accountability and inter-institutional dialogue while advancing the legislative process.

title: Non-commercial movement of pet animals: REPORT on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the non-commercial movement of pet animals
background: The European Union's 2003 pet movement regulations required updating due to expiring transitional measures, improved rabies control from vaccination campaigns, and increased cross-border travel with pets. Rising pet ownership and post-Lisbon Treaty legislative adjustments necessitated streamlined procedures. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing non-commercial pet movement rules to simplify procedures and address public health risks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the establishment of a pan-European companion animal register, aligning with their longstanding commitment to harmonizing animal welfare standards across EU policies.  
EPP urges stricter enforcement of EU animal welfare treaties in all member states, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to address systemic violations like greyhound abuse in Spain.  
EPP applauds the harmonized pet travel rules for maintaining rabies-free status while facilitating family mobility within the Single Market.  
EPP endorses veterinary-led vaccination protocols for young animals, ensuring health protections remain scientifically grounded without unnecessary travel restrictions.  
EPP approves simplified documentation requirements to reduce administrative burdens on responsible pet owners, reinforcing free movement principles.

EFD supports the updated pet movement rules for building on Directive 998/2003’s disease control foundations while maintaining cross-border mobility.  
EFD advises clarifying Article 6 to establish concrete verification mechanisms distinguishing commercial/non-commercial movements, preventing regulatory ambiguity.  
EFD recommends standardizing electronic pet identification formats across member states to reduce administrative inconsistencies in certification processes.  
EFD acknowledges public health safeguards but urges mandatory veterinary consultation requirements pre-travel to strengthen disease prevention protocols.  
EFD concurs with streamlining objectives but proposes a five-year review clause to evaluate rabies antibody testing efficacy in low-risk regions.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's balanced approach to facilitating pet mobility while safeguarding public and animal health, aligning perfectly with their commitment to harmonizing citizen freedoms with rigorous disease prevention.  
GREEN_EFA approves the compromise on limited vaccination derogations for young animals, recognizing this as a scientifically grounded exception that maintains core biosecurity principles.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on standardized documentation and public information requirements, which effectively advance transparency and owner compliance – key priorities in their animal welfare agenda.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing future traceability measures through the Commission's feasibility study for an EU-wide pet movement database, urging rapid implementation to close monitoring gaps.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that continued success depends on maintaining robust vaccination protocols and public trust, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for prevention-first health policies.

ALDE strongly endorses the updated pet movement rules for upholding rabies control and enabling cross-border mobility, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to integrated EU policies and family-focused free movement.  
ALDE approves the streamlined online access for travel requirements and balanced exceptions for working animals like sled dogs, effectively advancing practical solutions that reflect citizens' needs while maintaining public health safeguards.  
ALDE endorses veterinarian-administered microchipping and anti-fraud document controls as critical measures to combat illegal pet trade, consistent with their prioritization of animal welfare and single-market integrity.  
ALDE proposes enhancing implementation by tasking the Commission with evaluating cost-efficient EU-wide registration systems and monitoring compliance with multi-pet movement exceptions to prevent abuse.

SD strongly upholds the harmonized vaccination requirements as a critical safeguard against rabies transmission, aligning with their public health protection priorities.  
SD approves the 5-animal limit for non-commercial travel as an effective barrier against illegal puppy trade while allowing legitimate exceptions for exhibitions under veterinary supervision.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 8 by requiring the Commission to publish its pet database feasibility study within 12 months rather than leaving timelines open-ended.  
SD applauds the mandatory multilingual publication of national import rules as advancing transparency and cross-border mobility for citizens with pets.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s alignment with their One Health approach by explicitly linking animal vaccination standards to human disease prevention frameworks.

ECR strongly agrees the harmonized pet movement framework as advancing animal welfare priorities while preserving rabies-free status safeguards.  
ECR applauds the euthanasia-as-last-resort amendment in Article 8(3a), aligning with their principle of minimizing bureaucratic harm to animals.  
ECR proposes enhancing Article 4(1) by mandating microchips over tattoos to strengthen fraud prevention in pet passport systems.  
ECR approves the derogation clauses for rabies-free territories, recognizing their alignment with national biosecurity imperatives.  
ECR endorses streamlined compliance checks under Article 6 as balancing free movement with public health vigilance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0089) concerning measures under Articles 43(2) and 168(4)(b) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, focusing on agriculture and public health. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0371/2012) and considered the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of 23 May 2012. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are introduced, ensuring legislative coherence. It also instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and inter-institutional dialogue. The resolution centered on aligning EU policies with legal frameworks while addressing sector-specific challenges in agriculture and public health.

title: Pharmacovigilance (amendment of Directive 2001/83/EC): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 as regards pharmacovigilance
background: The delayed withdrawal of diabetes drug Mediator in France, linked to adverse cardiovascular effects and regulatory gaps in EU pharmacovigilance systems, prompted scrutiny of post-market safety monitoring protocols. The Parliament will discuss amendments to medicinal product regulations aimed at improving transparency and oversight mechanisms for drug safety evaluations.

stances.stance:
EPP fully promotes the enhanced transparency mandates requiring marketing authorisation holders to disclose withdrawal reasons, perfectly aligning with its commitment to patient safety and market integrity.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the systematic inclusion of post-authorisation safety studies (PASS) in monitoring lists, advancing its priority of proactive pharmacovigilance.  
EPP applauds the drug facts box initiative as a critical enhancement to package inserts, reflecting its manifesto pledge for patient-centric healthcare communication.  
EPP acknowledges off-label prescription monitoring as a future enhancement opportunity, urging the Commission to explore EMA-led guidelines without opposing the issue’s current scope.  
EPP celebrates the swift legislative response to the Mediator case, reinforcing its stance on inter-institutional collaboration to mitigate public health risks.

EFD supports the issue’s reinforcement of pharmacovigilance systems to enhance patient safety and market transparency, aligning with their prioritization of public health safeguards.  
EFD advises amending Article 114 to require independent conflict-of-interest audits for regulatory bodies, ensuring pharmaceutical industry influence does not compromise risk evaluations.  
EFD proposes modifying Article 168(4)(c) to authorize EU-level emergency drug suspension protocols when Member State disagreements delay critical safety actions.  
EFD highlights the need for mandatory real-world tolerability profiling in post-market surveillance, urging amendments to mandate quarterly updates accessible to healthcare providers.  
EFD underscores stricter transparency requirements for clinical trial data sharing, advocating for centralized public databases managed by the European Medicines Agency.

ALDE strongly upholds the enhanced transparency measures in the pharmacovigilance framework, particularly the obligation for companies to disclose safety-related reasons for product withdrawals.  
ALDE approves the automatic triggering of emergency procedures when drug withdrawals stem from safety concerns, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to proactive patient protection.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need to adequately resource the European Medicines Agency to fulfill expanded monitoring roles, proposing accelerated Commission action on funding allocations.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on reinforcing post-market surveillance mechanisms, which effectively advances ALDE's priority of evidence-based public health governance.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s alignment with internal market harmonization principles while maintaining rigorous safety standards, reflecting their balanced approach to regulatory efficiency.

SD totally agrees the issue's mandate for EU-level pharmacovigilance harmonization, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to transnational health safety frameworks that prevent tragedies like the Mediator drug case.  
SD perfectly aligns with the requirement for automatic EU reassessment of withdrawn medications, emphasizing this closes critical gaps in post-market surveillance identified through national system failures.  
SD fully supports extended medicinal product monitoring periods and transparency obligations, ensuring adverse effects are rapidly communicated across all Member States to protect patient trust.  
SD highlights the issue's advancement of healthcare worker collaboration as essential to operationalize pharmacovigilance reforms, consistent with SD's advocacy for systemic stakeholder integration.  
 SD proposes future enhancements to ensure complete independence of regulatory bodies from industry influence, framing this as complementary evolution rather than criticism of current provisions.

ECR totally accepts the issue’s mandate for automatic emergency evaluations upon drug safety withdrawals, perfectly aligning with their commitment to rigorous patient protection frameworks.  
ECR applauds the swift closure of pharmacovigilance loopholes, effectively advancing public health priorities through immediate legislative action over protracted revisions.

GUE_NGL totally agrees the issue's pharmacovigilance reforms as a critical safeguard against pharmaceutical scandals like Mediator, perfectly aligning with their commitment to rigorous patient protection standards.

resolution: The European Parliament adopted its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2012)0051) concerning measures under Article 114 (internal market harmonization) and Article 168(4)(c) (public health) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. title: Pharmacovigilance (amendment of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 as regards pharmacovigilance
background: The 2010 EU pharmacovigilance framework faced scrutiny following the Mediator drug case in France, where delayed market withdrawal revealed gaps in post-authorization safety monitoring and transparency. The Parliament will discuss amendments to Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 to strengthen drug safety oversight and risk assessment processes after market approval.

stances.stance:
EPP completely sanctions the enhanced transparency requirements for marketing authorization withdrawals, perfectly aligning with their commitment to patient safety and market integrity.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the mandatory reporting of third-country drug suspensions to all Member States through EMA, ensuring cross-border pharmacovigilance coherence.  
EPP completely sanctions systematic inclusion of products in post-authorization safety studies, strengthening proactive risk management as outlined in their public health priorities.  
EPP proposes future consideration of off-label prescription monitoring frameworks to address residual safety concerns while maintaining current issue's core objectives.  
EPP completely sanctions the commitment to improve medicinal product information leaflets, aligning with their patient empowerment agenda through clearer risk communication.

EFD supports the pharmacovigilance reforms to strengthen patient safety and EU-wide medicinal product transparency, aligning with public health priorities.  
EFD advises amending Article 23 to mandate explicit conflict-of-interest disclosures for regulatory bodies overseeing drug approvals, addressing imbalances in pharmaceutical oversight.  
EFD highlights the necessity for accelerated EU-level drug withdrawal mechanisms when risks are identified, citing unresolved cases like the French lethal drug incident as justification.  
EFD endorses harmonized post-market surveillance to ensure consistent safety evaluations across Member States, reducing regulatory fragmentation.  
EFD proposes reinforcing the European Medicines Agency’s authority to override national inaction on high-risk medications within 30 days of risk confirmation.

ALDE fundamentally accepts the obligation for pharmaceutical companies to disclose withdrawal rationales, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transparency in public health governance  
ALDE perfectly supports the automatic triggering of emergency procedures upon safety-related market withdrawals, advancing their priority of proactive patient protection  
ALDE strongly commends the reinforced post-authorization monitoring framework as effectively realizing their manifesto goals for dynamic risk assessment systems  
ALDE highlights the European Medicines Agency's expanded mandate as fully consistent with their vision of empowered EU institutions safeguarding health standards  
ALDE applauds the issue's crisis-response mechanisms, seeing perfect alignment with their principles of agile EU legislation addressing systemic failures

SD entirely approves the enhanced transparency measures, perfectly aligning with their commitment to patient safety through immediate EU-wide adverse reaction alerts and mandatory market withdrawal explanations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's urgency in closing pharmacovigilance loopholes, emphasizing rapid post-authorization monitoring to prevent tragedies like the Mediator drug's delayed withdrawal.  
SD fully supports extended EU-level scientific assessments for nationally withdrawn medicines, advancing their priority to unify drug safety standards across Member States.  
SD endorses mandatory collaboration between healthcare professionals and patients as critical to building public trust, reflecting their manifesto principle of participatory health governance.  
SD recognizes the amendments as a foundational step toward stricter oversight, proposing future initiatives to ensure therapeutic progress requirements align with long-term safety goals.

ECR fundamentally approves the issue's mandate for automatic emergency evaluations upon drug withdrawal declarations, perfectly aligning with their commitment to rigorous patient safety protocols.  
ECR highlights the critical closure of regulatory loopholes requiring companies to disclose safety-related drug withdrawals as a vital safeguard against tragedies like the Mediator case.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the swift legislative prioritization of immediate public health protections over protracted revisions, reflecting their principle of decisive regulatory action.  
ECR commends the issue's alignment with their manifesto goal of transparent pharmacovigilance, ensuring market accountability without compromising rapid response mechanisms.  
ECR emphasizes the issue's advancement of cross-border health security frameworks, a cornerstone of their policy agenda for harmonized risk prevention.

GUE/NGL completely advocates the enhanced pharmacovigilance measures as a vital safeguard against pharmaceutical scandals like the Mediator case, aligning perfectly with their commitment to rigorous patient protection.

GUE/NGL emphasizes that the issue advances public health sovereignty by rejecting crisis-era delays in medicine access, directly supporting their opposition to austerity harming vulnerable populations.  
GUE/NGL highlights the legislation’s role in combating preventable deaths from medicine shortages, framing it as a cornerstone of their agenda to prioritize public health over market interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0051) to harmonize public health and internal market measures under Treaty Articles 114 and 168(4)(c), endorsing the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0164/2012). The resolution mandates the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments or replacement, ensuring legislative oversight, and instructs the Parliament’s President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance the legislative process.

title: Placing on the market and use of biocidal products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing on the market and use of biocidal products
background: The existing 1998 EU Directive on biocidal products faced challenges in harmonizing market access and addressing evolving safety standards, including emerging technologies like nanomaterials, prompting a 2009 Commission proposal for reform. The Parliament will discuss updating regulatory frameworks to enhance internal market coherence and safety protocols for biocidal products.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions the harmonized EU authorization system for biocidal products as achieving perfect alignment with its commitment to single market efficiency and consumer health safeguards.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of REACH coherence, affirming this as critical to eliminating regulatory conflicts while advancing innovation-friendly standards.  
EPP totally sanctions the phased implementation framework under Article 33, recognizing its balance between immediate hazard mitigation and transitional flexibility for industry adaptation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with centralized authorization provisions, emphasizing their role in reducing fragmentation and strengthening cross-border trade predictability.  
EPP totally sanctions the issue’s prioritization of nanotechnology research as integral to developing safer alternatives, consistent with its 2010 innovation agenda for sustainable biocides.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the inadequate resourcing of ECHA as undermining chemical safety protocols central to consumer protection.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to align budgetary provisions with expanded ECHA mandates, creating systemic risk of regulatory capture by industry interests.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's contradiction with precautionary principles by allowing superficial evaluations through underfunded nanoparticle assessments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the disregard for scientific rigor in biocidal product authorization, directly conflicting with their 2019 manifesto on toxic-free environments.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the text overlooks critical health safeguards by prioritizing administrative speed over robust endocrine disruptor exclusion mechanisms.

ALDE strongly upholds the balanced authorization framework incentivizing low-risk biocidal products, aligning with ALDE's commitment to harmonizing market efficiency with robust health and environmental safeguards.  
ALDE approves the issue's integration of precautionary principles and risk-reduction mandates, advancing the party's priority to mitigate biocide dangers while preserving their essential utility.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need to maintain strict substitution requirements for hazardous substances, rejecting provisions that dilute assessment standards or delay phase-outs of harmful chemicals.  
ALDE proposes clarifying Amendment 243's interaction with Article 5 to ensure coherence in addressing rodenticide concerns, enhancing regulatory predictability without opposing the issue's core objectives.  
ALDE highlights the importance of proportionality in future evaluations, urging alignment with REACH's data-driven authorization model to support SME innovation and effective pest control strategies.

SD strongly approves the issue’s prioritization of health and environmental safeguards, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to reducing chemical risks through substitution of hazardous biocides with safer alternatives.  
SD applauds the integration of national opt-out provisions for biocidal product restrictions, effectively advancing the principle of localized environmental protection without undermining internal market harmonization.  
SD proposes ensuring the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) receives sufficient funding and operational capacity to manage centralized authorization by 2017, enhancing procedural reliability while maintaining the issue’s timeline.  
SD endorses the mandate to develop a framework directive on biocidal product usage, reinforcing their stance that application methods are as critical as substance approval for comprehensive risk mitigation.  
SD emphasizes the need to formalize animal testing reduction commitments in Annexes, urging explicit timelines for adopting alternative methods to exceed current compromise thresholds.

ECR strongly promotes the issue's alignment with scientific assessment protocols for biocidal authorization, effectively advancing their priority of evidence-based policymaking in public health protection.  
ECR approves maintaining professional access to rodenticides like Difenacoum but proposes amending Annex I to require biennial resistance monitoring, ensuring efficacy without opposing substitution principles.  
ECR endorses harmonized market rules under Article 114 while suggesting refining Amendment 61’s substitution criteria to explicitly exempt rotation-dependent active substances.  
ECR applauds the issue’s rejection of non-scientific bans on critical biocides, aligning with their commitment to practical pest control solutions for agricultural stakeholders.  
ECR advocates retaining Annex VII provisions for rodenticide rotation systems, proposing strengthened labeling requirements to enhance user compliance.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's market-first approach as fundamentally disapproveing with their mandate to prioritize human health and environmental protection over free circulation of biocides.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's failure to institute a strict ban on carcinogenic and non-biodegradable biocides, directly contradicting their demand for hazard elimination in Amendment 352.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's oversight of 400,000 tonnes/year household biocide risks as incompatible with their child safety advocacy, particularly regarding wood preservatives and insect sprays.  
GUE_NGL condemns the text's reliance on manufacturer assurances of "proper use," which neglects real-world accident scenarios central to their consumer protection principles.  
GUE_NGL demands rejection of the Commission's framework for enabling hazardous substance circulation, insisting on binding toxicity thresholds absent in the current Articles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0267), emphasizing the need to align the legislative process with the Treaty of Lisbon’s provisions, particularly Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, to ensure harmonization of internal market rules. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, safeguarding procedural integrity under Article 294(3). The resolution integrated opinions from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (A7-0239/2010), reflecting cross-committee consensus. Parliament instructed its President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing transparency and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Sulphur content of marine fuels: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 1999/32/EC as regards the sulphur content of marine fuels
background: The International Maritime Organisation’s 2008 agreement established stricter sulphur limits for marine fuels to reduce air pollution, prompting the EU to update its 1999 directive. Regional disparities in existing standards and compliance timelines necessitated legislative action. The Parliament will discuss aligning EU regulations with international norms and addressing environmental and public health implications of maritime emissions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's alignment with global sulphur standards, emphasizing its critical role in curbing maritime emissions that threaten public health and environmental progress.  
EPP applauds the balanced regional differentiation approach, recognizing objective health imperatives in the Baltic and North Sea while upholding the International Maritime Organisation's framework as consistent with EPP's environmental-economic synergy principles.  
EPP proposes future harmonization of sulphur limits across all EU waters to address equity concerns, framing current asymmetries as transitional necessities pending broader fuel availability and port infrastructure upgrades.  
EPP endorses the 2020 implementation timeline and MARPOL revision clause, highlighting their congruence with EPP's manifesto priorities for sustainable transport investment cycles and regulatory predictability.  
EPP urges accelerated development of LNG infrastructure and scrubber technologies to mitigate sectoral disruptions, reinforcing the issue's focus on long-term competitiveness alongside emission reductions.

EFD rejects the directive's disproportionate sulphur limits as firmly challengeing with their commitment to fair internal market competition.  
EFD opposes the Baltic Sea's fivefold stricter regulation compared to Mediterranean zones, citing severe economic harm to Finnish export industries.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of regional economic dependency, risking 20 000 job losses and €500 million annual costs in Finland.  
EFD condemns the issue's distortion of market fairness, evidenced by UPM's production relocation threat due to uncompetitive operational burdens.  
This approach is inconsistent with EFD's principle of balanced environmental regulation respecting Member States' economic realities.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s stringent sulphur limits as a critical step to mitigate maritime pollution, aligning perfectly with their commitment to safeguarding marine ecosystems and public health.  
GREEN_EFA approves the Baltic Sea’s enhanced protections, recognizing its ecological sensitivity and the necessity for region-specific measures to preserve brackish water biodiversity.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the cost feasibility of scrubber investments, rebutting industry exaggerations by emphasizing minimal financial impacts relative to long-term environmental and human health gains.  
GREEN_EFA endorses harmonizing shipping emissions with land-based transport standards, advancing a level playing field that prioritizes air quality equity across transport sectors.  
GREEN_EFA counters opposition claims about regional competition, asserting that differentiated rules for sensitive areas do not undermine trade but align with science-driven environmental stewardship.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s harmonization of sulphur limits with IMO standards, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmentally effective maritime policy while upholding international obligations.  
ALDE applauds the balanced approach to emission reductions in SECA zones, advancing cleaner air through market-compatible mechanisms as outlined in their sustainability priorities.  
ALDE proposes enhanced post-2015 monitoring of modal shift risks and regional competitiveness impacts to ensure the policy’s ecological goals do not inadvertently disadvantage northern maritime economies.  
ALDE endorses the cross-committee collaboration reflected in the issue, reinforcing their principle of evidence-based policymaking for complex environmental challenges.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for future reviews to address transitional disparities between SECA and Mediterranean regions, ensuring equitable implementation without opposing the core standards.

SD strongly approves the directive's stringent sulphur limits, which align perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to public health and environmental protection, effectively preventing thousands of premature deaths linked to marine fuel emissions.  
SD strongly advocates for harmonized implementation across all EU maritime regions to ensure equitable environmental standards and maintain the integrity of the internal market, addressing current north-south disparities.  
SD proposes enhancing the directive with targeted financial assistance and transitional support mechanisms for shipowners and industries most affected by the rapid fuel quality transition.  
SD strongly endorses accelerated research funding and infrastructure development for liquefied natural gas (LNG) propulsion and shore-side electrification as critical pathways to sustainable maritime transport.  
SD emphasizes the issue's dual benefit of generating over €30 billion in healthcare savings while strengthening port competitiveness through expanded Sulphur Emission Control Areas.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the issue’s alignment with their environmental justice priorities, particularly its stricter sulphur limits to prevent tens of thousands of premature deaths linked to marine emissions.  
GUE_NGL applauds the proposal’s advancement of SECA parity with North American standards as a critical step toward equitable public health protections.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening Article 4 enforcement mechanisms by mandating penalties for non-compliance rather than allowing exemptions for fuel storage limitations.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need for binding monitoring protocols in Annex II to close loopholes that risk undermining emission reduction goals.  
GUE_NGL urges the Commission to prioritize strict enforcement collaboration with Member States, reflecting their manifesto commitment to holding polluters accountable.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0439) concerning environmental and transport policies under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0038/2012) and incorporating input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts to ensure alignment with legislative intent. title: Sound level of motor vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the sound level of motor vehicles
background: Persistent public health concerns over traffic noise exposure linked to cardiovascular risks by WHO studies, coupled with outdated EU vehicle noise standards last revised in 1995, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss updated motor vehicle noise regulations to address health impacts and align technical standards with current environmental and public health priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's phased decibel reduction framework, aligning with EPP's commitment to balanced environmental progress without jeopardizing industrial stability during economic recovery.  
EPP proposes revising Annex III classification thresholds through technical expert consultation to better reflect UNECE standards and current automotive engineering realities.  
EPP endorses mandatory acoustic vehicle alert systems for electric/hybrid vehicles as a safety imperative, ensuring pedestrian protection complements noise reduction objectives.  
EPP advocates expanding the noise reduction strategy to include road surface quality standards and tire innovation incentives, creating a holistic approach beyond engine-focused metrics.  
EPP recommends adopting Amendment 61's extended implementation timeline to maintain emission reduction ambition while allowing manufacturers transitional flexibility for compliance.

EFD supports the regulation’s goal to reduce urban noise pollution, aligning with public health priorities for densely populated areas.  
EFD proposes amending the regulation to mandate acoustic signaling systems in electric vehicles (Amendment 66), ensuring pedestrian safety while maintaining noise reduction objectives.  
EFD highlights concerns over the financial strain of mandatory road surface upgrades, urging EU-funded support mechanisms for Member States.  
EFD advises incorporating subsidiarity principles to allow national flexibility in cost-effective implementation strategies.  
EFD recommends periodic reviews to balance technological advancements with achievable noise reduction targets.

GREEN_EFA totally rejects with the issue's diluted noise reduction targets, which fail to address the €54 billion annual health cost burden from traffic noise highlighted in their 2023 policy briefs.  
GREEN_EFA rejects Amendment 61's loopholes allowing phased compliance timelines, directly contradicting their demand for immediate "quiet vehicle" mandates in urban zones.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the false industry collapse narrative, emphasizing their Automotive Innovation Fund proposal (2021/C 301/08) demonstrates feasible electrification pathways.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's inconsistency with WHO night noise guidelines (Lnight <45 dB), permitting 20% higher thresholds than medically advised.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding measures to eliminate combustion engine idling noise by 2028, absent from current Article 4 provisions.

SD rejects the issue's Annex III noise limits as dangerously aligned with automotive industry interests, absolutely disapproveing with SD's evidence-based public health priorities.  
SD opposes the extended compliance timelines for heavy vehicles, which perpetuate avoidable noise exposure in low-income urban communities.

SD condemns the issue's exclusion of aerodynamic noise controls as inconsistent with comprehensive environmental health strategies endorsed in their 2023 Urban Welfare Pact.  
The compromise on electric vehicle warning systems fails to address SD's safety accessibility requirements while granting unjustified concessions to manufacturers.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to counteract automotive lobbyist influence undermining public health protections.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the delayed 7-year implementation timeline as incompatible with urgent noise pollution mitigation needs.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's omission of binding mechanisms to hold manufacturers financially accountable for noise-related societal costs.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's disregard for WHO health impact studies, conflicting with GUE_NGL's mandate to prioritize environmental justice.  
GUE_NGL asserts the text institutionalizes corporate cost externalization, violating the polluter-pays principle central to their policy framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2011)0856) concerning EU internal market measures under Article 114 TFEU, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0435/2012). It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal arise, ensuring legislative coherence and procedural accountability. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional communication and alignment in the legislative process.

title: Standards of quality and safety of human organs intended for transplantation: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on standards of quality and safety of human organs intended for transplantation
background: Significant disparities in organ donation rates among EU member states and persistent shortages affecting over 56,000 patients awaiting transplants necessitated harmonized quality and safety protocols. The Parliament will discuss establishing EU-wide standards for human organ transplantation to address cross-border compatibility and improve healthcare outcomes.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the Spanish model of transplant coordination as a blueprint for EU-wide efficiency gains in organ donation systems  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's binding provisions ensuring voluntary unpaid donations while combating organ trafficking through traceability measures  
EPP fully supports cross-border organ exchange protocols enabled by harmonized quality standards to address critical patient waiting lists  
EPP strongly advocates maintaining professional hospital transplant coordinators as essential to replicating Spain's 34.4 donors/million success EU-wide  
EPP unequivocally backs the directive's balance between data protection requirements and clinical traceability needs to prevent illegal organ trade

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on EU-level coordination to harmonize divergent national regulations, aligning with EFD’s call to eliminate disparities in donor consent frameworks and insurance schemes.  
EFD advises amending Article 4 to mandate standardized health screening protocols for all organs, addressing concerns about contagious diseases and ensuring donor-recipient safety.  
EFD endorses the introduction of a European donor card and stricter penalties for illegal trafficking, as proposed in the debate, to combat transplant tourism and organ commercialization.  
EFD recommends reinforcing provisions for non-commercial living donations, ensuring compensation is strictly limited to post-operation inconveniences as defined by national laws.  
EFD highlights the need to prioritize post-mortem donations over living donations in Directive Annex II, minimizing risks of coercion while maintaining altruistic donation principles.

GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the issue's emphasis on combating illegal organ trade, perfectly aligning with their commitment to human rights and ethical medical practices.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening safeguards for living donors by urging Member States to implement rigorous national verification systems beyond familial donations, enhancing protections against exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the directive’s focus on voluntary, non-commercial donations as the cornerstone of ethical transplantation policy, reflecting their long-standing anti-trafficking principles.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of prior parliamentary priorities into the directive, particularly measures to reduce waiting lists through transparent donor recruitment strategies.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need for continuous EU monitoring to eradicate criminal organ markets, framing this as a critical extension of the issue’s existing accountability framework.

ALDE totally agrees the directive’s focus on increasing organ donations through awareness campaigns and dismantling administrative barriers, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to patient-centered healthcare innovation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s mandate for national quality-control authorities, emphasizing transparency and safety from donor extraction to transplantation as critical to harmonizing EU standards.  
ALDE highlights the Basque Country’s record donation rates as proof that regional coordination systems and public awareness, as promoted in the directive, effectively advance cross-border health collaboration.  
ALDE fully supports the authorization of non-optimal organ use in emergencies and expanded living donations, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of pragmatic, life-saving solutions within ethical frameworks.  
ALDE applauds the inclusion of digital donor registries and identity markers as transformative tools to accelerate donations, reinforcing ALDE’s vision for technology-driven healthcare efficiency.

SD totally upholds the issue's absolute prohibition of organ commercialization, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to ethical voluntary donation systems that eliminate profit motives.  
SD perfectly supports harmonizing EU-wide donor identification protocols to replicate Spain's success in achieving 40 donations per million citizens through optimized consent frameworks.  
SD unequivocally backs the mandate for traceable transnational organ exchanges, recognizing this as critical to reducing daily patient deaths through coordinated cross-border availability.  
SD champions the issue's reinforcement of post-transplant monitoring standards as essential for maintaining public trust in donation systems across all Member States.  
SD fully aligns with the directive's requirement for national authorities to combat transplant tourism, ensuring European patients never face incentives to seek illegal procedures abroad.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on reducing systemic inequalities in organ access across Member States, aligning with their commitment to equitable healthcare.  
GUE_NGL applauds the inclusion of expanded donor eligibility beyond conventional family structures, ensuring protections against discriminatory practices.  
GUE_NGL endorses the focus on volunteer-based donation systems and patient data safeguards as critical to combating organ trafficking.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening cross-border cooperation mechanisms to further disrupt illicit organ trade networks while maintaining procedural transparency.  
GUE_NGL approves the issue’s alignment with public health solidarity principles, particularly traceability measures ensuring donor-recipient accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of the position at first reading on the Commission’s 2008 proposal (COM(2008)0818) concerning public health measures under Article 152(4)(a) of the EC Treaty and Article 168(4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7‑0106/2009). title: Possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC as regards the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory
background: The EU's existing regulatory framework allowed centralized GMO authorization but faced challenges as member states increasingly invoked safeguard clauses to restrict cultivation, conflicting with single market principles and prompting legal disputes. The Parliament will discuss amending GMO cultivation rules to reconcile national autonomy with EU-wide authorization processes.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the issue’s alignment with subsidiarity principles, affirming Member States’ rights to regulate GMO cultivation per their citizens’ will.  
EFD advises amending Article 3 to explicitly require “Made in” labeling for GMO-derived foods, addressing consumer transparency gaps noted in the debate.  
EFD highlights the need for stricter safeguards against cross-border contamination, proposing Annex I revisions to enforce buffer zones between GMO and non-GMO farms.  
EFD urges reinforcing Clause 7 to mandate biannual public consultations in Member States, ensuring ongoing democratic oversight of GMO policies.  
EFD commends the rapporteur’s emphasis on procedural transparency but cautions against centralized market harmonization undermining national diversity.

GREEN_EFA firmly promotes the issue's establishment of liability frameworks ensuring polluters bear costs for GMO contamination, perfectly aligning with their principle of ecological accountability.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's recognition of socio-economic impacts and biodiversity preservation as valid grounds for national GMO bans, advancing their vision of farmer sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the rejection of GMO cultivation as a solution to global hunger, affirming their commitment to agroecological systems over industrial monocultures.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue's reinforcement of coexistence rules between GMO and non-GMO agriculture, safeguarding consumer choice and organic farming integrity.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue's critical improvement over the Commission’s flawed proposal by creating a legally robust pathway for Member States to restrict GMOs.

ALDE strongly upholds the establishment of a common European framework enabling Member States to restrict GMO cultivation, aligning with their commitment to subsidiarity in environmental protection.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s harmonization of legal frameworks under Article 114 TFEU, ensuring procedural clarity while respecting regional biodiversity priorities.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing internal market coherence in future reviews by requiring EFSA’s risk assessments to inform national restrictions, addressing concerns about precedent-setting without opposing the core provision.  
ALDE emphasizes that safeguarding public health and environmental integrity must supersede unqualified market freedoms, as articulated in their 2023 sustainability agenda.  
ALDE urges strict adherence to transparency mechanisms in transmitting issues to national parliaments, ensuring citizen-centric governance.

SD strongly agrees the issue's empowerment of Member States to restrict GMO cultivation, aligning with SD's commitment to environmental precaution and subsidiarity in agricultural policy.  
SD approves the inclusion of socio-economic and environmental grounds for prohibitions, enhancing legal certainty as emphasized in multiple committee inputs.  
SD highlights the need to amend Article 4 to mandate EU-funded research on long-term GMO impacts, addressing concerns raised about unresolved ecological risks.  
SD endorses the issue’s respect for public skepticism, strongly mirroring Eurobarometer findings and SD’s prioritization of citizen-led policymaking.  
SD proposes strengthening coexistence protocols by specifying minimum buffer zones between GMO/conventional crops to operationalize Jo Leinen’s call for farmer choice safeguards.

 While some ECR members acknowledge Member State sovereignty provisions, the group maintains unified opposition to the issue’s restrictive core.

GUE_NGL proposes strengthening socio-economic protections in Article 4 to explicitly shield farmers from market distortions caused by cross-border GMO contamination.  
GUE_NGL approves the inclusion of health and environmental grounds for bans, urging enhanced public consultation mandates to ensure grassroots democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need for binding EU-wide safeguards against corporate litigation targeting national GMO prohibitions, reinforcing the issue’s precautionary principles.  
GUE_NGL highlights the urgency of extending risk assessment protocols to address long-term biodiversity impacts, aligning with their manifesto’s ecological justice priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0375) to harmonize internal market rules under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety’s report and incorporating input from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. It emphasized the need for alignment with legal and procedural frameworks, including opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. The resolution affirmed Parliament’s formal adoption of its negotiated position, urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending substantial amendments, and instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and transparency.

title: Programme for the environment and climate action (LIFE): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE)
background: The EU’s LIFE Programme, operational since 1992, faced renewal under the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework amid evolving environmental priorities and funding challenges. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised Programme for Environment and Climate Action to address biodiversity, climate change, and policy implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the LIFE Programme's budget expansion and climate action tripling, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cross-border environmental innovation and Natura 2000 preservation.  
EPP approves enhanced co-financing structures enabling member states to maximize project scalability while safeguarding national implementation frameworks critical for regional biodiversity.  
EPP proposes streamlining VAT reimbursement processes and personnel cost eligibility to broaden SME participation, enhancing grassroots environmental entrepreneurship without compromising core funding streams.  
EPP emphasizes integrating agricultural sustainability measures through coordinated LIFE-CAP synergies, advancing both ecological targets and rural economic stability as championed in their climate manifestos.  
EPP advocates periodic impact assessments of integrated projects to optimize job creation metrics, ensuring LIFE's economic benefits match its ecological ambitions through evidence-based refinements.

EFD partially accepts the LIFE Programme's biodiversity protection framework but demands reallocation of at least 15% of its climate action budget to local flood management infrastructure, citing Sardinia's river dredging neglect under EU fiscal rules.  
EFD entirely conflicts binding climate spending quotas in the issue, arguing they disproportionately burden EU industries without matching commitments from China or India as referenced in Warsaw Summit failures.  
EFD requests deletion of Article 4's emissions reduction benchmarks, asserting they accelerate industrial relocation to non-participating states as warned in competitiveness analyses.  
EFD requires amendment of Natura 2000 funding mechanisms to exclude climate adaptation projects, redirecting resources to "immediate environmental maintenance" like river systems cited in Olbia's disaster.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s demand for dedicating 10% of LIFE’s budget to Natura 2000, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reversing biodiversity loss and fulfilling Treaty obligations.  

GREEN_EFA approves the integration of climate adaptation funding, effectively advancing their priority of linking ecological resilience with climate action, as demonstrated by successful grassroots projects.  

GREEN_EFA proposes stricter oversight to prevent climate funds from being diverted to private interests, ensuring resources directly benefit nature restoration and community-led initiatives.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the regionalized project selection and operational cost coverage for NGOs, which mirrors their advocacy for decentralized, locally informed environmental governance.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of exceeding the proposed budget to close funding gaps, reinforcing the issue’s stance that current allocations remain insufficient for EU climate targets.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on maintaining LIFE Programme funding quality, aligning with their commitment to effective EU environmental instruments.  
ALDE applauds the proposed 10% budget allocation for Natura 2000 as critical to addressing biodiversity gaps, reflecting their prioritization of measurable conservation targets.  
ALDE urges the Commission to conduct an annual analysis of nature conservation spending across EU funds to ensure alignment with Biodiversity Strategy goals, enhancing accountability.  
ALDE endorses safeguarding LIFE's traditional project funding while expanding innovative instruments, preventing resource diversion from proven environmental initiatives.  
ALDE emphasizes rejecting Member States' attempts to lower co-financing standards, insisting on quality-driven allocations over purely national quota systems.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on biodiversity protection and Natura 2000 funding, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to halting irreversible environmental degradation. The proposed 10% allocation to Natura 2000 directly advances SD’s priority of bridging critical funding gaps through LIFE’s proven mechanisms.  

SD applauds the focus on capacity-building in underutilized regions and higher co-financing rates for less-developed areas, which effectively addresses regional disparities in environmental investment and ensures equitable implementation of EU climate laws.  

SD endorses the integration of climate action across EU policies via LIFE projects, noting that this approach mirrors SD’s advocacy for cross-sectoral sustainability and green job creation as outlined in the EU2020 strategy.  

SD proposes enhancing future Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations to progressively increase LIFE’s budget beyond current proposals, ensuring full alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon’s environmental obligations while maintaining support for traditional projects.  

SD highlights the necessity of safeguarding LIFE’s core environmental sub-programs, emphasizing that expanding the program’s scope must not compromise funding for high-impact initiatives like habitat restoration or anti-biodiversity loss measures.

GUE/NGL fundamentally doubts the proposed LIFE Programme budget as it fails to allocate the demanded 1% of the EU budget, perpetuating systemic underfunding of environmental priorities central to their platform.  
GUE/NGL rejects the reliance on co-financing mechanisms and private sources, which they argue creates unequal access for smaller projects and contradicts their principle of equitable EU-led environmental stewardship.  
The proposal overlooks critical structural barriers identified by GUE/NGL, including insufficient technical support for proposal drafting and regional disparities in project approval rates, which undermine participatory environmental governance.  
GUE/NGL warns that expanding LIFE’s climate scope without binding safeguards risks deprioritizing biodiversity conservation, directly conflicting with their demand to maintain Natura 2000 as the program’s core mission.  
The issue’s 10% allocation for Natura 2000 is deemed grossly inadequate by GUE/NGL, who insist this represents a retreat from binding Treaty obligations rather than meaningful progress.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the adequacy of the proposed financial envelope for the LIFE Programme (2014-2020), emphasizing that its final budget depends on the ongoing Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations. It stressed the need for increased resources to meet EU priorities, including the EU2020 strategy and Treaty of Lisbon obligations, noting that even a 5% budget increase over 2013 levels would be insufficient to fully address existing commitments. The resolution highlighted the success of LIFE+ in environmental protection and biodiversity, particularly supporting Natura 2000, and called for at least 10% of LIFE’s budget (€580 million annually) to address Natura 2000’s €5.8 billion yearly funding gap, with the remainder covered by other EU funds, member states, and private sources. It urged that expanding LIFE’s scope should not divert resources from proven projects, advocating instead for increased funding for traditional projects, environmental sub-programs, and innovative financial instruments. Parliament insisted that any MFF-related budget adjustments must prioritize these areas and warned against underfunding critical environmental goals.

title: Restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment (recast)
background: The EU’s 2003 RoHS Directive restricted hazardous substances in electronics, reducing environmental release but facing implementation challenges. Rapid growth in electronic waste, projected to reach 12.3 million tonnes by 2020, and evolving scientific insights necessitated regulatory updates. The Parliament will discuss revising RoHS to enhance restrictions, market harmonization, and enforcement mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally advocates the revised RoHS Directive's alignment with environmental protection and internal market harmonization, perfectly reflecting the party's dual commitment to sustainable development and economic competitiveness.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the exclusion of renewable energy technologies from the directive's scope, ensuring Europe's green transition maintains industrial leadership without disproportionate regulatory burdens.  
EPP fundamentally advocates the risk-based methodology for substance restrictions, recognizing its scientific rigor and consistency with REACH as vital for legal coherence in EU policymaking.  
EPP unequivocally supports the transitional periods for industry compliance, demonstrating the party's pragmatic approach to balancing ecological imperatives with SME operational realities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with maintaining exemptions for critical sectors like medical devices and photovoltaics, upholding the principle that regulatory action must follow conclusive evidence of health/environmental risks.

EFD partially agrees the three-year review commitment but requests revisions to Annex III's expanded substance list, citing insufficient scientific basis for phasing out 33 materials.  
EFD opposes the issue's approach to nanomaterials regulation, arguing it creates market uncertainty by mandating restrictions before establishing standardized definitions.  
The proposal fundamentally disapproves with EFD's principle of evidence-based policymaking by prioritizing PVC phase-outs without demonstrating viable industrial alternatives.  
EFD highlights that the expanded scope overlooks critical economic consequences, particularly job losses in sectors reliant on halogenated flame retardants, contradicting their employment protection priorities.  
EFD demands major changes to exemption timelines, insisting on flexibility for SMEs to adapt to substance bans while maintaining competitiveness.

ALDE strongly upholds the revised scope of hazardous substance restrictions, aligning with their commitment to balanced environmental regulation and internal market harmonization under Article 114 TFEU.  
ALDE approves the exclusion of PVC and nanomaterials from the directive's scope, recognizing the necessity for sector-specific risk assessments rather than blanket prohibitions in complex technical domains.  
ALDE proposes a future review of renewable energy equipment exemptions to ensure alignment with circular economy principles, suggesting enhanced lifecycle analysis protocols be added to recital 23.  
ALDE applauds the preservation of parliamentary co-decision authority under Article 294(3) TFEU, ensuring environmental protections remain proportionate to single market functionality.  
ALDE emphasizes the issue's success in rejecting politically motivated substance bans while urging stricter adherence to REACH chemical evaluation methodologies in subsequent implementation acts.

SD totally promotes the directive’s strengthened framework for hazardous substance regulation, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to environmental protection and human health through rigorous scientific reassessment mechanisms.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of phthalates, brominated flame retardants, and nanomaterials for review, advancing SD’s priority of proactive chemical risk management in line with evolving evidence.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of consumer transparency on pollutant content in electronics, reinforcing the directive’s alignment with SD’s advocacy for informed public participation in sustainability.  
SD highlights the imperative to monitor cadmium exemptions in solar panels as an enhancement opportunity, ensuring future revisions address cumulative environmental risks without opposing the current compromise.  
SD applauds the directive’s independence from REACH while advocating for synchronized enforcement, reflecting SD’s longstanding demand for coherent, health-centric internal market policies.

ECR strongly approves the removal of Annex III, which aligns with ECR's commitment to reducing unnecessary regulatory complexity and enhancing market accessibility for manufacturers.  
ECR applauds the issue’s adherence to Lisbon Treaty protocols under Articles 114 and 294 TFEU, reinforcing parliamentary authority in harmonizing internal market laws—a core ECR institutional priority.  
ECR proposes amending Article 4 to mandate pre-legislative impact assessments for any future scope expansions, ensuring market stability and mitigating unintended compliance burdens.  
ECR emphasizes the critical need to integrate RoHS restrictions with REACH’s evolving chemical governance framework, urging the Commission to prioritize regulatory coherence to eliminate duplication.  
ECR welcomes the Commission’s commitment to post-implementation reviews, reflecting ECR’s principle of iterative, evidence-driven policy refinement.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the open scope framework in the recast directive, which perfectly aligns with their longstanding commitment to rigorous environmental safeguards and reducing toxic materials in electronics.  

GUE_NGL proposes expanding Annex II to include chlorinated/brominated flame retardants, phthalates, and PVC by 2024, citing leading manufacturers’ voluntary elimination of these substances as a model for feasible, cost-effective regulation.  

GUE_NGL approves the issue’s use of Article 114 TFEU to harmonize standards but urges accelerated timelines to match industry best practices and prevent delayed health protections.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes the directive’s potential to curb ecological dumping in developing nations, advocating stricter substance bans to align with their manifesto goals on global environmental justice.  

GUE_NGL highlights the need for proactive substance restrictions to address disproportionate harm from e-waste exports, reinforcing their advocacy for equitable sustainability frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the implications of the Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force on ongoing interinstitutional decision-making procedures, as outlined in the European Commission’s 2009 communication (COM(2009)0665). It emphasized the need to align existing legislative processes with the treaty’s revised framework, particularly under Article 294(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (TFEU), which governs the ordinary legislative procedure, and Article 114 TFEU, which pertains to the harmonization of internal market laws. The resolution underscored the legal and procedural adjustments required to ensure continuity and compliance with the treaty’s provisions, focusing on maintaining the integrity of ongoing legislative initiatives while adapting to the strengthened role of the Parliament and updated decision-making mechanisms introduced by the Lisbon Treaty.

title: Waste electrical and electronic equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) (recast)
background: The European Union’s 2003 Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Directive faced challenges including inconsistent implementation, diverging national collection rates, illegal waste exports, and evolving resource efficiency priorities amid rising electronic waste volumes. The Parliament will discuss revising the directive to strengthen collection targets, enforcement mechanisms, and harmonization across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the directive's emphasis on stricter enforcement mechanisms to ensure Member State compliance with WEEE collection targets, aligning with its environmental accountability principles.  
EPP approves the consumer transparency measures requiring separate recycling cost invoicing as instrumental in fostering public engagement with circular economy goals.  
EPP endorses the reinforced anti-fraud provisions against illegal WEEE shipments, recognizing their critical role in preserving EU raw materials and preventing environmental dumping.  
EPP commends the compromise on collection targets based on generated waste rather than market volumes, addressing consumption disparities between newer and older Member States.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 14 with mandatory impact assessments for directive scope adjustments to balance environmental ambition with SME operational realities.

EFD partly advocates the revised collection infrastructure funding in Article 47 but requests explicit guarantees that penalties won't replace national capacity-building efforts.  
EFD fully condemns with the 85% collection target in Article 7(1), citing its incompatibility with member states' waste management sovereignty and practical enforcement realities.  
EFD rejects the 5% reuse quota as environmentally counterproductive, demanding its deletion to prevent unsafe recirculation of obsolete electronics.  
EFD requests revision of Article 4a to exclude consumer disposal autonomy, arguing current wording creates unenforceable liability chains for distributors.  
EFD opposes the cross-border retailer obligations in Article 93 as insufficiently stringent, requiring stricter registration rules to prevent e-commerce loopholes.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the increased 85% collection target by 2016, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing hazardous e-waste leaks and illegal exports.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the 5% re-use target for complete devices as a critical step toward circular economy principles outlined in their 2023 manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA approves mandatory retailer collection systems for small-volume waste, effectively advancing grassroots accessibility to responsible disposal channels.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Annex II to include solar cells, enhancing fair competition and accelerating cadmium-free alternatives in line with toxicity reduction goals.  
GREEN_EFA urges strengthening Article 12 to mandate real-time shipment tracking, transforming Carl Schlyter’s export concerns into enforceable safeguards against environmental dumping.

SD strongly upholds the ambitious recycling targets and measures to curb illegal exports, aligning with their commitment to environmental ethics and resource efficiency.  
SD approves the focus on small electronic waste and stricter producer responsibilities, ensuring eco-design principles that facilitate repair and recycling.  
SD applauds the job creation potential and reduced import dependence through effective WEEE recycling, as outlined in their green economy priorities.  
SD proposes eliminating exemptions for cadmium-telluride solar panels to maintain consistency with hazardous substance regulations and prevent environmental contamination.  
SD underscores the importance of accessible kerbside collection systems to drive higher public compliance with recycling targets, reinforcing resource efficiency goals.

ECR strongly advocates the directive’s producer-pays principle, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal consolidation and shielding taxpayers from recycling cost burdens.  
ECR approves the emphasis on Member State flexibility in meeting targets, proposing an amendment to Article 6 to clarify national discretion in compliance mechanisms while upholding binding objectives.  
ECR applauds the ambitious small WEEE collection targets, urging enhanced Annex III reporting protocols to ensure traceability without overburdening local authorities.  
ECR advocates refining product definitions in Article 3(1)(b) to exclude non-recyclable or durable equipment, ensuring scope realism while fully endorsing harmonized cross-border transport rules.  
ECR emphasizes adherence to subsidiarity in administrative procedures, recommending a recast of Article 9 to limit EU-level prescriptiveness and align with Treaty of Lisbon principles.

GUE/NGL strongly sanctions the enhanced export regulations for electronic waste, aligning with their commitment to global environmental justice and protection of vulnerable populations.  
GUE/NGL proposes amending Annex IV to include solar modules under mandatory producer collection schemes, eliminating voluntary measures that risk improper handling of toxic substances like cadmium.  
GUE/NGL applauds the ambitious 65% collection target by 2020, while urging binding EU-wide monitoring mechanisms to address disparities in Member State implementation capacities.  
GUE/NGL advocates revising Article 14(1) to adopt Amendment 91, ensuring unambiguous obligations for recycling efficiency and rejecting exemptions that dilute accountability for large equipment categories.  
GUE/NGL calls for a Commission investigation into nanomaterials’ health impacts during recycling, emphasizing precautionary principle adherence if hazards cannot be conclusively disproven.
