Parliament called for suspending GM authorizations until a revised regulation addressing national concerns beyond health and environmental risks is adopted, urged the Commission to repeal Decision 2015/2279, and demanded a new legislative proposal aligned with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU to restore a functional approval framework.

title: Objection pursuant to Rule 106: draft Commission regulation amending Annex II to Regulation (EC)1107/2009 by setting out scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the draft Commission regulation amending Annex II to Regulation (EC) 1107/2009 by setting out scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties
background: The European Commission faced delays in establishing scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors under Regulation (EC) 1107/2009, prompting a 2015 Court of Justice ruling mandating action. A 2017 draft regulation proposing criteria raised concerns over alignment with legal mandates and scientific robustness. The Parliament will discuss compliance and adequacy of endocrine disruptor identification criteria.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the exemption clause for substances with intended endocrine effects as it fully doubts with their commitment to hazard-based regulation and the precautionary principle.  
EPP opposes the draft’s failure to include a "suspected endocrine disruptor" category, which overlooks critical aspects of preventive health protection akin to CMR classifications.  
EPP highlights the inconsistency between the draft’s simplified definition of endocrine mode of action and stricter EFSA/ECHA guidance, risking systemic underidentification of disruptors.  
EPP demands withdrawal of the draft and deletion of the exemption clause, insisting legislative amendments under Article 294 TFEU are required to alter core hazard criteria.  
EPP criticizes the prioritization of standardized protocol data over independent studies as inconsistent with scientific rigor, perpetuating unnecessary animal testing.

GREEN_EFA firmly promotes the issue’s insistence on maintaining hazard-based cut-off criteria, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to prioritizing human and environmental health over industry exemptions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand to delete the derogation for substances with intended endocrine modes of action, as this directly upholds their manifesto pledge to eliminate regulatory loopholes for toxic chemicals.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the alignment with EFSA/ECHA scientific guidance, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for independent, evidence-based policymaking free from corporate influence.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue’s rejection of data prioritization hierarchies that marginalize independent studies, mirroring their 2023 campaign against biased regulatory frameworks favoring industry-submitted data.  
GREEN_EFA unreservedly backs the call to reinstate a “suspected endocrine disruptor” category, a measure they have championed since 2016 to enable precautionary action akin to CMR classifications.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s objection to the Commission’s draft regulation, aligning with their longstanding commitment to science-driven environmental protection and hazard-based regulatory frameworks.  
ALDE endorses the deletion of the exemption clause for substances with intended endocrine modes of action, ensuring all disruptors are assessed under strict hazard-based criteria without political interference.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of introducing a “suspected endocrine disruptor” category, mirroring CMR classifications, to enable proactive regulatory measures and uphold the precautionary principle.  
ALDE advocates for mandatory integration of read-across methodologies in the revised criteria to accelerate hazard identification while reducing reliance on redundant animal testing.  
ALDE proposes amending the revised guidance to explicitly require equal evaluation of independent peer-reviewed studies alongside standardized protocols, ensuring scientific rigor aligns with EFSA/ECHA standards.

SD strongly advocates the objection to the Commission’s exemption clause for substances with intended endocrine modes of action, aligning with SD’s commitment to upholding hazard-based cut-off criteria as mandated by Regulation (EC) 1107/2009.  
SD applauds the issue’s insistence on criteria grounded solely in objective science, free from economic influence, which advances SD’s priority of prioritizing public health over industry interests.  
SD proposes enhancing the draft by introducing a “suspected endocrine disruptor” category, mirroring CMR classifications, to enable precautionary action while maintaining scientific rigor.  
SD urges stricter alignment with EFSA/ECHA guidance on endocrine mode of action definitions to prevent underidentification of disruptors, ensuring consistency with SD’s environmental health objectives.  
SD calls for explicit inclusion of read-across methodologies in the criteria to reduce redundant animal testing, reinforcing SD’s advocacy for ethical and efficient regulatory science.

ECR totally againsts the draft regulation for exceeding the Commission’s delegated powers, violating institutional balance and legislative procedures under Article 294 TFEU.  
ECR rejects the political compromise in criteria development, demanding strict adherence to scientific objectivity as required by the General Court’s 2015 ruling.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s failure to maintain hazard-based cut-off criteria, undermining core principles of preventive environmental protection.  
ECR condemns the exemption for substances with intended endocrine effects as a dangerous loophole inconsistent with precautionary regulation of chemicals.  
ECR opposes the omission of a "suspected endocrine disruptor" category, which disregards necessary risk mitigation akin to CMR classifications.

GUE_NGL totally promotes the issue's demand to withdraw the Commission's draft regulation, aligning perfectly with their uncompromising stance against exemptions for endocrine disruptors with intended modes of action.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the call to delete the exemption clause, as this directly advances their priority to eliminate all hazard-based loopholes in chemical regulation.  
GUE_NGL fully supports the issue’s emphasis on scientific rigor and the precautionary principle, which mirrors their decades-long advocacy for removing endocrine disruptors from consumer and agricultural products.  
GUE_NGL strongly endorses the issue’s critique of the Commission’s procedural overreach, reinforcing their commitment to democratic oversight in EU chemical policy.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s rejection of data hierarchies favoring industry protocols, as this aligns with their mandate to prioritize independent science and comprehensive risk assessment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the draft Commission regulation setting scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors, arguing it exceeds the Commission’s implementing powers under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 by introducing a derogation exempting substances with an intended endocrine mode of action (e.g., growth regulators) from being classified as endocrine disruptors for non-target organisms, thereby undermining the hazard-based cut-off criterion in Annex II. The Parliament emphasized that the General Court’s 2015 judgment requires criteria to be based solely on objective scientific data, independent of economic considerations, and stressed that altering essential regulatory elements like the cut-off criterion must be done via legislative amendment under Article 294 TFEU, not through implementing acts. It criticized the draft for failing to align with the Seventh Environment Action Programme’s mandate for horizontal, hazard-based criteria, noting omissions such as a “suspected endocrine disrupter” category (akin to CMR classifications in Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008) and the exclusion of read-across methodologies, which could hinder regulatory action and necessitate redundant animal testing. The Parliament also highlighted inconsistencies between the draft regulation’s simplified definition of “endocrine mode of action” and the stricter EFSA/ECHA guidance, which risks underidentifying disruptors, and opposed the prioritization of data from standardized protocols over independent studies. It called for the draft’s withdrawal, deletion of the exemption clause, and revised guidance ensuring scientific rigor, weight-of-evidence approaches, and parity in data evaluation.

title: Packaging and packaging waste: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
background: The EU's 1994 Packaging Directive established waste management standards, but rising packaging waste volumes, environmental concerns, and divergent national recycling rates prompted the 2015 Commission proposal to update regulations. The Parliament will discuss amendments to align packaging waste measures with circular economy goals, addressing sustainability challenges and material recovery inefficiencies.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly accepts the enhanced recycling targets but demands amendments to exempt member states from binding EU-wide harmonization, asserting national sovereignty over waste policy design.  
EFDD contends the issue fundamentally rejects with subsidiarity principles by imposing centralized environmental standards without equivalent obligations on global economic competitors like China.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's failure to prohibit waste incineration entirely, advocating instead for stricter bans to prevent continued reliance on carbon-intensive disposal methods.  
The proposal overlooks critical market distortions by permitting fossil fuel subsidies to persist, which EFDD argues undermines genuine circular economy incentives for renewable material innovation.  
EFDD requests revisions to Article 9 landfill restrictions to empower national parliaments in setting regionally adaptable transition timelines rather than fixed EU benchmarks.

ENF rejects the fiscal incentives as a violation of member state prerogatives under subsidiarity principles, contrary to ENF's defense of national sovereignty.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the extended producer responsibility scheme for disproportionately burdening manufacturers while exempting supply chain intermediaries, exacerbating uncontrollable production costs.  
This totally disapproves with ENF's position that EU legislation must respect regional economic diversity, as the rigid framework overlooks disparate waste management realities across member states.  
The proposal fails to address ENF's documented concerns about 400% tax increases on artisans and families in Italy, directly contradicting the party's mandate to reduce citizen financial burdens.  
ENF condemns the issue's 230-page complexity as emblematic of EU overreach, creating bureaucratic labyrinths inconsistent with practical cost reduction for SMEs.

GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue’s binding 70% municipal waste recycling target by 2030, perfectly aligning with the party’s vision for systemic circular economy transitions.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the proposed 5% landfill limit for municipal waste, emphasizing that this prevents harmful waste-to-energy overreliance and accelerates material reuse.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the 80% packaging recycling target, which mirrors the party’s demands to phase out single-use materials and prioritize reusable/refundable packaging systems.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with binding food waste reduction goals, recognizing their critical role in reducing marine pollution and promoting localized resource efficiency.  
This issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority to eliminate planned obsolescence through eco-design mandates, creating 34,000+ jobs as highlighted in impact assessments.

SD firmly agrees the binding marine waste targets and minimum recycled plastic requirements as perfectly aligning with their environmental protection agenda.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's food waste reduction hierarchy and binding quota framework, advancing SD's manifesto commitment to combat "scandalous" food disposal.  
SD fully supports the landfill phase-out provisions and waste transfer monitoring system, recognizing their critical role in transitioning to a circular resource model.  
SD applauds the integration of social economy principles into packaging reforms, directly mirroring SD's 2023 Circular Economy Action Plan priorities.  
SD strongly affirms the product redesign requirements for reuse/repair compatibility as effectively advancing SD's industrial transition goals.

ECR partly approves the recycling targets but requests differentiated timelines for member states with lower baseline rates, referencing Poland's need for 225% increase by 2030 as unachievable without flexibility clauses.  
ECR requests revision of Article 8a to remove prescriptive extended producer responsibility requirements, advocating national flexibility in scheme design while maintaining core accountability principles.  
ECR proposes amending Article 3 to mandate an EU-wide standardized recycling calculation methodology, citing Flanders' success with comparable metrics for material recovery.  
ECR urges inclusion of explicit citizen engagement strategies in Article 11, requiring member states to implement public awareness campaigns on reuse initiatives.  
ECR emphasizes the need to prioritize Horizon Europe funding for circular business models in Annex II, particularly for industrial symbiosis and bio-waste valorization technologies.

GUE/NGL strongly promotes the issue’s systemic approach to waste reduction, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmental justice and participatory governance through local community engagement.  
GUE/NGL applauds the ambitious recycling targets and circular economy integration, particularly the emphasis on renewable energy as critical for sustainable material cycles.  
GUE/NGL endorses binding producer responsibility requirements and landfill phase-out mandates, urging increased EU funding for regions disproportionately affected by austerity to meet these targets.  
GUE/NGL proposes enhancing Article 11 to allow regulated energy recovery from non-recyclable waste under strict emissions standards where scientifically preferable to landfilling, maintaining ecological safeguards.  
GUE/NGL strongly promotes the issue’s provisions for public consultation and landfill audits, emphasizing their role in combating environmental health emergencies caused by improper waste management.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2015 legislative proposal (COM(2015)0596) aimed at harmonizing rules under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, while addressing objections from the French Senate over non-compliance with subsidiarity principles. It adopted its first-reading position based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0029/2017) and considered opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2016) and the Committee of the Regions (June 2016). The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments are made, ensuring parliamentary oversight, and instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence under Article 294(3) of the Treaty.

title: Health technology assessment: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on health technology assessment and amending Directive 2011/24/EU
background: Prior to parliamentary consideration, EU member states conducted fragmented national health technology assessments (HTA), leading to duplicated efforts, delayed patient access to innovative treatments, and increased costs. Existing voluntary cooperation mechanisms like EUnetHTA faced limitations in harmonizing methodologies across borders. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified regulatory framework for cross-border HTA collaboration.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally sanctions the establishment of joint clinical assessments to eliminate therapeutic value disparities across member states, perfectly aligning with its vision of a unified European health market.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of early innovation identification, which accelerates patient access to transformative therapies while maintaining national pricing autonomy.  
EPP fundamentally sanctions the voluntary scientific consultation framework, recognizing it as a critical tool to harmonize expertise and reduce redundant national evaluations that delay life-saving treatments.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on capacity-building for smaller member states, ensuring equitable access to HTA resources without overriding national health authorities’ roles.  
EPP strongly upholds the exclusion of abrupt regulatory impacts on medical device SMEs, framing this precaution as essential to balance innovation promotion with sectoral stability.

EFDD partially sanctions joint clinical assessments but demands binding criteria to exclude marginally effective therapies like cetuximab, requiring amended Annex 1 thresholds for "significant patient impact."  
EFDD requests revising Article 5 on scientific consultations to mandate parallel national assessment protocols, preventing EU-level conclusions from overriding member states' cost-effectiveness analyses.  
EFDD warns the issue inadequately addresses CAP/TTIP health policy contradictions, proposing Recital 17 additions to prohibit HTA approvals for technologies linked to pesticide-dependent production chains.  
EFDD insists Section 4(2) include explicit opt-outs allowing states to reject joint assessments when pharmaceutical pricing exceeds nationally defined affordability benchmarks.  
EFDD challenges the centralized "emerging technology" prioritization mechanism in Article 7, urging decentralized alerts through existing national pharmacovigilance systems to respect subsidiarity.

ENF opposes fundamentally the centralized health technology assessment framework, citing France's erosion of affordable generics as economic interests overriding patient care.  
ENF rejects the issue's economic prioritization, which conflicts with their principle that member state sovereignty must prevail in healthcare decisions.  
The proposal fails to address ENF's concerns about transparency, risking corporate influence over clinical evaluations of devices like extracorporeal circulation equipment.  
ENF highlights contradictions with national autonomy, as joint EU-level assessments could invalidate locally validated treatments against member states' wishes.  
The issue overlooks safeguards against profit-driven exclusion of proven techniques, inconsistent with ENF's stance on protecting innovative SMEs and patient access.

ALDE fundamentally supports the establishment of EU-wide joint clinical assessments as perfectly aligning with its commitment to patient-centric innovation and cross-border healthcare equity.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on voluntary cooperation frameworks, recognizing their necessity to preserve member states’ autonomy in reimbursement decisions while advancing pan-European research synergies.  
ALDE fundamentally supports the streamlined single clinical testing process for manufacturers, which directly advances its agenda to reduce administrative fragmentation and accelerate market access for breakthrough therapies.  
ALDE’s prioritization of emerging health technology identification is wholly reflected in the issue’s mechanisms for early innovation tracking, reinforcing Europe’s competitive position in medical R&D.  
 While initially advocating for delayed medical device assessments, ALDE recognizes the rapporteur’s narrowed scope as an enhancement opportunity that maintains alignment with safety standards under existing regulations.

SD fundamentally agrees the joint clinical assessment framework as perfectly aligning with their commitment to pan-European healthcare equity, particularly in accelerating patient access to breakthrough therapies while eliminating redundant national evaluations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s scientific consultation mechanism, recognizing its capacity to strengthen evidence-based decision-making and uphold rigorous therapeutic standards across all member states.  
SD emphasizes that centralized HTA cooperation directly advances their manifesto priority of sustainable health systems through optimized resource allocation and prevention of fragmented market authorizations.  
SD applauds the early identification protocol for emerging technologies as transformative for innovation-driven care models, ensuring EU-wide preparedness to adopt high-impact medical advancements.  
SD underscores the issue’s adherence to subsidiarity principles by focusing exclusively on clinical evaluations while safeguarding national autonomy over reimbursement decisions and pricing policies.

GUE_NGL slightly upholds the framework for joint clinical assessments but criticizes the exclusion of economic, social, and ethical aspects as absolutely conflicting with their commitment to comprehensive healthcare equity.  
GUE_NGL requests revising Article 9 to mandate patient representation in the coordination group, emphasizing that current provisions fail to address democratic participation in health governance.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposed extended transitional period, urging amendments to accelerate implementation and ensure timely patient access across all member states.  
GUE_NGL demands the inclusion of medical devices in joint assessments, stating that their de facto exclusion contradicts the issue's goal of harmonized health technology evaluation.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the progress on rare disease treatments but insists this must be paired with broader systemic reforms to achieve equitable patient outcomes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance health technology assessment (HTA) cooperation across the EU by establishing a framework for joint clinical assessments focusing on the most innovative health technologies with significant potential patient impact, joint scientific consultations to enable developers to seek advice from HTA authorities, and early identification of emerging health technologies to prioritize promising innovations. The resolution emphasized voluntary cooperation in additional areas, adopted its position at first reading based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report, and called on the Commission to refer the matter back to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its original proposal, ensuring alignment with legislative procedures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

title: Implementation of the Ecodesign Directive: REPORT on the implementation of the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC)
background: The Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC) established energy efficiency standards for energy-related products, aligning with EU climate goals and circular economy objectives. Implementation since 2009 included 29 regulations and voluntary agreements, while gaps persisted in addressing non-energy impacts, lifecycle sustainability, and market compliance. The Parliament will discuss strengthening the directive’s scope, enforcement, and alignment with broader environmental priorities.

stances.stance:
EFDD firmly disputes with the issue's failure to exempt theatre lighting systems, disproportionately harming cultural sectors through forced adoption of unproven alternatives.  
EFDD partially endorses circular economy principles but demands amended Article 7 to exclude stage lighting equipment until viable LED solutions meet artistic quality standards.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's inconsistency with innovation freedom by banning specialized tungsten lamps without consulting entertainment industry stakeholders.  
EFDD requests revisions to Annex III to create permanent exemptions for SMEs in creative industries facing €20,000+ retrofitting costs per venue.  
 While supporting reuse sector job growth concepts, EFDD rejects blanket product bans that erase niche technical ecosystems like theatrical lighting supply chains.

ENF supports the emphasis on expanding ecodesign criteria to ICT devices, particularly measures to reduce dependency on rare earth metals through enhanced recyclability and durability standards.  
ENF advises strengthening market surveillance mechanisms to prioritize blocking non-compliant imports from Asia, aligning with the issue’s call for harmonized testing and penalties.  
ENF highlights the need for accelerated Commission guidance to member states to address implementation delays, ensuring SMEs receive tailored support for compliance.  
ENF suggests explicitly integrating targets for ethical sourcing of raw materials into product passports to reinforce circular economy principles.  
ENF expresses concern about insufficient focus on reducing microplastics in ICT components, urging stricter hazardous substance restrictions in future revisions.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the expansion of ecodesign requirements to ICT devices, aligning perfectly with their commitment to lifecycle sustainability and resource justice in digital technologies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of ethical sourcing criteria for rare minerals, effectively advancing their manifesto priorities on human rights and environmental due diligence in supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Annex III to explicitly mandate microplastic filtration systems in washing machines, strengthening the issue’s hazardous substance restrictions.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the digital product passport system as critical for enforcing reparability standards and circular material flows in electronics.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of implementing binding recyclability quotas for smartphones, urging faster regulatory timelines to match planetary boundaries.

ALDE strongly promotes the expansion of ecodesign criteria to encompass recyclability, durability, and reparability, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to systemic resource efficiency and circular economy transitions.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on broadening the directive’s scope to ICT products and furniture, proposing accelerated inclusion of these high-impact sectors to maximize material recovery and waste reduction.  
ALDE applauds the integration of lifecycle assessments and digital product passports as critical enhancements to market surveillance, effectively advancing their priority of transparent, innovation-driven environmental governance.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to harmonize ecodesign standards with ethical sourcing requirements for raw materials, reinforcing the issue’s call to address supply chain sustainability without opposing its core framework.  
ALDE urges prioritizing rapid implementation for product groups with outsized climate footprints, such as smartphones, to deliver immediate emissions reductions while maintaining full alignment with the directive’s goals.

SD strongly upholds expanding the Ecodesign Directive's scope to ICT devices, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to circular economy principles through lifecycle criteria like reparability and recycled material use.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on harmonized market surveillance, proposing enhanced digital product passports to address non-compliance while maintaining single market integrity.  
SD urges faster integration of ethical sourcing requirements for critical raw materials, noting this directly advances SD's 2023 manifesto goals on supply chain sustainability.  
SD proposes maintaining specific exemptions for theater lighting systems during transitional periods to prevent cultural sector burdens while fully endorsing long-term efficiency targets.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to allocate EU cohesion funds for SME compliance support, ensuring affordability aligns with social justice priorities in green transitions.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes expanding the Ecodesign Directive’s scope to non-energy products like smartphones, aligning perfectly with their commitment to systemic circular economy reforms.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on lifecycle criteria such as durability and reparability, which effectively advances their advocacy for reducing resource exploitation and waste generation.  
GUE_NGL endorses stricter market surveillance and digital product passports as critical tools to combat non-compliance, reflecting their demand for robust enforcement mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL proposes explicitly prioritizing textiles and construction materials in future ecodesign regulations to address overlooked high-impact sectors.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the necessity of integrating chemical safety frameworks with ecodesign rules to eliminate hazardous substances like microplastics, consistent with their health-first environmental policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing the Ecodesign Directive to maximize its role in achieving EU climate, energy efficiency, and circular economy goals. It highlighted the directive’s success in reducing energy consumption (projected 175 Mtoe annual savings by 2020) and greenhouse gas emissions (320 million tonnes CO2eq/year), generating €55 billion in annual revenue for industries and €490 annual savings per household. The resolution urged expanding the directive’s scope to include non-energy products, particularly ICT devices like smartphones, emphasizing lifecycle criteria such as durability, reparability, recyclability, and use of recycled materials. It called for stricter market surveillance to address non-compliance (10-25% of products), advocating for harmonized testing, digital product passports, and penalties for violations. The Parliament stressed integrating circular economy principles, including restrictions on hazardous substances (e.g., microplastics, POPs), ethical sourcing, and promoting secondary raw material markets. It emphasized the need for faster regulatory processes, alignment with energy labeling, and support for SMEs, while prioritizing low-income households in resource-efficient product adoption. The resolution also linked ecodesign to broader policies like the Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C target and urged EU institutions to lead by example in green public procurement and circular economy strategies.

title: Market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emission trading scheme: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emission trading scheme and amending Directive 2003/87/EC
background: Persistent oversupply of emission allowances under the EU Emissions Trading System, exacerbated by economic downturns reducing industrial demand and revealing structural inflexibilities in adjusting carbon market supply. The Parliament will discuss establishing a market stability reserve mechanism to address systemic imbalances and enhance the scheme’s effectiveness in meeting climate targets.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the market stability reserve as totally disputeing with EFDD's position that market-based mechanisms exacerbate economic decline and fail to address climate priorities.  
EFDD opposes the issue's reliance on regulatory price interventions, which contradict EFDD's principle that autonomous markets—not bureaucratic mechanisms—should determine energy costs.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as systemic fraud and human rights violations linked to emissions trading schemes, issues EFDD deems inherent to the ETS structure.  
EFDD condemns the issue for institutionalizing speculative financial practices that enrich brokers while undermining EU industries and employment.  
This framework fails to address EFDD's core objection: artificially inflating energy prices accelerates deindustrialization and contradicts urgent competitiveness needs.

ENF rejects the market stability reserve as a flawed mechanism that fails to address systemic ETS failures, contradicting their demand for complete system overhaul  
ENF opposes the indirect taxation burden on EU industries, highlighting competitive disadvantages against unregulated global polluters like China and the US  
ENF fully doubts with the proposal's neglect of Carbon Leakage protections, crucial for energy-intensive sectors' survival  
ENF condemns the ETS as enabling financial speculation and fraud, citing the €5 billion scandal as evidence of inherent structural weaknesses  
ENF disputes the issue's environmental efficacy, arguing it destabilizes EU economies while non-European aviation sectors gain unfair advantages

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the Market Stability Reserve as perfectly aligning with their climate governance priorities, particularly in addressing allowance surplus through structured mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s procedural rigor under Article 294 TFEU, which effectively advances their institutional transparency goals while maintaining parliamentary oversight.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to permanently retire surplus allowances in future ETS reforms, building on this issue’s foundation to ensure long-term carbon price signals.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the importance of preventing dilution of unallocated allowance provisions, urging strict adherence to direct reserve placement as a model for subsequent climate legislation.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes this compromise as vital progress while stressing that structural ETS reforms must follow to phase out free allowances and achieve science-based 2030 targets.

ALDE strongly endorses the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) as a critical tool to restore carbon price signals and incentivize green investments, aligning with their commitment to market-driven climate action and innovation-led decarbonization.  
ALDE applauds the accelerated MSR launch in 2019 instead of 2021, emphasizing its role in stabilizing emissions trading and reinforcing EU leadership ahead of global climate negotiations.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the MSR framework with an innovation fund for low-carbon technologies by 2020 to accelerate industrial modernization, reflecting their focus on future-oriented climate solutions.  
ALDE urges complementary measures to address carbon leakage risks and transitional challenges for coal-dependent regions like Poland, ensuring climate policy coherence with industrial competitiveness.  
ALDE approves the direct allocation of 900 million surplus permits to the MSR, preventing market distortion while maintaining alignment with long-term emission reduction targets.

SD strongly endorses the Market Stability Reserve as a critical mechanism to correct structural oversupply in the EU ETS, ensuring credible carbon pricing that aligns with SD’s climate leadership goals under the Paris Agreement.  
SD applauds the removal of 1.5 billion allowances to stabilize prices, which directly advances SD’s manifesto pledge to harmonize industrial competitiveness with decarbonization through predictable investment frameworks.  
SD proposes amending Article 3 to accelerate the Reserve’s activation timeline to 2017 rather than 2019, enhancing its relevance ahead of COP21 while maintaining the provisional compromise.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of coupling the Reserve with EU-wide financial solidarity mechanisms to offset asymmetric impacts on heavy industries, ensuring a just transition consistent with SD’s regional equity principles.  
 SD conditionally highlights the need for an independent carbon market authority in future ETS reforms to address residual volatility concerns, framing this as an enhancement rather than opposition.

GUE/NGL fully challenges the market stability reserve mechanism as it perpetuates reliance on failed carbon trading systems inconsistent with their demand for binding emission regulations.  
GUE/NGL rejects the issue's market-based approach, citing João Ferreira's evidence that EU ETS has never effectively priced carbon nor driven structural emission reductions since 2009.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal's failure to address systemic fraud risks and corporate windfall profits from emission allowances, as criticized by Kateřina Konečná regarding unresolved carbon leakage vulnerabilities.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue for ignoring Cornelia Ernst's critique of allowance surplus retention rather than direct cancellation, maintaining polluter advantages contrary to climate justice principles.  
GUE/NGL asserts the proposal conflicts with their manifesto by prioritizing market management over Merja Kyllönen's acknowledged need for "globally binding agreements" and regulatory alternatives to carbon trading.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0020) concerning environmental policy under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with legislative procedures under Article 294. It incorporated inputs from the European Economic and Social Committee’s June 2014 opinion and the Committee of the Regions, while relying on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0029/2015). The resolution formally adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to avoid unilateral amendments and instead re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial changes. It mandated the transmission of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring procedural adherence under Rule 59 of its Rules of Procedure while prioritizing institutional collaboration and transparency in legislative refinement.

title: Maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination following a nuclear accident: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation laying down maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency
background: Following historical nuclear incidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima, EU regulations from 1987 set post-accident radioactive contamination limits in food/feed, requiring updates under post-Lisbon Treaty frameworks. The Parliament will discuss establishing revised maximum permitted contamination levels and the legal basis for harmonizing public health and internal market standards.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's application of the precautionary principle through radiation limits ten times stricter than international maximums, aligning with EPP's commitment to prioritizing public health in food safety standards.  
EPP entirely advocates shifting to ordinary legislative procedure under Article 114 TFEU, ensuring parliamentary codecision to strengthen democratic oversight of radiological safeguards.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 31 Euratom implementation by mandating biannual scientific reviews of radiation thresholds to maintain alignment with cutting-edge research.  
EPP approves the issue’s reliance on Euratom expert committees and Codex Alimentarius standards, countering alarmist narratives while maintaining rigorous science-based policymaking.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of harmonized EU-wide contamination limits to prevent market fragmentation, consistent with its longstanding advocacy for a unified internal market framework.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally rejects the proposed radiation limits as dangerously inconsistent with public health protection, particularly the 626 Bq allowance for infant nutrition which exceeds pre-Chernobyl safety thresholds.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's reliance on undisclosed Euratom experts whose industry ties create unacceptable conflicts of interest in setting contamination standards.  
This proposal conflicts with GREEN_EFA's precautionary principle by falsely assuming only 10% food contamination post-accident, ignoring real-world nuclear disaster scenarios.  
The issue fails to address GREEN_EFA's evidence that permitted radiation doses would surpass 1mSv/year safety ceilings, directly endangering vulnerable populations.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the undemocratic process excluding parliamentary scrutiny of scientific assumptions behind lax contamination thresholds.

ALDE opposes fundamentally the legal basis shift from Euratom to TFEU frameworks, as Article 31 provides tailored radiation safeguards conflicting with general environmental provisions under Article 192.  
ALDE rejects parliamentary decision-making on technical contamination limits, asserting such determinations must remain exclusively with scientific experts per evidence-based protocols.  
ALDE highlights incompatibility with ECJ jurisprudence on radiological standards, notably regarding drinking water, which reinforces Euratom’s primacy over TFEU in radiation matters.  
ALDE contests the application of ordinary legislative procedures for radiological limits, arguing it politicizes safety metrics that require specialized Euratom governance structures.  
ALDE warns against diluting Euratom’s regulatory authority, as harmonization under TFEU Article 114 risks fragmenting scientific consensus and market stability in nuclear emergencies.

SD completely approves the issue’s alignment with Article 168 TFEU, ensuring Parliament’s co-decision role to prioritize public health in radioactive contamination limits.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for science-based maximum radiation thresholds, recognizing the necessity of independent expert consultations to maintain cutting-edge safety standards.  
SD emphasizes the critical enhancement of expert transparency, advocating for public disclosure of their qualifications to reinforce trust in EU food safety mechanisms.  
SD strongly accepts the issue’s insistence on immediate public information dissemination during radiological emergencies, fulfilling consumer protection mandates.  
SD applauds the precedence given to Euratom Treaty provisions under Article 31, safeguarding tailored radiation protections while harmonizing TFEU health priorities.

ECR firmly condemns the issue's expansion of parliamentary decision-making authority, which conflicts with the Euratom Treaty’s role as the primary framework for nuclear safety governance.  
ECR rejects the proposed contamination thresholds as dangerously high, failing to address risks from nuclear plants near EU population centers like Strasbourg and Brussels.  
ECR opposes the reliance on 1998 safety assumptions, which inaccurately model accidents as distant events rather than immediate threats to densely populated regions.  
ECR criticizes invoking TFEU environmental provisions (Article 192) as creating regulatory conflict with Euratom’s specialized radiation protection mandates under Article 31.  
ECR condemns the issue’s failure to prioritize drastic reductions in permissible radiation levels for food and water, directly endangering public health.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's reliance on outdated maximum contamination levels that fail to align with the Codex Alimentarius 2013 radionuclide criteria, firmly opposeing with their principle of zero tolerance for carcinogenic substances in food.  
GUE/NGL opposes the exclusion of critical isotopes from Annex I, highlighting how this omission contradicts scientific recommendations and leaves populations vulnerable to unmonitored radioactive threats.  
GUE/NGL condemns the refusal to integrate stricter post-accident food safety thresholds, a stance inconsistent with their demand for science-based "tolerancia cero" policies prioritizing health over corporate interests.  
GUE/NGL disputes the issue's legitimacy due to the unresolved anomalies in Euratom's dose assessments, which the Commission Independent Radiation Committee confirmed as dangerously underestimating risks.  
GUE/NGL demands democratic accountability for shelving expert consultations, a failure that perpetuates the regulatory capture criticized in their critique of revolving-door science governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to update the legal basis for regulating radioactive contamination to prioritize public health under Article 168(4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty, ensuring democratic legitimacy by granting Parliament a decision-making role. It emphasized harmonizing maximum residue limits for food and feed under Article 114 TFEU to safeguard the internal market and public health, while requiring the Commission to establish science-based basic safety standards—including maximum permissible radiation doses, exposure levels, and worker health protections—through consultations with scientific experts from member states and committees. The resolution stressed that the Euratom Treaty’s specific provisions on radiation protection, particularly Article 31, should take precedence over general TFEU environmental frameworks (e.g., Article 192), as they provide tailored safeguards against ionizing radiation. It mandated that future measures align with the Lisbon Treaty’s ordinary legislative procedure, ensuring high-level health protections informed by scientific advancements, and required member states to notify the Commission of public health concerns arising from harmonized rules, triggering prompt review. The Parliament also underscored that the Euratom Treaty’s provisions cannot be overridden by conflicting TFEU rules, preserving its role in regulating radioactive risks.

title: Medical devices: RECOMMENDATION FOR SECOND READING on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on medical devices, amending Directive 2001/83/EC, Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 and Regulation (EC) No 1223/2009 and repealing Council Directives 90/385/EEC and 93/42/EEC
background: Outdated EU medical device regulations from the 1990s faced criticism following safety scandals involving implants and diagnostic tools, exposing gaps in pre-market assessments, post-market surveillance, and transparency. The Parliament will discuss modernizing regulatory frameworks to strengthen patient safety, clinical evaluation, and market oversight for medical devices and in vitro diagnostics.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly promotes the issue’s risk-based surveillance framework but demands expedited adoption of endocrine disruptor identification criteria to prevent regulatory gaps in substance safety.  
EFDD objects to centralized EU laboratory networks under Article 12, arguing this undermines national competence and contradicts subsidiarity principles critical to EFDD’s decentralization agenda.  
EFDD supports lifetime monitoring requirements for high-risk devices yet insists on amendments to Annex III to mandate real-time public access to malfunction data for patient transparency.  
EFDD highlights unresolved tensions between EU-wide standardization and member state sovereignty, particularly in pre-market assessments under Chapter IV, which risk overburdening national systems.  
EFDD requests stricter prohibitions on non-medical grade materials in Article 10(3), citing the PIP implant scandal as evidence of systemic industrial loopholes.

ENF absolutely approves the regulation’s enhanced traceability requirements as a critical safeguard against fraudulent medical devices, perfectly aligning with their commitment to patient safety and sovereignty.  
ENF applauds the issue’s harmonized certification framework for reinforcing pan-European quality benchmarks, advancing their priority of equitable market access for SMEs.  
ENF emphasizes the necessity of maintaining national oversight capacities to complement notified bodies, ensuring rigorous enforcement without privatizing health governance.  
ENF supports accelerated implementation timelines to address historical regulatory gaps while urging proportional cost structures to prevent SME exclusion.  
ENF highlights the regulation’s alignment with long-term industrial competitiveness, urging targeted funding to offset certification burdens for micro-enterprises.

ALDE fully approves the enhanced patient safety measures and risk classification system as critical improvements post-breast implant scandal.  
 ALDE strongly approves maintaining decentralized approval processes to preserve innovation and patient access to medical technologies.  
 ALDE approves conditional allowance for single-use device reprocessing under strict member state oversight frameworks.  
 ALDE advocates retaining accessible clinical testing pathways to ensure timely patient access to diagnostic innovations.  
 ALDE urgently requests Commission resource allocation guarantees for proper implementation of delegated acts and notified body designation.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to mandate manufacturer insurance requirements despite patient safety claims.  
ECR opposes the genetic counseling provisions as incompatible with national healthcare sovereignty principles.  
This completely rejects with ECR's position that price stability should outweigh expanded liability mechanisms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding safeguards against regulatory overreach by EU agencies.  
ECR opposes centralized traceability systems as disproportionate to member states' existing monitoring capacities.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s failure to mandate immediate post-market surveillance mechanisms for medical devices, inconsistent with their demand for continuous safety verification.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the absence of binding timelines for member state implementation, overlooking critical risks of prolonged regulatory gaps.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s silence on mandatory punitive measures for non-compliant manufacturers, conflicting with their stance on corporate accountability.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s neglect of retrospective safety analyses for existing implants, a core demand following the French implant scandal.  
GUE/NGL disputes the theoretical 2020/2022 efficacy deadlines as structurally inadequate, failing to address decade-long procedural delays exposed in national analyses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Council’s first reading position (10728/4/2016) on a legislative act, adopting it in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure under Article 297(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution endorsed the act, which originated from the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0542) and incorporated the 2013 opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee and the 2017 recommendation of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (A8-0068/2017). It instructed the Parliament’s President and Secretary-General to formally sign the act, verify procedural compliance, and arrange for its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union, while also directing communication of the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution concluded the legislative process without amendments, finalizing the act as aligned with the Council’s negotiated text.

title: Mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy: REPORT on the mid-term review of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy
background: The EU’s 2020 Biodiversity Strategy, established to address ecosystem degradation and species decline, faced mid-term review indicating insufficient progress. Reports highlighted habitat loss, climate change, pollution, and invasive species as key pressures, alongside international commitments under the Aichi Targets and UN Sustainable Development Goals. The Parliament will discuss progress towards achieving the strategy’s 2020 targets.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially sanctions the issue's biodiversity targets but requests revisions to eliminate centralized marine management frameworks, advocating localized fisheries governance instead of Common Fisheries Policy expansion.  
EFDD opposes the issue's EU-wide Natura 2000 implementation mandates as inconsistent with EFDD's principle of national sovereignty, urging amendment to delegate management plans exclusively to member states.  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to address habitat loss drivers like UK migration-induced housing demands, which require national population policies rather than EU habitat directives.  
EFDD stresses the need to maintain existing Habitat and Birds Directives without revision, as proposed in Article 12, but rejects binding biomass sustainability criteria under the Renewable Energy Directive as bureaucratic overreach.  
EFDD criticizes deforestation linkage to palm oil trade as a pretext for EU regulatory encroachment on national agriculture policies, demanding deletion of Clause 22’s trade conditionality.

GREEN_EFA fully promotes the issue's emphasis on rigorous implementation of existing environmental directives, perfectly aligning with their principle that legal frameworks must be enforced before considering structural changes.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to operationalize the Aarhus Convention's access-to-justice provisions, recognizing this as essential for empowering citizens and local actors in biodiversity governance.  
GREEN_EFA fully promotes the prioritization of Natura 2000 management plans, viewing this as the cornerstone for achieving terrestrial and marine biodiversity targets through existing EU instruments.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of directive revisions under external pressures, affirming that legislative stability enables predictable conservation investments by regional stakeholders.  
GREEN_EFA fully promotes the integration of compliance monitoring into all biodiversity financing mechanisms, mirroring their longstanding demand for conditionality in EU subsidy programs.

ALDE totally accepts the issue's emphasis on strict enforcement of existing environmental legislation, perfectly aligning with ALDE's longstanding commitment to preserving the Birds and Habitats Directives as non-negotiable safeguards for Natura 2000 sites.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for multi-stakeholder governance models, proposing strengthened collaboration between agricultural innovators and conservation bodies to enhance ecosystem-based management without revising core directives.  
ALDE totally accepts integrating biodiversity across all SDG implementation, urging accelerated adoption of sustainability criteria for biomass production under the Renewable Energy Directive to complement existing agricultural modernization efforts.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s global leadership demands, advocating intensified EU funding for peat forest protection in Southeast Asia and stricter traceability requirements in trade agreements to combat deforestation.  
ALDE totally accepts marine biodiversity protections beyond national jurisdictions, emphasizing enhanced satellite monitoring systems and data-sharing frameworks to address gaps in habitat status assessments.

SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s emphasis on rigorous implementation of existing environmental legislation, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to safeguarding biodiversity through enforceable frameworks rather than disruptive revisions.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to integrate multi-stakeholder approaches in fisheries and agriculture, reflecting SD’s priority of ecosystem-based management to halt species loss while supporting sustainable livelihoods.  
SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s demand to combat deforestation linked to palm oil, echoing SD’s manifesto pledge to align trade policies with ecological imperatives and global climate justice.  
SD perfectly aligns with the urgency to eliminate harmful subsidies and enforce stricter controls on illegal fishing, recognizing these as critical enhancers of the EU’s global biodiversity leadership.  
SD fundamentally promotes embedding biodiversity into SDGs and climate agendas, a stance that effectively advances SD’s vision of policy coherence to limit warming below 2°C while protecting vital ecosystems.

ECR partially sanctions biodiversity protection goals but requests exemptions for shale gas extraction, arguing current restrictions contradict energy security priorities and lack evidence of unique environmental risks.  
ECR demands revision of trade provisions allowing duty-free Tunisian oil imports, citing incompatibility with fair competition principles and disproportionate harm to Greek farmers under austerity measures.  
ECR highlights fundamental conflict between the issue’s environmental mandates and member states’ sovereign rights to develop domestic energy resources, particularly Poland’s shale gas projects as a counter to Russian dependence.  
ECR urges amendments to agricultural biodiversity clauses to address tax inequities in fuel policies that disadvantage producers in austerity-affected nations like Greece.  
ECR supports ecosystem-based management principles but insists issue text explicitly exclude blanket bans on industrial activities lacking proven biodiversity harm, such as regulated shale gas operations.

GUE/NGL fundamentally endorses the issue's unequivocal defense of the Nature Directives, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to oppose any weakening of habitat and species protection laws.  
GUE/NGL perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on binding enforcement of biodiversity legislation, advancing their priority to hold Member States accountable for implementation failures rather than revising existing frameworks.  
GUE/NGL fundamentally endorses the condemnation of intensive agriculture’s biodiversity impacts, reflecting their demand to replace industrial livestock systems with agroecological practices as outlined in the issue’s sustainable farming goals.  
GUE/NGL perfectly aligns with the call to eliminate subsidies driving deforestation-linked palm oil imports, mirroring their stance against EU trade policies that accelerate global ecosystem destruction.  
GUE/NGL fundamentally endorses integrating biodiversity across climate and development agendas, advancing their vision of systemic policy coherence to halt overconsumption and habitat loss.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the slow progress in achieving the EU’s 2020 biodiversity targets, emphasizing the urgent need for Member States to prioritize implementation of environmental legislation, complete terrestrial and marine Natura 2000 site designations (noting only 58% had management plans in 2012), and adopt multi-stakeholder approaches involving regional and local actors. It highlighted the critical role of sustainable agriculture, forestry, and fisheries—including ecosystem-based management to achieve maximum sustainable yield—in halting biodiversity loss, while stressing the adverse impacts of land-use change, pollution, climate change, and invasive species. The resolution underscored the EU’s global responsibility, citing its status as the largest biodiversity donor (with funding doubled between 2006-2013) and urging alignment of trade agreements and development policies with biodiversity goals, including combating deforestation linked to palm oil production (90% of which occurs in Indonesia and Malaysia, driving peat forest destruction and greenhouse gas emissions). It called for integrating biodiversity into Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), eliminating harmful subsidies, promoting nature-based climate solutions, and addressing overconsumption patterns. Specific measures included developing sustainability criteria for biomass under the Renewable Energy Directive, reducing the EU’s global biodiversity footprint, and enforcing stricter controls on illegal fishing and wildlife trafficking. The Parliament also emphasized protecting marine biodiversity beyond national jurisdictions, safeguarding agricultural biodiversity in developing countries, and ensuring policy coherence across climate, energy, and development agendas to meet Aichi Targets and limit global warming to below 2°C.

title: Minimum requirements for water reuse: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on minimum requirements for water reuse
background: Increasing water scarcity in EU regions, driven by climate-related droughts and agricultural demands, alongside existing disparities in national water reuse frameworks, prompted the European Commission’s 2018 proposal under circular economy objectives. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing minimum standards for treated urban wastewater reuse in agriculture to enhance water resource sustainability.

stances.stance:
EPP totally promotes the regulation’s alignment with circular economy principles, particularly its potential to expand water reuse beyond agriculture to industrial sectors like petrochemicals, as demonstrated by successful LIFE-funded projects.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s climate adaptation focus, emphasizing that water scarcity—even in historically water-rich regions—demands proactive EU-wide standards to address climate-driven droughts.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for health safeguards in reused water quality, ensuring consumer trust and ecosystem protection through rigorous monitoring and farmer education, as highlighted in agricultural stakeholder consultations.  
EPP strongly endorses modernizing water infrastructure to minimize losses, aligning with the issue’s call for sustainable resource management and systemic upgrades to aging distribution networks.  
EPP backs the integration of water reuse into broader agricultural policies, ensuring coherence with CAP objectives and biodiversity protection while advancing the EU’s 2030 climate targets.

EFDD slightly sanctions the water reuse framework but demands Article 6 explicitly ban PFAS and endocrine disruptors in treated water.  
EFDD requests revising Annex II to include mandatory microplastic filtration standards, citing contamination risks to agricultural ecosystems.  
EFDD requires stricter monitoring protocols under Article 9 to ensure agricultural reuse does not compromise soil health or biodiversity.  
EFDD opposes any dilution of quality thresholds in recital 14, inconsistent with their principle of absolute environmental safeguards.  
EFDD insists on independent scientific review panels for risk assessments, absent in current provisions addressing pollutant accumulation.

ALDE fundamentally supports the harmonized EU standards for treated wastewater reuse, perfectly aligning with their commitment to climate-resilient agriculture and single market integrity.  
ALDE strongly endorses the issue's binding criteria for food safety and public health protection, recognizing water reuse as essential for drought mitigation across member states.  
ALDE applauds the regulation’s potential to unlock 6.6 billion m³ of sustainable water resources, advancing their manifesto priorities for circular economy innovation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on preventing market distortions through unified rules, ensuring fair competition for agricultural products irrigated with reused water.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of EU-level action to address water scarcity, echoing their longstanding advocacy for science-based environmental policymaking and cross-border resource management.

SD totally sanctions the issue’s integration of flexible water reuse standards, perfectly aligning with S&D’s advocacy for regionally adaptable solutions that respect diverse hydrological conditions like those in Spanish basins.  
SD perfectly aligns with the push for EU-harmonized wastewater reuse criteria, recognizing this as a critical step toward mitigating water scarcity and advancing circular economy principles central to S&D’s environmental agenda.  
SD highlights the necessity of complementing water reuse measures with a future EU contaminated soils directive, proposing this as an enhancement to holistically address water quality at its source in line with ecological priorities.  
SD emphasizes extending wastewater reuse beyond agricultural irrigation to industrial and energy sectors under stringent safety protocols, framing this as a strategic expansion opportunity to maximize resource efficiency.  
SD fully supports the issue’s rigorous monitoring and sanction mechanisms, which align with S&D’s commitment to enforceable sustainability frameworks that protect public health and ecosystems.

ECR opposes the uniform imposition of water reuse requirements as outlined in Articles 4-7, which fail to account for the disparate water resource availability and management capabilities across member states.  
The proposal fully disputes with ECR's principle of subsidiarity by neglecting the necessity for regionally adaptable frameworks that prevent social polarization in peripheral, resource-poor areas.  
ECR highlights the issue's oversight of critical educational and awareness disparities among regions, inconsistent with the party's advocacy for gradual, context-sensitive policy implementation.  
The stringent conditions risk generating long-term counterproductive outcomes, directly opposing ECR's stance on avoiding top-down environmental mandates that exacerbate regional inequalities.  
By mandating abrupt compliance without phased adaptation periods, the proposal contradicts ECR's emphasis on equitable transitions that respect member states' unique socio-economic landscapes.

GUE_NGL strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on binding climate targets and biodiversity safeguards, aligning with their commitment to environmental justice and public health protection.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to mandate public ownership of water regeneration infrastructure, ensuring accountability over private operators’ profit-driven motives.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s integration of scientific monitoring for water reuse impacts, urging stricter aquifer protection standards to prevent cross-contamination.  
GUE_NGL highlights the necessity of circular economy principles in Annex III to mitigate rural waste displacement, reinforcing sustainable agricultural models.  
GUE_NGL firmly approves the issue’s alignment with the Paris Agreement, emphasizing its role in advancing equitable transitions for affected communities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0337) concerning environmental and agricultural policies, adopting amendments to strengthen climate action, biodiversity protection, and sustainable resource use. It emphasized alignment with the Paris Agreement and the EU’s 2030 climate targets, advocating for binding national emission reduction measures and enhanced monitoring of land use, forestry, and agricultural practices. The resolution stressed integrating biodiversity safeguards into EU funding programs and called for stricter controls on pesticide use to protect pollinators and ecosystems. It also highlighted the need for transparent stakeholder consultations and scientific assessments in policy implementation. Parliament urged the Commission to ensure coherence with existing EU laws, such as the Common Agricultural Policy, and to prioritize just transitions for affected sectors. The resolution mandated that any substantial revisions to the proposal by the Commission must be resubmitted to Parliament for further scrutiny, underscoring legislative accountability.

title: Governance of the Energy Union: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Governance of the Energy Union, amending Directive 94/22/EC, Directive 98/70/EC, Directive 2009/31/EC, Regulation (EC) No 663/2009, Regulation (EC) No 715/2009, Directive 2009/73/EC, Council Directive 2009/119/EC, Directive 2010/31/EU, Directive 2012/27/EU, Directive 2013/30/EU and Council Directive (EU) 2015/652 and repealing Regulation (EU) No 525/2013
background: The European Commission proposed a 2016 regulation to establish governance mechanisms for the Energy Union, aiming to coordinate climate and energy policies, meet 2030 emissions targets, and align with the Paris Agreement by amending multiple energy-related directives. The Parliament will discuss the regulatory framework for achieving integrated energy and climate objectives across EU member states.

stances.stance:
ENF fundamentally rejects the issue's centralization of energy governance as a direct assault on national sovereignty and competitive market principles.  
ENF opposes binding renewable targets that exclude nuclear energy, contradicting their stance on diversified decarbonization strategies.  
ENF condemns the issue's LNG import reliance as ecologically hypocritical, amplifying carbon footprints through transcontinental shipping.  
ENF dismisses transparency measures as superficial while the proposal ignores industrial competitiveness costs exceeding €500 billion.  
ENF challenges the moral authority of climate goals citing lawmakers' refusal to adopt personal sacrifices like reduced air travel.

GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the mandated transparency in legislative negotiations, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of accountability in climate governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on binding national renewable energy targets of at least 35%, reflecting their manifesto commitment to accelerate the phase-out of fossil fuels.  
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the exclusion of conditional mechanisms that risk diluting energy efficiency goals, as emphasized in the debate to prevent backtracking on Paris Agreement obligations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to ban palm oil-based biofuels by 2020, reinforcing their long-standing advocacy against deforestation-linked energy sources.  
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the integration of regional renewable energy initiatives, mirroring their support for community-led solutions highlighted in the debate as models for EU-wide adoption.

ALDE strongly advocates the governance framework as vital for legal certainty and achieving Paris Agreement targets, aligning with their commitment to a renewables-based energy transition.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s transparency measures and renewable energy focus, emphasizing their role in reducing fossil fuel dependence and enhancing EU competitiveness.  
ALDE highlights the necessity for increased ambition in renewable deployment to match global leaders like China, urging alignment with ALDE’s 2030 climate manifesto priorities.  
ALDE proposes streamlining bioenergy sustainability criteria to rely on national forestry laws, avoiding redundant EU bureaucracy while ensuring market-driven innovation.  
ALDE advocates reinforcing policy coherence across member states to prevent fragmented implementation, suggesting enhanced coordination mechanisms in Article 12.

SD strongly accepts the binding 40% energy efficiency target as critical for aligning with Paris Agreement goals, particularly its potential to lift 35 million Europeans out of energy poverty through housing renovations.  
SD applauds the issue's transparency mechanisms requiring disclosure of stakeholder meetings, which directly advance accountability in climate policymaking as outlined in the S&D 2023 manifesto.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 6 to specify sustainable biomass criteria, ensuring forest management supports carbon sequestration while meeting renewable energy targets.  
SD totally sanctions the integration of energy poverty eradication into national climate plans, mirroring Theresa Griffin's emphasis on protecting vulnerable households through legally binding renovation targets.  
SD recommends amending Annex III to include IRENA's cost-benefit methodology for renewable investments, strengthening the issue's economic competitiveness arguments while maintaining the 35% renewables target.

ECR rejects the binding 40% energy efficiency target as economically unjustified, fully againsting with their principle of cost-competitive energy policies.  
ECR opposes mandatory renewable energy thresholds that restrict national sovereignty over energy mix choices, inconsistent with treaty obligations under Article 194 TFEU.  
ECR condemns the issue’s disregard for energy poverty impacts, overlooking critical aspects like electricity price surges for low-income households.  
ECR challenges biomass restrictions in renewable targets, arguing the proposal fails to address sustainable forestry practices and regional energy security needs.  
ECR disputes the legal binding nature of climate plans, warning they create EU-level overreach into member states’ fiscal and energy infrastructure decisions.

GUE/NGL absolutely challenges the regulation's reliance on market-driven energy policies that perpetuate corporate monopolies over public energy sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL rejects the inclusion of biofuels in transport targets as ecologically destructive, citing deforestation risks and increased carbon emissions from land-use changes.  
GUE/NGL condemns the absence of legally binding national renewable targets as incompatible with Paris Agreement obligations, enabling member state non-compliance.  
GUE/NGL challenges the issue's vague energy poverty definition as insufficient for combating systemic exclusion from essential services across EU populations.  
GUE/NGL disputes the regulation's "unachievable linear trajectories" that disregard national economic capacities and physical resource limitations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced transparency and governance in energy and climate policies, adopting a position that mandates the publication of a list of all organizations and stakeholders met by co-rapporteurs Michèle Rivasi and Claude Turmes during legislative negotiations to ensure accountability. The resolution emphasizes aligning the EU’s energy transition with the Paris Agreement’s climate goals, stressing the importance of stakeholder engagement while preventing undue influence. It calls for robust monitoring and reporting mechanisms to track progress toward renewable energy targets and greenhouse gas reductions, integrating input from the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee. The Parliament also urged the Commission to revise its proposal to strengthen provisions on public participation, access to information, and coherence with existing environmental legislation, ensuring that national energy and climate plans are transparent, inclusive, and legally binding. The adopted text underscores the need to forward these measures to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to uphold democratic oversight and multi-level governance in EU climate action.

title: Landfill of waste: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 1999/31/EC on the landfill of waste
background: The European Commission’s 2015 proposal to revise Directive 1999/31/EC on landfill waste management followed concerns over resource inefficiency, environmental impacts of landfilling, and alignment with circular economy objectives. The Parliament will discuss amendments to reduce landfill dependency, improve waste management standards, and integrate sustainability goals into EU waste policy.

stances.stance:
EPP completely upholds the landfill directive amendment as it perfectly aligns with the party's commitment to transforming waste into reusable resources and securing raw materials for future generations.  
EPP perfectly supports binding recycling targets and landfill reduction measures to eliminate methane emissions, directly advancing the EPP's climate action priorities under the Circular Economy Package.  
EPP emphasizes that harmonized EU-wide definitions of municipal waste and recycling methodologies - as proposed in Amendment 251 - crucially prevent market fragmentation while maintaining environmental ambition.  
EPP highlights the directive's alignment with industrial innovation strategies, particularly in catalytic regions like Catalonia's Bufalvent industrial park, which demonstrates scalable circular economy models.  
EPP recognizes enhanced marine litter prevention through microplastic bans as a critical enhancement opportunity to complement core landfill diversion goals.

EFDD slightly upholds the landfill directive amendments but requests Article 3 be amended to prohibit waste incineration entirely, aligning with stricter environmental safeguards.  
EFDD demands revision of Clause 7 to phase out all fossil fuel subsidies, arguing current provisions contradict circular economy transition goals.  
EFDD challenges the proposal's adherence to subsidiarity, insisting national governments retain authority to implement tailored waste policies as raised in the French Senate's reasoned opinion.  
EFDD warns the directive firmly challenges with global competitiveness priorities by imposing uniform EU standards without addressing non-EU market disparities.  
EFDD asserts the issue overlooks corporate lobbying influences, requiring binding transparency measures in Annex 2 to counter industry capture of waste management frameworks.

ENF fundamentally rejects the extended producer responsibility scheme as contradicting national sovereignty over fiscal policy and economic freedom.  
ENF opposes the directive's lack of flexibility, citing its incompatibility with diverse regional waste management realities across EU member states.  
ENF condemns the proposal’s failure to reduce waste tax burdens, referencing Italy’s 400% cost increases as proof of anti-citizen consequences.  
ENF challenges the circular economy premise as hypocritical given the EU’s own institutional wastefulness and dysfunctional policies like the Türkiye deal.  
ENF declares the 230-page directive structurally flawed for prioritizing bureaucratic complexity over tangible cost reductions for families and businesses.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the binding 70% municipal waste recycling target by 2030, perfectly aligning with their circular economy roadmap to eliminate landfill dependency.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the 5% landfill cap for municipal waste by 2030, recognizing this as essential to prevent planetary-scale environmental collapse as warned in the Wall-E analogy.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the mandatory 50% food waste reduction target by 2030, seeing this as a systemic transformation of resource management consistent with their zero-waste manifestos.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand to phase out single-use packaging through reuse systems, mirroring their decade-long advocacy for material loop closure.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's integration of CO2 reduction and job creation metrics, confirming their stance that environmental ambition drives economic resilience.

SD fundamentally accepts the binding marine waste targets and recycled plastic requirements, perfectly aligning with their commitment to combatting aquatic ecosystem degradation.
