SD perfectly aligns with the landfill phase-out provisions, recognizing their critical role in transforming waste management systems toward resource recovery.  
SD fully supports mandatory EU-wide food waste reduction metrics, seeing these as essential for addressing both economic inefficiency and ethical resource allocation.  
SD fundamentally accepts the circular economy’s job creation potential, affirming its alignment with their manifesto priorities for green industrial transformation.  
SD perfectly aligns with product design integration proposals, emphasizing their necessity to achieve systemic material reuse from production inception.

ECR partly advocates the landfill directive amendments but demands deletion of Article 8a's prescriptive extended producer responsibility requirements to preserve national scheme flexibility.  
ECR opposes the uniform 65% municipal waste recycling target in Article 5(2), insisting on differentiated timelines for member states with current rates below 35%.  
ECR proposes amending Annex III to implement standardized EU-wide recycling calculation methodologies, preventing disparities in national reporting.  
ECR requests adding Article 9a to mandate citizen engagement programs in circular economy strategies, addressing insufficient public participation mechanisms.  
ECR urges revision of Recital 12 to include innovation grants for SMEs transitioning to circular models, ensuring competitiveness alongside environmental goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the compliance of the Commission’s 2015 legislative proposal to amend environmental legislation with the principle of subsidiarity, particularly in light of the French Senate’s reasoned opinion challenging this aspect. It adopted its first-reading position under Article 192(1) of the TFEU, emphasizing the need for the Commission to reassess and resubmit the proposal if substantial changes are introduced, while incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2016) and the Committee of the Regions (June 2016). The resolution instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with procedural requirements and substantive legal considerations.

title: Lessons learned from the red mud disaster five years after the accident in Hungary: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on lessons learned from the red mud disaster, five years after the accident in Hungary
background: The 2010 Hungarian red mud reservoir collapse caused fatalities, ecological damage, and raised concerns about hazardous waste classification discrepancies and implementation challenges of EU extractive waste regulations. The Parliament will discuss industrial disaster prevention, environmental liability frameworks, and EU-wide safety standards for hazardous material management.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the mandatory financial guarantees system to enforce the "polluter pays" principle, aligning with the issue's demand for harmonized mechanisms to hold industries accountable for environmental damages.  
EPP absolutely endorses creating an EU risk-sharing facility to address legacy pollution, particularly emphasizing its urgency for Central and Eastern Europe’s unresolved environmental liabilities as highlighted in the debate.  
EPP approves the call for binding EU-wide inspection criteria and stress tests for mining sites, noting this directly advances systemic prevention of industrial disasters like the red mud spill.  
EPP proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly mandating an EU catastrophe insurance framework to operationalize financial guarantees, ensuring immediate remediation funding even when polluters evade responsibility.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on transparency in post-disaster remediation, citing Hungary’s reconstruction of affected villages as proof of effective solidarity-based recovery aligned with EPP values.

EFDD partly promotes the issue's citizen involvement provisions but requests revisions to eliminate EU-wide binding inspection criteria, which contradict subsidiarity principles by centralizing environmental oversight.  
EFDD absolutely againsts mandatory harmonized financial guarantees (Article 9), arguing this imposes Brussels-centric solutions inconsistent with EFDD's rejection of EU regulatory overreach in national industries.  
EFDD demands amendment of the 2016 dry disposal technology deadline, aligning with Nathan Gill's warning that inflexible EU mandates risk destroying local industries without context-specific risk assessments.  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to condemn member state negligence, exemplified by Italy's dismantling of environmental inspection bodies despite EU pledges to strengthen oversight capacities.  
EFDD rejects the issue's implicit trust in Commission enforcement, citing systemic delays in financial security reports as proof that EU mechanisms cannot replace national accountability.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s demand to reclassify red mud as hazardous waste and transition to dry disposal technologies, aligning perfectly with their commitment to preventing industrial ecological disasters.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for harmonized mandatory financial guarantees, proposing an EU-wide industrial disaster fund to operationalize the polluter-pays principle and shield taxpayers from corporate liability evasion.  
GREEN_EFA urges expanding stress-test requirements to include cross-border risk assessments, particularly for non-EU neighboring sites like Bosnia’s Neretva basin, to prevent regional ecological cascades.  
GREEN_EFA endorses binding EU criteria for environmental inspections, emphasizing the need to finalize the Commission’s delayed guidelines on inspection frameworks to prevent weak enforcement.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity of retroactive liability clauses in environmental permits to ensure companies like MAL Zrt. cannot evade compensation, aligning with their manifesto pledge for corporate accountability.

ALDE absolutely upholds the issue’s emphasis on harmonized EU-level environmental inspections, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to supranational enforcement mechanisms that transcend inconsistent national implementation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the demand for urgency in finalizing the EU environmental inspection proposal, stressing that preexisting frameworks like the Seventh Environmental Action Programme already mandate such measures and require immediate operationalization.  
ALDE fully supports the critique of systemic implementation failures, framing them as critical enhancement opportunities to strengthen compliance with the “polluter-pays” principle and disaster prevention—a cornerstone of ALDE’s environmental policy agenda.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on solidarity and risk-sharing facilities, recognizing these as essential to advancing ALDE’s priority of EU-wide accountability in managing legacy pollution and industrial hazards.  
ALDE underscores the necessity of binding financial guarantees and stress tests for mining sites, reflecting ALDE’s 2023 manifesto pledge to institutionalize preemptive risk mitigation in industrial regulation.

SD firmly endorses the issue’s emphasis on harmonized mandatory financial guarantees, perfectly aligning with S&D’s unwavering commitment to enforcing the polluter-pays principle and creating EU-wide accountability frameworks for industrial disasters.  
SD firmly endorses the call for binding EU criteria on environmental inspections, reflecting S&D’s priority to strengthen national oversight bodies and eliminate systemic enforcement gaps exposed by the disaster.  
SD firmly endorses the demand for transparency in remediation processes, which directly advances S&D’s focus on preventing corruption and ensuring public funds serve affected communities rather than oligarchic interests.  
SD firmly endorses the urgency to reclassify red mud as hazardous waste, aligning perfectly with S&D’s environmental justice agenda to uphold EU directives and prevent future misclassification tragedies.  
SD firmly endorses the push for an EU risk-sharing facility, resonating with S&D’s vision of solidarity-based solutions to address legacy pollution while safeguarding vulnerable regions.

ECR slightly accepts the issue’s pollution prevention goals but requests revisions to mandate immediate remediation of legacy contamination sites like Greece’s Asopos River, where heavy metals persist despite EU waste directives.  
ECR highlights that the issue’s narrow focus on industrial waste misclassification fails to address widespread agricultural and urban wastewater pollution in rivers like the Axios and Aliakmonas, contradicting ECR’s demand for holistic pollution accountability.  
ECR argues the proposed EU binding inspection criteria overlook systemic national enforcement failures, exemplified by Greece’s prolonged negligence in curbing hexavalent chromium discharges into the Asopos.  
ECR questions the efficacy of harmonized financial guarantees without criminal liability mechanisms for governments enabling delays, as seen in unresolved Greek river contamination spanning multiple administrations.  
ECR urges amendments to enforce real-time pollution monitoring and public data access under the polluter-pays principle, aligning with local Greek communities’ demands for transparency in remediation efforts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2010 Hungarian red mud disaster, which released nearly one million cubic meters of hazardous waste, killed ten people, injured 150, and polluted vast areas, including four NATURA 2000 sites. It highlighted systemic failures in implementing EU environmental laws, including misclassification of red mud as non-hazardous under Directive 91/689/EEC and deficiencies in enforcing the Mining Waste Directive. The resolution urged Member States to reclassify red mud as hazardous waste, revise permits accordingly, and report to the Commission by end-2016, while demanding a shift to dry disposal technologies by 2016 to prevent pollution. It criticized persistent gaps in EU legislation, inconsistent enforcement of the Environmental Liability Directive, and delays in the Commission’s 2014 report on financial security mechanisms. The Parliament called for harmonized mandatory financial guarantees, stress tests for mining sites, stronger national inspection bodies, and EU-wide binding criteria for environmental inspections. It emphasized disaster prevention, transparency in remediation, and an EU risk-sharing facility to address legacy pollution, stressing solidarity and the polluter-pays principle. The Commission was urged to submit overdue reports, propose access-to-justice rules, and ensure compliance with international conventions on hazardous waste management.

title: Limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air from medium combustion plants
background: Prior EU air quality policies addressed emissions from small (<1MW) and large (>50MW) combustion plants, leaving medium installations (1-50MW) unregulated, contributing to persistent air pollution health impacts (400,000 annual premature deaths) and environmental damage. The Parliament will discuss establishing emission limits for medium combustion plants to address this regulatory gap.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the issue's balanced approach to reducing air pollution while maintaining economic feasibility, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to sustainable growth and public health protection.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the establishment of emission limits for 150,000 medium combustion plants, recognizing this as a critical step to fill regulatory gaps and address cross-border pollution challenges.  
EPP totally agrees the mandatory review clause for 2020, viewing it as an opportunity to enhance energy efficiency standards in harmony with technological advancements and COP21 climate goals.  
EPP strongly supports the flexibility granted to SMEs and district heating systems, which effectively advances EPP's priority of minimizing administrative burdens while achieving environmental targets.  
EPP applauds the issue’s provision for stricter emission limits in non-compliant air quality zones, reinforcing EPP’s longstanding focus on localized environmental solutions and citizen health safeguards.

EFDD rejects the directive's failure to regulate mercury and dioxins, fundamentally challengeing with their demand for stringent public health protections.  
EFDD opposes the exemption of offshore oil platforms and biomass plants from emission limits, overlooking critical accountability for industrial pollution sources.  
EFDD rejects EU-mandated registration schemes for combustion plants as bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with their opposition to centralized regulatory control.  
EFDD criticizes weakened emission standards in the amended proposal as contradictory to ecological innovation, arguing it prioritizes energy conglomerates over environmental modernization.  
EFDD opposes the directive's EU-level framework entirely, asserting national governments must retain sovereignty over industrial regulation to prevent economic harm.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's elimination of Council-proposed loopholes, aligning perfectly with their commitment to rigorous source-level pollution control.  
GREEN_EFA approves the strengthened application of the polluter-pays principle, ensuring industries internalize health costs rather than burdening public systems.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending transitional provisions to include EU funding mechanisms for biomass plants in renewable transition regions, ensuring compliance without stifling green energy growth.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on binding emission limits for particulate matter as critical for advancing public health priorities under the Clean Air Agenda.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s role in addressing 20% of NEC Directive emissions, urging parallel action on other pollution sources to meet air quality targets.

ALDE absolutely agrees the issue’s harmonized emission limits for medium combustion plants, perfectly aligning with their commitment to science-based environmental protection and cross-border air quality improvement.  
ALDE applauds the strict closure of non-emergency operational loopholes, which decisively addresses previous regulatory gaps while maintaining energy security provisions.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s tailored provisions for biomass installations as essential for advancing renewable energy adoption without compromising emission reduction targets.  
ALDE commends the elimination of redundant bureaucratic processes, which strengthens compliance efficiency while preserving robust environmental safeguards.  
ALDE recognizes the issue’s emphasis on intergovernmental knowledge-sharing as instrumental in elevating emission standards uniformly across all Member States.

SD fundamentally advocates the issue's closure of the regulatory gap for 142,000 medium combustion plants, ensuring comprehensive emission controls across critical sectors like energy production and industrial processes.  
SD perfectly aligns with the mandatory carbon monoxide monitoring provisions, which strengthen data transparency and lay the groundwork for future legislative action on air quality.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with COP21 climate objectives, reinforcing Europe’s leadership in reducing greenhouse gases while addressing 348,000 annual premature deaths linked to air pollution.  
SD fully supports the balanced emission limits and phased timelines for biomass-based district heating systems, recognizing their role in sustainable energy transitions without compromising air quality goals.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s harmonized approach to registration and monitoring, which reduces administrative burdens while maintaining stringent environmental safeguards for high-risk zones.

GUE/NGL fundamentally sanctions the directive’s universal application to all European territories, including outermost regions, perfectly aligning with their commitment to equitable environmental protections across geographical boundaries.  
GUE/NGL perfectly aligns with the issue’s preventive framework against corporate exploitation, emphasizing strict enforcement to avert scandals like Volkswagen through robust compliance mechanisms.  
GUE/NGL highlights the critical need for future EU-wide coordination on local heating systems, ensuring regional disparities like Moravskoslezský’s coal pollution are addressed without compromising the directive’s immediate emission reduction goals.  
GUE/NGL strongly agrees closing regulatory gaps for medium combustion plants, advancing public health priorities as evidenced by Ireland’s preventable air-quality-related deaths and costs.  
GUE/NGL applauds the directive’s alignment with climate justice imperatives ahead of the Paris Summit, rejecting corporate-driven delays in transitioning from fossil fuels.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning environmental policy, adopting its first reading stance under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized alignment with the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0919) and incorporated opinions from the Economic and Social Committee (July 2014) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2014). The resolution instructed the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring legislative continuity. It mandated the Parliament’s President to formally transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under Rule 59 of its Rules of Procedure while prioritizing environmental objectives as outlined by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.

title: Quality of water intended for human consumption: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the quality of water intended for human consumption (recast)
background: The 1998 Drinking Water Directive required revision to address scientific advancements, emerging contaminants, and universal access demands, following the 2013 Right2Water citizens' initiative. The European Commission proposed updates aligning water quality standards with WHO guidelines and Sustainable Development Goal 6. The Parliament will discuss modernizing EU drinking water regulations.

stances.stance:
EPP supports enhancing water quality standards while advising against EU-wide mandates for free water access, emphasizing subsidiarity in municipal implementation.  
EPP endorses updating technical monitoring parameters but cautions against redundant sampling frequencies to prevent disproportionate cost increases for local suppliers.  
EPP proposes amending Article 6 to adjust boron thresholds to 2.4 mg/L in volcanic regions, aligning with WHO guidelines while maintaining health safeguards.  
EPP advises balancing contamination controls with affordability, rejecting amendments that would double compliance costs for small-scale water providers.  
EPP emphasizes partnership with municipalities to expand access sustainably, prioritizing leak reduction and infrastructure modernization under circular economy principles.

EFDD totally challenges the proposal's failure to mandate universal access to water as a public good  
EFDD rejects the diluted regulatory approach to PFAS contaminants despite Veneto's 85,000 exposed citizens  
The issue conflicts with EFDD's principles by not codifying Right2Water initiative demands into binding law  
EFDD condemns the lack of enforceable mechanisms to prevent corporate pollution of critical aquifers  
This proposal overlooks EFDD's core demand for water service remunicipalization across EU member states

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to comprehensively regulate all PFAS compounds, entirely challengeing with their demand for strict chemical safety standards protecting against persistent toxins.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the weak phrasing on water access rights, overlooking critical aspects like legally binding guarantees for universal clean water provision in public spaces.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the omission of explicit safeguards for vital water sources like Lake Vättern, inconsistent with their principle of prioritizing ecological security over military activities.  
GREEN_EFA entirely challenges with the issue's inadequate monitoring framework, which fails to mandate EU-wide testing for microplastics and endocrine disruptors as demanded by citizens’ initiatives.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the lack of binding investment commitments for water treatment infrastructure, disregarding urgent needs to filter pharmaceuticals and emerging pollutants.

ALDE strongly endorses the harmonization of water quality standards to protect public health across the EU, aligning perfectly with their commitment to safeguarding environmental and citizen well-being under Article 192(1) TFEU.  
ALDE applauds the expansion of consumer information requirements, which effectively advance transparency and reinforce trust in Europe’s high-quality tap water, a longstanding priority for the party.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of preserving member states’ flexibility in water provision, ensuring proven organizational models like municipal systems are not disrupted by impractical regulatory demands.  
ALDE proposes retaining Annex II Part B’s proportional measurement frequency system to avoid undue cost increases for smaller providers while maintaining health protections, enhancing the directive’s proportionality.  
ALDE suggests limiting Annex IV’s additional obligations to water quality data only, excluding unrelated metrics like energy efficiency, to focus on core health objectives without overburdening suppliers.

ECR absolutely disapproves with the proposal’s harmonized water quality standards, undermining subsidiarity and member states’ autonomy in public health regulation.  
ECR rejects the directive’s centralized approach to data transparency, failing to address national frameworks for water management.  
ECR opposes the lack of explicit funding mechanisms to support affordability, overlooking critical socioeconomic disparities in water access.  
ECR argues the proposal imposes disproportionate EU-level requirements, inconsistent with ECR’s emphasis on localized risk assessment and decision-making.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to enshrine water access as a human right in EU law, firmly conflicting with their mandate from the Right2Water petition signed by two million citizens.  
GUE_NGL opposes the directive's tolerance of PFAS chemicals, demanding zero thresholds to prevent water from becoming "a source of death" as seen in Veneto's contamination cases.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal's silence on privatization risks, which undermines universal affordability and contradicts their anti-commodification stance on water infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL challenges the issue's lack of binding mechanisms to fund public water systems, overlooking critical needs for infrastructure renewal and endocrine disruptor regulation.  
GUE_NGL denounces the weakened Article 13 provisions as inconsistent with precautionary principles, prioritizing corporate profits over health protections demanded by affected communities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the proposed Directive on the quality of water intended for human consumption (COM(2017)0753), emphasizing the need to ensure safe drinking water across the EU by updating existing standards. The resolution highlighted that the Commission’s proposal primarily codified prior legislation without substantive changes, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of legal services. It noted concerns from the Czech, Irish, Austrian, and UK parliaments regarding non-compliance with subsidiarity principles, though these did not alter the legislative process. The Parliament endorsed the proposal’s alignment with environmental and public health objectives under Article 192(1) TFEU, urging the Commission to maintain transparency by re-engaging Parliament if future amendments significantly alter the proposal. The resolution also stressed forwarding the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting procedural adherence while focusing on harmonizing water quality standards to protect citizens’ health.

title: Reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment
background: In May 2018, the European Commission proposed addressing marine plastic pollution, with single-use items constituting 70% of EU beach litter. Annual EU plastic waste reached 26 million tonnes, 150,000 tonnes entering seas. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to reduce single-use plastic environmental impact and promote sustainable alternatives.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially advocates the directive’s waste reduction intent but requests amendments to Annex II to explicitly recognize oxo-biodegradable plastics as compliant alternatives, citing UK Environment Agency lifecycle assessments.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in Article 4’s material criteria, urging inclusion of recyclability metrics to address non-recyclable bio-plastics like Novamont’s product.  
EFDD demands revisions to Article 7 to mandate pre-legislative publication of EU technical studies, preventing rushed adoption skewed toward specific national industries.  
EFDD questions the proposal’s environmental rigor, noting failure to impose binding plastic bottle reduction targets despite evidence of 400-year degradation cycles.  
EFDD urges Article 3 modifications to require CO2 emission thresholds in production processes, aligning with UK Intertek findings on energy-efficient oxo-biodegradables.

ENF supports the directive’s emphasis on reducing single-use plastics but advises amending Article 4 to prioritize stricter phase-out timelines for non-recyclable plastics where viable alternatives exist, aligning with Lechevalier’s call for substitution mandates.  
ENF highlights concerns that the issue’s focus on EU measures should be complemented by binding international agreements targeting Asia and Africa’s plastic waste, as Lancini noted, to address 95% of marine pollution sources.  
ENF proposes modifying Annex III to include transitional financial support for SMEs in the plastics sector, ensuring proportionality in compliance costs as raised by Kappel, while maintaining environmental goals.  
ENF advises strengthening Recital 12 to explicitly reference endocrine disruptors in microplastics, mandating health impact assessments for all permitted plastic products, reflecting Lechevalier’s health-centric arguments.  
ENF requests clarity in Article 8 on extended producer responsibility schemes to avoid disproportionate burdens on small manufacturers, echoing Kappel’s call for balanced implementation.

GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the issue's preventive approach to plastic pollution, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that systemic waste reduction must precede substitution strategies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the ban on non-degradable alternatives like bioplastics, emphasizing that marine ecosystems require solutions beyond mere material swaps.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes binding producer responsibility clauses, recognizing their effectiveness in holding industries accountable for plastic lifecycle management without exemptions.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s science-based urgency, particularly its recognition of microplastic infiltration into food chains and everyday consumer products.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the rejection of deregulatory pressures, applauding the issue’s refusal to prioritize industrial convenience over ecological preservation.

SD entirely supports the directive’s enhanced ambition in combatting single-use plastics, as this aligns perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to ocean conservation and circular economy principles.  
SD perfectly aligns with the urgency to address Mediterranean microplastic pollution highlighted in the issue, proposing strengthening international legal frameworks to prevent cross-border plastic leakage.  
SD fully supports the extended producer responsibility model, urging its rigorous enforcement to ensure polluters bear costs while fostering innovation in eco-sustainable production.  
SD recommends further differentiation between biodegradable and non-degradable plastics in the directive’s implementation to optimize environmental and economic sustainability outcomes.  
SD endorses systemic recycling incentives and job creation strategies, urging the Commission to incentivize multinational corporations to adopt eco-friendly substitutes without destabilizing EU industries.

ECR supports the issue's differentiated product approach but advises expanding Article 7 to mandate cross-border cooperation on Asian and African river plastic waste mitigation.  
ECR endorses phased implementation timelines while proposing amendments to Annex III to include agricultural plastic mulch contamination safeguards.  
ECR supports recycling targets for single-use bottles but recommends regional feasibility assessments for the 35% recycled content requirement.  
ECR proposes allocating Horizon Europe funds to scale marine plastic-to-fuel conversion technologies under Section 5.2 innovation criteria.  
ECR advises developing a comprehensive EU strategy for all disposable products by 2026, building on the current single-use plastics framework.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s ambition to combat plastic pollution, aligning perfectly with their commitment to transformative environmental action.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening the definition of single-use plastics in Article 3 to eliminate industry loopholes, ensuring no exemptions for biodegradable alternatives.  
GUE_NGL approves empowering Member States to adopt stricter measures than the directive’s baseline, urging enhancements to Article 5 to explicitly permit exceeding minimum standards.  
GUE_NGL applauds the prioritization of environmental protection over Single Market efficiency, reflecting their manifesto’s demand to center ecological imperatives.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of binding reduction targets for all single-use plastics, urging accelerated timelines in Annex II to match public demand for decisive action.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 environmental policy proposal (COM(2018)0340), grounded in Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which aims to advance EU environmental objectives. The resolution reflects input from multiple parliamentary committees, including Environment, Economic Affairs, Industry, Agriculture, and Fisheries, and incorporates opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. It formally adopts Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially alters or replaces the original proposal. The resolution emphasizes procedural accountability by instructing the President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative processes and stakeholder consultations.

title: Implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation: REPORT on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation ((EC) No 1935/2004)
background: The EU’s 2004 Food Contact Materials Regulation established safety standards but only harmonized rules for 4 of 17 material categories, resulting in divergent national measures. Emerging scientific evidence on nanomaterials, cumulative exposure risks, and internal market challenges highlighted regulatory gaps. The Parliament will discuss regulatory implementation improvements and enhanced safety protocols for food-contact materials.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's call for harmonized EU measures on food contact materials, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to a functional internal market and high consumer protection standards.  
EPP approves the prioritization of EU-wide migration limits for Bisphenol A in plastics and coatings but proposes these be implemented through case-specific scientific assessments rather than horizontal bans to ensure proportionality.  
EPP emphasizes the urgent need for harmonized testing methods and traceability requirements, particularly for recycled materials, to advance circular economy goals while safeguarding against contaminants.  
EPP advocates enhancing EFSA's risk assessment protocols to include vulnerable groups and cumulative "cocktail effects," effectively advancing EPP's priority of science-based health protections.  
EPP recommends accelerating Commission action on paper and metal packaging regulations using existing national rules as a baseline, with one amendment to clarify industry compliance timelines in Article 4(2).

EFDD partially approves the harmonization push but requests revisions to Article 7 requiring EFSA to assess "cocktail effects" in all material evaluations.  
EFDD requests amendments to Annex III to mandate a complete ban on endocrine disruptors in FCMs, reflecting their demand for 100% exclusion of such substances.  
EFDD proposes modifying Section 5.2 to allow national supplementary safety measures for high-risk materials like metals, provided they do not fragment the internal market.  
EFDD objects to uniform migration limits in Article 12, arguing innovation-driven industry practices better ensure safety than rigid EU thresholds.  
EFDD opposes centralized enforcement in Chapter 9, advocating market-led transparency models over bureaucratic controls.

ENF strongly endorses the issue’s push to harmonize EU-wide safety standards for high-risk materials like paper and metals, aligning with ENF’s commitment to eliminating endocrine disruptors and protecting vulnerable populations.  
ENF proposes amending Annex II to expand the BPA ban to all bisphenol derivatives, enhancing alignment with France’s 2015 precedent and addressing emerging scientific evidence on structural analogs.  
ENF applauds the emphasis on stricter migration limits for cadmium and lead in ceramics, which directly advances ENF’s health-first agenda for maternal and infant safety.  
ENF urges accelerated collaboration between EFSA and ECHA to address cocktail effects, transforming current procedural gaps into a robust cross-agency risk assessment framework.  
ENF endorses mandatory nano-labeling provisions as a critical step toward consumer transparency, consistent with ENF’s 2023 manifesto pledge for chemical safety democratization.

SD strongly upholds the issue's prioritization of harmonized EU measures for high-risk materials like paper and metals, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to eliminating endocrine disruptors such as BPA from all food contact applications.  
SD approves the proposed reduction of BPA limits to 0.05 mg/kg and urges extending this standard to coatings and adhesives, enhancing protections for vulnerable groups as emphasized in the issue.  
SD endorses mandatory nano-material labeling and enhanced traceability requirements, proposing to strengthen documentation protocols for imported FCMs to ensure full compliance with EU safety thresholds.  
SD applauds the focus on "cocktail effects" in chemical risk assessments, advocating for accelerated EFSA-ECHA collaboration to develop cumulative exposure models that reflect real-world consumption patterns.  
SD highlights the need to augment funding for EFSA's 2024-2027 work program as a minor enhancement opportunity, ensuring sufficient resources for evaluating recycled material safety without delaying circular economy transitions.

ECR partly upholds the proposed BPA reduction limits but demands accelerated research funding for alternatives, noting the issue's timeline risks industry stagnation without replacement solutions.  
ECR requests revising Article 12 to mandate full chemical disclosure on packaging labels, arguing the current traceability framework fails to address consumer "right-to-know" principles.  
ECR insists the issue must create SME compliance subsidies for harmonized testing, highlighting fragmented enforcement disproportionately burdens small producers.  
ECR rejects the absence of binding thresholds for endocrine disruptors in recycled paper, urging amendments to Section 9 specifying contamination limits aligned with REACH SVHC criteria.  
ECR challenges the reliance on member-state oversight for imported FCMs, proposing EU-wide customs protocols with standardized detection methods for non-compliant substances.

GUE_NGL strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on reducing endocrine disruptors like BPA, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL’s longstanding commitment to prioritizing public health over industry interests.  
GUE_NGL applauds the push for mandatory nanomaterial labeling and harmonized migration limits, effectively advancing transparency goals outlined in their 2023 manifesto.  
GUE_NGL endorses the call for stricter enforcement via national registrations, which directly addresses systemic gaps in FCM compliance monitoring.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to accelerate timelines for banning mineral oils in inks, proposing an amendment to Annex II to include interim safety thresholds pending full prohibition.  
GUE_NGL urges expanding the scope of hazardous substance phase-outs to cover all SVHCs in recycled materials, ensuring circular economy goals do not compromise safety.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over gaps in EU legislation on food contact materials (FCMs), noting that only 4 of 17 materials listed in Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 (plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose, and active materials) have specific EU measures, leaving 13 materials—including paper, metals, inks, and adhesives—subject to fragmented national rules, undermining the internal market and public health. It urged the Commission to prioritize harmonized EU measures for high-risk materials like paper, metals, and coatings, emphasizing risks from endocrine disruptors, nanomaterials, and "cocktail effects" from combined chemical exposures. The resolution called for stricter migration limits, including reducing Bisphenol A (BPA) limits to 0.05 mg/kg in plastics and coatings, revising cadmium and lead limits in ceramics, and banning mineral oils in inks pending further research. It highlighted the need for improved risk assessments by EFSA and ECHA, incorporating vulnerable groups (infants, pregnant women), low-dose effects, and microbial risks, while advocating for mandatory labeling of nanomaterials and enhanced traceability. The Parliament stressed harmonized testing methods, better enforcement via national registrations, and alignment with REACH to phase out hazardous substances like SVHCs and CMRs. It linked FCM safety to circular economy goals, urging measures to ensure recycled materials (e.g., paper) meet safety standards without increasing contaminants. Additional demands included research into safer alternatives to BPA, coordination between biocides and FCM regulations, and ensuring imported FCMs comply with EU standards. The resolution underscored the need for funding boosts for EFSA, improved compliance documentation (Declarations of Compliance), and expanded controls to address non-compliance risks across member states.

title: Implementation of the cross-border Healthcare Directive: REPORT on the implementation of the Cross-Border Healthcare Directive
background: The 2011 Cross-Border Healthcare Directive aimed to clarify patient rights to access care abroad, but uneven national implementation, low citizen awareness, administrative barriers, reimbursement discrepancies, and data inconsistencies persisted. Challenges in coordinating digital health tools and rare disease networks further complicated cross-border care. The Parliament will discuss improving the directive’s application to address systemic gaps.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on enhancing National Contact Points, aligning with EPP’s commitment to patient-centered healthcare and proposing streamlined reimbursement procedures to eliminate administrative barriers.  
EPP approves expanding European Reference Networks for rare cancers, urging harmonized registries to match EPP’s 2023 manifesto priorities on equitable access to specialized care.  
EPP highlights the need to accelerate eHealth interoperability through eHDSI, converting criticism of low awareness into a call for EU-wide campaigns to boost directive visibility.  
EPP endorses stricter enforcement of correct directive implementation, framing delayed transposition as an opportunity for targeted audits and structural fund reallocations.  
EPP applauds the focus on telemedicine reimbursement, aligning with EPP’s digital single market goals while suggesting expedited GDPR-compliant data exchange frameworks.

ENF firmly conflicts with the issue's digital health infrastructure plans, viewing eHDSI as a pretext for intrusive EU-wide patient databases that erode national sovereignty over healthcare data management.  
ENF rejects the expansion of European Reference Networks (ERNs), arguing it centralizes medical authority and could force member states to accept supranational treatment protocols incompatible with national health priorities.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of immigration control, failing to prevent potential abuse of cross-border healthcare rights as a backdoor for uncontrolled migration under medical pretenses.  
ENF opposes the issue's emphasis on standardized registries and e-prescriptions, warning these mechanisms enable surveillance architectures masked as "interoperability," contradicting ENF's defense of medical autonomy.  
ENF rejects increased EU health funding allocations, asserting they prioritize bureaucratic integration over addressing national disparities in care access caused by EU free movement policies.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on strengthening National Contact Points, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable healthcare access across borders through enhanced patient information systems.  

GREEN_EFA approves the prioritization of European Reference Networks for rare diseases, which directly advances their manifesto goal of specialized care for vulnerable patient groups through EU-wide medical collaboration.  

GREEN_EFA proposes expanding NCP guidance materials to explicitly include outreach protocols for homeless and undocumented populations, ensuring inclusivity matches the issue’s universal healthcare principles.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on patient-centered care quality metrics, strongly resonating with their long-standing advocacy for dignity-driven health policy evaluations beyond purely economic criteria.  

GREEN_EFA highlights the need to pair data transparency measures with ethical oversight frameworks as an enhancement opportunity, ensuring abuse prevention aligns with GDPR without compromising care accessibility.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on enhancing National Contact Points, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to seamless cross-border healthcare access and administrative efficiency.  
ALDE applauds the prioritization of transparency in healthcare reimbursement and complaint mechanisms, which effectively advances ALDE’s priority of empowering patients through clear, actionable information.  
ALDE endorses the accelerated digital transformation via interoperable eHealth systems, urging Member States to expedite eHDSI integration while ensuring GDPR compliance as outlined.  
ALDE proposes harmonizing NCP platforms with standardized multilingual interfaces to address language barriers and disparities in resources, enhancing their visibility as a “one-stop shop” for patients.  
ALDE welcomes the call for annual reporting on cross-border reimbursements and patient flows, which aligns with their manifesto goals for data-driven accountability and reducing regional health inequalities.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s prioritization of harmonized National Contact Points, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to transparent patient rights enforcement and cross-border health equity. SD proposes explicitly including vaccination access within the directive’s scope to counter preventable disease resurgence as a targeted enhancement.  
SD applauds the emphasis on interoperable eHealth systems, which effectively advances SD’s digital sovereignty agenda while safeguarding GDPR compliance as a non-negotiable privacy standard.  
SD endorses the call to expand European Reference Networks for rare diseases, reflecting SD’s manifesto pledge to eliminate healthcare disparities through pan-European clinical collaboration.  
SD approves the issue’s demand for strengthened EHIC implementation and post-Brexit health protections, recognizing these as critical to preserving seamless patient mobility aligned with SD’s social solidarity principles.  
SD highlights the need to accelerate telemedicine reimbursement frameworks as an enhancement opportunity, urging binding timelines to operationalize digital health parity.

ECR supports the emphasis on National Contact Points but advises specifying funding safeguards to prevent budget strains in Central European member states.  
ECR endorses cross-border cooperation for rare diseases yet proposes expanding ERNs only if accompanied by EU mechanisms to offset treatment cost disparities.  
ECR cautions against centralizing vaccination policies in the directive, stressing this must remain under national competence per treaty obligations.  
ECR advises amending eHealth provisions to explicitly prohibit data-sharing beyond treatment reimbursement without patient consent, reinforcing GDPR alignment.  
ECR welcomes patient mobility principles but requests adding clauses requiring national audits to preemptively address regional healthcare capacity drains.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the uneven implementation of Directive 2011/24/EU on cross-border healthcare, noting that many Member States failed to fully transpose or enforce its provisions, leading to low patient mobility (only 20% of citizens aware of their rights) and persistent barriers such as administrative burdens, reimbursement delays, and restrictive prior authorization systems. It emphasized the need to enhance National Contact Points (NCPs) by improving their visibility, funding, and harmonization of information, particularly on reimbursement procedures, treatment costs, and complaint mechanisms, while addressing language barriers and disparities in NCP resources. The resolution highlighted the growing role of eHealth, urging Member States to accelerate digital transformation through interoperable systems like the EU-wide eHealth Digital Service Infrastructure (eHDSI) for cross-border data exchange, while ensuring GDPR compliance and safeguarding patient privacy. It called for stronger EU cooperation on rare diseases and rare cancers, advocating expanded European Reference Networks (ERNs), standardized registries, and improved access to diagnostics and treatments, alongside integrating ERNs into national health systems. The Parliament stressed the importance of addressing medicine shortages, price disparities, and mutual recognition of prescriptions, including e-prescriptions, and urged action to simplify reimbursement for telemedicine. It criticized proposed cuts to the EU health programme, demanding increased funding in the 2021-2027 MFF to tackle cross-border challenges, antimicrobial resistance, and chronic diseases, while leveraging structural funds to reduce regional health inequalities. The resolution also highlighted the need for clearer guidelines on the interaction between the directive and social security coordination, improved EHIC implementation, and post-Brexit health agreements to protect patient rights. Noting healthcare’s economic significance (10% of EU GDP, potentially rising to 12.6% by 2060), it urged Member States to eliminate discriminatory practices by insurers, ensure cost transparency for patients, and prioritize patient quality of life in policy evaluations. Finally, the Parliament welcomed the European Court of Auditors’ planned audit on the directive’s effectiveness and called for annual reporting on cross-border reimbursements and patient flows to enhance accountability and data comparability.

title: In vitro diagnostic medical devices: RECOMMENDATION FOR SECOND READING on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council onin vitrodiagnostic medical devices and repealing Directive 98/79/EC and Commission Decision 2010/227/EU
background: Outdated EU regulations on in vitro diagnostics, established in the 1990s, faced criticism following safety incidents involving medical devices, highlighting gaps in pre-market scrutiny and post-market surveillance. The EU, a global leader in medical device innovation with 25,000 companies, required updated standards. The Parliament will discuss modernizing diagnostic device regulations to strengthen safety protocols and market compliance.

stances.stance:
EFDD slightly endorses the issue's post-market surveillance requirements but requests amendment of Article 78 to establish binding EU-wide deadlines for endocrine disruptor identification criteria.  
EFDD supports centralized reference laboratories for high-risk devices yet demands revision of Annex IX to mandate immediate interim testing protocols for suspected endocrine-active substances.  
EFDD questions the harmonized authorization framework, advocating amendment of Recital 34 to explicitly recognize national authorities' primacy in clinical validity assessments.  
EFDD acknowledges improved device traceability but warns unresolved endocrine classification gaps fundamentally undermine Article 56's chemical safety enforcement mechanisms.  
EFDD requests inclusion of Article 14a requiring manufacturers to disclose all component chemicals pending final endocrine disruptor guidelines.

ENF strongly sanctions the issue’s harmonized safety standards, aligning perfectly with ENF’s commitment to preventing medical fraud through enhanced traceability mechanisms.  
ENF endorses the centralized certification framework while proposing amendments to Article 9 to establish sovereignty safeguards allowing national health authorities to retain supplementary oversight capacities.  
ENF applauds the patient-centric focus of the regulation, which effectively advances ENF’s priority of rigorous device quality control across EU markets.  
ENF approves the notified bodies’ expanded role but recommends extending implementation timelines by 18 months to ensure French SMEs can adapt without losing market share.  
ENF recognizes the issue’s potential to strengthen EU medical sovereignty and urges parallel measures to prioritize domestically certified devices in public procurement processes.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to implement centralized market authorization, creating fragmentation risks in device safety standards.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the inadequate safeguards for notified bodies, demanding mandatory unannounced inspections to prevent recurring scandals like Essure's toxic implants.  
The proposal completely condemns with GREEN_EFA's requirement for binding patient counseling protocols before high-stakes genetic testing procedures.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's dangerous omission of deadlines to eliminate all carcinogenic substances from IVDs, violating precautionary principles.  
This framework overlooks critical funding guarantees for the Eudamed transparency database, undermining its operational viability as warned in parliamentary communications.

ALDE completely disputes the issue's framework for in vitro diagnostics, citing inadequate safeguards against another implant scandal.   
ALDE rejects the risk classification system as insufficiently rigorous, failing to mandate EU-wide clinical evaluations for Class 3 devices.   
ALDE condemns the provisions allowing member states to permit device reprocessing, directly conflicting with patient safety priorities.   
ALDE disputes the issue's testing accessibility provisions as dangerously lowering quality standards for critical diagnostics.   
ALDE demands complete restructuring of implementation timelines, arguing current resource commitments guarantee regulatory failures.

SD rejects the issue's failure to mandate a centralized EU-wide approval system for high-risk devices, contradicting S&D's patient safety principles.  
SD opposes fundamentally the inadequate staffing provisions for regulatory bodies, which undermine the issue's enforcement capabilities.  
 Contradictory arguments detected: All S&D speakers explicitly endorsed the issue's adoption while raising implementation concerns.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to mandate producer insurance requirements, firmly againsting with their stance on consumer protection accountability.  
ECR opposes the inadequate provisions for genetic counseling oversight, inconsistent with ECR's emphasis on ethical medical governance.  
The proposal overlooks critical cost-control mechanisms, contradicting ECR's principle of preventing regulatory-induced price inflation.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the centralized notification body system, which erodes national competence in device certification.  
 Debate arguments superficially endorse the text but reveal unresolved policy gaps aligning with ECR's opposition rationale.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Council’s first-reading position on the legislative act, endorsing its adoption in line with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It acknowledged accompanying Commission statements and confirmed the act’s finalization under the agreed procedures. The resolution mandated the Parliament’s President and Secretary-General to formally sign the act, verify procedural compliance, and arrange for its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union, ensuring legal effect. Additionally, the Parliament instructed its President to communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, concluding the legislative process without substantive amendments to the Council’s text.

title: Inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use change and forestry into the 2030 climate and energy framework: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use change and forestry into the 2030 climate and energy framework and amending Regulation No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council on a mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and other information relevant to climate change
background: The European Union's commitment to the Paris Agreement and its 2030 climate target of 40% domestic emissions reduction, alongside the US withdrawal from the accord, highlighted the need to address land use, forestry, and agriculture's role in carbon sequestration. The Parliament will discuss integrating LULUCF sector emissions and removals into EU climate policy frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP completely supports the science-based forest reference levels as perfectly aligning with their commitment to measurable climate action through sustainable forestry management.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's integration of Copernicus program data, enhancing transparent monitoring of carbon sinks while maintaining EU competitiveness.  
EPP emphasizes strict adherence to real carbon accounting standards to prevent creative bookkeeping, consistent with their climate leadership principles under the Paris Agreement.  
EPP strongly accepts geographic flexibility in forest management targets, ensuring member states like Croatia can address historical land-use constraints while meeting EU-wide climate goals.  
EPP applauds the rejection of rigid harvesting intensity caps, safeguarding member states’ proven sustainable forestry models that balance biomass growth with economic utilization.

EFDD rejects the issue's inadequate climate ambition as absolutely disputeing with EFDD's demand for urgent emissions reductions aligned with scientific urgency  
EFDD opposes the accounting flexibilities for Member States as enabling continued environmental degradation inconsistent with climate emergency declarations  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of forest carbon sequestration by permitting unsustainable harvesting practices under "sustainable management" loopholes  
EFDD condemns the limited binding targets as failing to address land-use emissions' cumulative impact on biodiversity collapse and food system destabilization

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's failure to prevent increased logging through flawed carbon accounting, absolutely disapproveing with their demand for binding forest protection aligned with Paris targets.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the reliance on technical accounting loopholes that permit unsustainable forestry practices, overlooking critical aspects like biodiversity loss and carbon sink degradation.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's allowance of intensive land use and non-sustainable bioenergy expansion, inconsistent with their principles of circular economy and long-life wood product prioritization.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely disapproves with the proposal's use of LULUCF as an offset mechanism for other sectors' emissions, which undermines genuine decarbonization efforts in transport and energy.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's inadequate forest reference levels and historical baseline errors, failing to address the urgency of enhancing carbon sinks as required by climate science.

ALDE firmly approves the issue’s science-based forest reference levels, perfectly aligning with their commitment to data-driven environmental governance and sustainable forestry innovation as emphasized by Fredrick Federley’s focus on modern technical standards.  

ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s utilization of Copernicus for land-use monitoring, recognizing this as critical for achieving geographically balanced and transparent climate action across all Member States.  

ALDE fully supports the LULUCF accounting framework’s integrity, reinforcing Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy’s emphasis on precise emissions budgeting to safeguard the EU’s climate targets without restricting national forestry sovereignty.  

ALDE endorses the issue’s prioritization of sustainable forest management, resonating with Anneli Jäätteenmäki’s assertion that responsible forestry practices inherently advance both biodiversity protection and climate mitigation goals.  

ALDE highlights the issue’s compatibility with bioeconomy development through long-life wood product utilization, aligning with Nils Torvalds’ advocacy for leveraging forest resources to create low-emission energy solutions.

SD absolutely upholds the issue's mandate for science-based forest reference levels, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to data-driven climate governance.  
SD applauds the integration of Copernicus monitoring systems as a critical advancement in transparent EU-wide emissions accounting for land use sectors.  
SD emphasizes that maintaining documented historical reference levels rather than speculative future models ensures accountability, directly supporting ENVI Committee safeguards against hidden emissions.  
SD proposes strengthening geographic equity provisions to address scientific concerns about variable Member State reference levels while maintaining aggregate EU climate targets.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's balance between sustainable forestry incentives and binding carbon removal targets, ensuring both economic viability and Paris Agreement compliance.

GUE/NGL conditionally upholds the monitoring mechanisms in Articles 4-6 but requests revisions to Article 9 mandating binding agroecology transition targets for agricultural systems.  
GUE/NGL entirely condemns with the issue's flexibility provisions allowing intensified logging under "sustainable management" clauses, demanding amendment to exclude industrial biomass incentives.  
GUE/NGL requests adding explicit prohibitions in Annex II against nitrogen-based fertilizers and industrial livestock farming - critical emission sources overlooked in current forestry-focused metrics.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's failure to address fossil fuel phase-out timelines, requiring integration of Just Transition mechanisms for rural energy systems in recital 18.  
GUE/NGL opposes the afforestation prioritization in Section 3.2 without food sovereignty safeguards, proposing amended biodiversity impact assessments for all land-use changes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key measures in its resolution, adopting a position on the Commission’s 2016 proposal to strengthen forestry management and climate action under the LULUCF framework. The resolution emphasized increased funding for research and development in forestry, prioritizing geographic diversity, and leveraging EU space programs like Copernicus for monitoring land use and forestry activities. It highlighted the need to integrate food security, biodiversity protection, compliance with international agreements and EU law, and the impacts of forestry practices on Member States’ accounting systems. The resolution also addressed flexibilities in implementation, sustainable management of long-life wood and non-wood forest products, and the establishment of science-based forest reference levels. Additionally, it urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to ensure alignment with climate goals.

title: Motions for resolutions - A global ban on animal testing for cosmetics: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on a global ban to end animal testing for cosmetics
background: The EU’s 2004-2013 bans on cosmetic animal testing and trade, alongside varying international regulations, prompted advocacy for harmonized global standards. The Parliament will discuss advancing a worldwide prohibition on animal testing for cosmetics through multilateral frameworks and trade policies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the global ban initiative, aligning perfectly with its commitment to ethical innovation and animal welfare leadership.  
EPP applauds the EU's model as a benchmark for diplomatic efforts, particularly urging enhanced engagement with China to phase out mandatory animal testing requirements through technical cooperation.  
EPP emphasizes strict enforcement of trade exclusions against non-compliant imports, reinforcing the CJEU precedent to maintain regulatory integrity.  
EPP proposes broadening future issues to address additional animal welfare priorities like fur farming, while maintaining full endorsement of the cosmetics testing ban's urgency.  
EPP highlights the issue's economic validation, noting the EU cosmetics sector's growth as proof that ethical standards drive rather than hinder industrial competitiveness.

EFDD partially endorses the global ban proposal but demands amendments to eliminate REACH regulation loopholes permitting ingredient retesting for non-cosmetic purposes.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in enforcement by citing unresolved cases of companies authorizing animal testing in third countries to access Asian markets.  
EFDD urges stricter exclusion clauses in trade deals to bar all cosmetics tested abroad, emphasizing the 2016 CJEU ruling’s limitations against commercial pressures.  
EFDD requests broadening the issue’s scope to ban animal testing in pharmaceuticals and detergents, where overlapping ingredient regulations perpetuate cruelty.  
EFDD emphasizes that the proposal overlooks cross-sectoral regulatory harmonization, risking persistent animal testing under chemical safety frameworks like REACH.

ENF strongly promotes the global ban on cosmetic animal testing as a critical step toward aligning international practices with the EU’s ethical standards, reflecting their unwavering commitment to animal welfare as a hallmark of societal progress.  
ENF proposes amending the REACH regulation to explicitly prohibit cosmetic-related animal testing under any pretext, closing loopholes that undermine the 2009 ban and ensuring scientific advancements in human-cell-based alternatives are prioritized.  
ENF applauds the issue’s demand to exclude animal-tested cosmetics from trade agreements, particularly to counter non-compliant imports like those mandated by China’s regulatory requirements, reinforcing the EU’s leadership in ethical trade.  
ENF underscores the urgency of accelerating funding for alternative toxicological testing methods, emphasizing collaboration through ICATM and EPAA to fast-track validation and global knowledge-sharing.  
ENF demands stringent enforcement of the 2013 marketing ban, including unannounced audits and WTO-compliant safeguards, to prevent circumvention of EU ethical principles.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue’s demand for a global ban on cosmetic animal testing by 2023, perfectly aligning with their ethical mandate to eliminate exploitative practices against animals.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on accelerating non-animal testing innovations, recognizing this as critical to advancing both scientific progress and interspecies justice.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call to exclude animal-tested cosmetics from trade agreements, a measure that upholds their principle of extraterritorial accountability in supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses leveraging UN frameworks to universalize the ban, reflecting their strategic focus on institutionalizing animal welfare in global governance.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of closing import loopholes through strict audits, ensuring the EU’s ethical standards remain uncompromised in cross-border commerce.

ECR strongly approves the issue’s call for a global ban on cosmetic animal testing, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to advancing ethical standards and animal welfare in international trade.  
ECR applauds the emphasis on leveraging the EU’s pioneering 2013 marketing ban as a model, urging intensified diplomatic efforts through UN frameworks to accelerate worldwide adoption of cruelty-free practices.  
ECR proposes enhancing enforcement mechanisms by mandating stricter compliance audits for imported cosmetics and prioritizing exclusion clauses in trade agreements to close third-country loopholes.  
ECR endorses increased funding for alternative testing methods, stressing the need for accelerated validation of non-animal approaches through platforms like ICATM to eliminate regulatory dependencies on animal data.  
ECR highlights the critical role of public awareness campaigns to amplify global consumer demand for cruelty-free products, aligning with the issue’s recognition of 89% EU citizen support for stronger animal welfare measures.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s call for a global ban on cosmetic animal testing, aligning perfectly with their unwavering commitment to ending systemic animal exploitation and advancing ethical scientific practices.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on leveraging UN frameworks and bilateral agreements to universalize the EU’s 2013 marketing ban, reflecting their vision of global solidarity against cruelty.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening enforcement by amending EU chemical regulations like REACH to explicitly prohibit loopholes that permit animal testing for cosmetics under other legislative pretexts.  
GUE_NGL highlights the urgency of redirecting agricultural subsidies toward funding non-animal testing innovations, ensuring scientific progress aligns with ethical imperatives.  
GUE_NGL underscores the moral necessity of this ban, echoing public demands to prioritize citizen welfare over corporate interests, as articulated in their manifesto against commodification of life.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about animal testing in cosmetics, emphasizing the EU’s 2004 testing ban and 2013 marketing ban, which prohibit animal testing for cosmetics and the sale of products tested on animals, even where alternatives are incomplete. It highlighted the thriving EU cosmetics sector (providing two million jobs) and stressed that the bans have not hindered industry growth, while noting loopholes allowing non-compliant imports. The resolution called for a global ban by 2023, using the EU Cosmetics Regulation as a model, and urged diplomatic efforts to promote this through UN frameworks, bilateral agreements, and multilateral forums. It cited public support, with 89% of EU citizens advocating stronger international animal welfare measures, and noted 80% of countries still permit cosmetic animal testing. The Parliament urged increased funding for alternative testing methods, particularly for complex toxicological endpoints, and emphasized international collaboration (e.g., via the EPAA, ICCR, and ICATM) to accelerate validation and knowledge transfer. It demanded strict enforcement of EU bans, including audits for compliance, exclusion of animal-tested cosmetics from trade deals, and safeguards against WTO rule conflicts. Academic institutions and regulators were urged to prioritize training on alternatives, while the CJEU’s 2016 ruling was referenced to reinforce bans on products tested abroad. The resolution also highlighted legislative progress in countries like Israel and Norway but stressed the need for broader global adoption to align with EU standards.

title: Motions for resolutions - Trans fats: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on trans fats (TFAs)
background: Existing EU food labeling regulations, varying national TFA limits, and scientific evidence linking industrial trans fats to cardiovascular risks prompted the Commission's 2015 report on TFA consumption patterns and policy options. The Parliament will discuss regulatory approaches to reduce industrial trans fatty acids in foods across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the binding 2g/100g TFA limit, aligning with successful national models like Hungary and Denmark that reduced cardiovascular mortality.  
EPP emphasizes harmonizing EU-wide legislation to eliminate market fragmentation while preserving natural TFAs in dairy/meat as distinct from industrial variants.  
EPP proposes amending issue clauses D and E to explicitly differentiate between harmful industrial TFAs and naturally occurring ones with proven health-neutral or beneficial profiles.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on nutritional literacy campaigns and SME impact assessments, advancing their commitment to equitable public health without stifling agri-food innovation.  
EPP endorses replacing industrial TFAs with healthier alternatives, noting this aligns with their 2023 manifesto priority of preventive healthcare through science-based food policies.

EFDD conditionally promotes the binding TFA limits but requests revising Annex II to explicitly prohibit palm oil as a replacement, citing deforestation risks and conflicting health impacts.  
EFDD highlights that recommending palm oil substitution entirely challenges with EFDD's environmental sustainability principles outlined in their 2023 agricultural policy.  
EFDD supports harmonized EU measures but demands the impact assessment evaluate regional disparities in SME adaptation costs to prevent market inequities.  
EFDD emphasizes alignment with the issue’s child obesity data, urging amendments to allocate specific EU funds for school meal programs eliminating processed foods.  
EFDD insists on amending Article 5 to mandate standardized front-of-pack TFA warning labels, rejecting the issue’s reliance on industry self-reporting as insufficient.

ENF supports the issue's recognition of trans fat health risks and urgency for vulnerable populations, aligning with public health priorities.  
ENF advises amending the proposed binding limits to allow national adaptations respecting dietary traditions, ensuring EU-wide measures do not homogenize gastronomic diversity.  
ENF proposes explicitly distinguishing industrial TFAs from natural dairy-derived TFAs in regulatory wording to safeguard struggling agricultural sectors.  
ENF recommends supplementing mandatory limits with tax incentives for SMEs adopting healthier alternatives, mitigating economic strain during economic stagnation.  
ENF cautions against overreliance on punitive measures, urging emphasis on corporate social responsibility initiatives to achieve compliance without excessive administrative burdens.

SD totally supports binding EU-wide 2g/100g TFA limits, perfectly aligning with Denmark’s proven model that reduced cardiovascular deaths without harming businesses.  
SD perfectly aligns with rejecting voluntary industry actions, demanding legal harmonization to eliminate health disparities between member states.  
SD fully supports replacing TFAs with healthier alternatives as mandated, emphasizing this prevents 660,000 annual EU deaths linked to industrial trans fats.  
SD endorses issue’s socioeconomic equity focus, noting TFA exposure disproportionately affects low-income groups reliant on cheap processed foods.  
SD perfectly aligns with urgent Commission action timelines, requiring immediate legislative proposals to meet WHO’s <1% daily energy intake threshold.

ECR supports the binding 2g/100g TFA limit, endorsing Denmark’s model which reduced cardiovascular mortality without disrupting food sector viability.  
ECR advises amending Article 2 to explicitly exclude naturally occurring trans fats in dairy and meat, preventing overreach while maintaining public health goals.  
ECR recommends revising Section 5 to mandate compatibility assessments with existing voluntary industry agreements on fat reduction, ensuring policy coherence.  
ECR emphasizes the need for the Commission’s impact assessment to include SME-specific subsidies, proposing Annex II detail regional funding mechanisms for small bakeries and producers.  
ECR highlights the issue’s equity focus, urging Member States to allocate cohesion funds for targeted nutritional literacy programs in disadvantaged communities.

GUE/NGL completely promotes the binding 2g/100g TFA limit as imperative public health policy, perfectly aligning with their mandate to eliminate corporate-driven dietary inequalities.  
GUE/NGL perfectly aligns with the issue’s socioeconomic analysis, emphasizing that mandatory limits—not consumer education—are essential to protect low-income households from industry exploitation through cheap processed foods.  
GUE/NGL demands immediate Commission action on Denmark-style caps, rejecting voluntary measures as incompatible with their anti-corporate health justice principles.  
GUE/NGL underscores the urgency of replacing TFAs with equitable access to unprocessed foods, aligning the issue’s impact assessment requirement with their systemic critique of profit-driven food systems.  
 João Ferreira’s contextual emphasis on economic barriers reinforces rather than modifies the issue’s equity focus, maintaining perfect alignment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the health risks of industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFAs), linked to cardiovascular disease (660,000 annual EU deaths, 14% of mortality), obesity, diabetes, and cancers. Noting that TFAs are prevalent in processed foods like baked goods, snacks, and fried items (up to 40-50g per 100g of fat in some products), the resolution highlighted inadequate EU-wide regulation and labeling, with only Denmark, Austria, Latvia, and Hungary imposing legal limits (e.g., Denmark’s 2g TFAs per 100g fat, reducing cardiovascular deaths). It criticized socioeconomic disparities, as lower-income groups face higher exposure through cheaper foods. Citing WHO recommendations (TFA intake <1% of daily energy) and EFSA’s call for minimal intake, Parliament urged the EU Commission to propose a binding 2g/100g TFA limit across all foods within two years, accompanied by an impact assessment evaluating costs for SMEs and consumers. It emphasized replacing TFAs with healthier alternatives, improving public nutritional literacy, and harmonizing EU measures to ensure equitable health benefits, rejecting reliance on voluntary industry actions or labeling alone due to inefficacy and consumer confusion.

title: Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1293/2013
background: The EU's LIFE Programme, established in 1992 to fund environmental and climate initiatives, faced renewal for 2021-2027 amid heightened global climate commitments under the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Development Goals. The Parliament will discuss a proposed regulation to establish an updated programme, addressing funding priorities and alignment with EU climate neutrality objectives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's prioritization of biodiversity protection in outermost regions, aligning with their commitment to preserving Europe's unique ecosystems through enhanced LIFE funding.  
EPP proposes strengthening agricultural sustainability provisions by explicitly including support for low-emission farming practices in Natura 2000 areas as a targeted enhancement to circular economy objectives.  
EPP applauds the focus on administrative simplification, which directly advances their priority of making environmental funds more accessible to regional stakeholders and farmers.  
EPP endorses the call for compensatory mechanisms for agricultural producers in protected areas, urging an amendment to Article 9 to specify loss-calculation methodologies.  
EPP emphasizes the need for dedicated funding streams for human-wildlife coexistence programs, framing large carnivore management as critical to maintaining balanced ecosystems.

EFDD conditionally endorses the LIFE Programme's structure but demands deletion of all farmer-focused climate provisions, asserting they contradict scientific realities of cosmic and solar drivers.  
EFDD entirely challenges allocating funds to methane reduction, requiring amendment of Annex II to reflect water vapor's primary greenhouse role.  
EFDD rejects the biodiversity prioritization for overseas territories, insisting 50% of BEST scheme funds be redirected to antimicrobial resistance research under Article 7(2).  
EFDD proposes replacing circular economy targets with mandatory grants for antibiotic-free poultry breeding programs in Section 4(c).
