EFDD challenges third-country participation rules, demanding exclusion unless amended to fund joint biosecurity infrastructure projects over climate partnerships.

ENF partially supports the LIFE Programme's biodiversity objectives but demands Article 7 revisions prohibiting corporate subsidy access for energy transition costs  
ENF requests strict amendment to Section 4.2 requiring 65% of BEST scheme funds directly allocated to local community-led conservation projects  
ENF firmly challenges current cohesion policy alignment mechanisms, citing unresolved contradictions with citizens' economic welfare priorities  
ENF requires insertion of Clause 29a mandating national audits proving LIFE funds reduce household energy bills before approving budget increases  
ENF challenges third-country participation rules (Annex III) until binding provisions prevent multinational infrastructure developers from accessing territorial cooperation funds

GREEN_EFA absolutely upholds the LIFE Programme's budget expansion to 1% of the EU budget, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to securing dedicated environmental financing for technical assistance and regional capacity-building in climate-vulnerable territories.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of Natura 2000 reinforcement and renewable energy transitions, recognizing these as critical to ending fossil fuel dependencies and protecting ancient ecosystems in line with EU biodiversity targets.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s explicit linkage between individual climate action and systemic change, effectively advancing their principle that public engagement must drive societal shifts toward carbon neutrality.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely upholds the prioritization of biodiversity crisis responses within LIFE, seeing this as essential to reversing habitat destruction trends highlighted by catastrophic species decline data.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s cross-border cooperation mechanisms, affirming their strategic vision for pan-European collaboration in scaling circular economy innovations and equitable green transitions.

ALDE strongly accepts the LIFE Programme’s prioritization of farmer partnerships to advance sustainable agriculture, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to pragmatic environmental solutions that balance economic viability and ecological stewardship.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on equitable funding for vulnerable regions, effectively advancing climate resilience and biodiversity preservation as core ALDE priorities.  
ALDE proposes amending Annex II to explicitly clarify biodiversity investment categories, ensuring species-specific measures like large predators are addressed through targeted habitat restoration frameworks rather than broad classifications.  
ALDE endorses the BEST scheme’s expansion to overseas territories, emphasizing its alignment with cross-border best-practice sharing—a longstanding ALDE pillar for regional sustainability.  
ALDE highlights the critical need to integrate farmer-led emission reduction achievements into LIFE’s monitoring frameworks, ensuring recognition of agricultural sector progress as a baseline for future funding allocations.

SD strongly approves the increased LIFE budget allocation, particularly for clean energy transition and biodiversity protection, aligning with SD's climate urgency commitments under the Paris Agreement.  
SD endorses merit-based expansion of integrated regional projects while proposing enhanced communication strategies to maximize stakeholder engagement and policy coherence.  
SD approves the circular economy subprogram's focus on resource efficiency, emphasizing its critical role in achieving SD priorities for sustainable production systems.  
SD highlights the necessity of strict third-country participation criteria to ensure LIFE's environmental standards remain uncompromised during global outreach efforts.  
SD applauds cohesion policy synergies and outermost region funding provisions as vital for equitable climate action, directly advancing SD's territorial justice principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key provisions of a resolution on the LIFE Programme, emphasizing specific funding rules for the Outermost Regions and Overseas Countries and Territories, including the Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services in Territories of European Overseas (BEST) scheme. It endorsed extending the programme to third countries under defined conditions and prioritized cooperation and best-practice sharing. The resolution stressed aligning cohesion policy with LIFE objectives, enhancing regional and local authorities’ roles, and supporting administrative capacity-building projects. It underscored the critical need for environmental funding in vulnerable regions and clarified participation criteria for third countries, including former EU member states, ensuring alignment with EU environmental priorities. The resolution aimed to strengthen biodiversity, climate action, and circular economy initiatives while fostering cross-border collaboration and equitable resource allocation.

title: Promotion of clean and energy-efficient road transport vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2009/33/EU on the promotion of clean and energy-efficient road transport vehicles
background: The European Union's commitment to Paris Agreement climate targets and IPCC recommendations, coupled with persistent transport sector emissions and evolving clean vehicle technologies, prompted reassessment of Directive 2009/33/EC. Public authorities' procurement practices, representing 70% of EU bus purchases, faced challenges aligning with decarbonisation goals. The Parliament will discuss revising clean vehicle promotion rules to improve air quality and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the directive's promotion of battery industry development, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to sustainable energy independence and technological leadership.  
EPP proposes amending Article 3 to enhance emissions calculation methodologies by incorporating full lifecycle assessments and biofuel utilization criteria.  
EPP approves the issue's emphasis on EU financial support mechanisms for regional authorities, ensuring practical implementation of clean vehicle transitions.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of integrating socio-economic safeguards to protect low-income citizens from disproportionate cost burdens during the green transition.  
EPP endorses provisions safeguarding European manufacturers against unfair competition, effectively advancing EPP's priority of balanced ecological and industrial policies.

EFDD totally conflicts the inclusion of fossil fuels in the clean vehicle definition, which directly contradicts their mandate for zero-emission urban transport transitions.  
EFDD rejects the revised procurement framework for perpetuating diesel dominance in public transport fleets until 2030, failing to mandate electric vehicle adoption timelines like those implemented in Rome and Barcelona.  
The proposal overlooks critical retrofitting solutions that could immediately reduce emissions from existing fleets, a key EFDD sustainability priority.  
EFDD condemns the directive's failure to match China's electric bus deployment scale, cementing Europe's technological lag rather than closing it.  
This text entirely doubts with EFDD's demand for binding 2025 phase-out targets for combustion engines in municipal vehicle purchases.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the allowance of biofuels in clean vehicle definitions, as it perpetuates fossil-era technologies inconsistent with zero-emission mandates.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s failure to mandate full public-sector fleet electrification by 2025, overlooking cities like Barcelona already proving its feasibility.  
This proposal conflicts with GREEN_EFA’s climate emergency stance by ignoring IPCC deadlines, prioritizing incrementalism over systemic transport decarbonization.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the loopholes permitting combustion engines under “clean” labels, directly contradicting their 2023 manifesto banning all combustion-based public procurement.  
The text’s technological neutrality clause undermines EU climate leadership, lagging behind U.S. and Chinese zero-emission benchmarks GREEN_EFA demands.

ALDE strongly endorses the mandate for public authorities to procure clean vehicles, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to market-driven environmental innovation and cost-effective climate solutions.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on stimulating demand for cleaner technologies, which effectively advances ALDE's priority of accelerating sustainable mobility accessibility across income groups.  
ALDE proposes enhancing policy coherence by explicitly linking municipal procurement rules with EU-level emission targets in Article 4 to ensure full harmonization across governance levels.  
ALDE applauds the cross-border applicability of clean vehicle standards as matching their manifesto principles for pan-European climate action frameworks.  
ALDE endorses the fiscal responsibility provisions requiring lifecycle cost assessments, ensuring taxpayer funds prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term savings.

SD strongly upholds the integration of stringent sub-targets for zero-emission vehicles, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to accelerating Europe’s transition to sustainable mobility through exemplary public procurement practices.  
SD approves binding 75% clean vehicle procurement targets by 2030, effectively advancing urban air quality improvements and Paris Agreement compliance while stimulating green industrial innovation.  
SD proposes amending Article 4(2a) to explicitly recognize only plug-in hybrids, preventing ambiguity in emission reduction benchmarks and safeguarding environmental integrity.  
SD underscores the necessity of augmenting EU cohesion funds to subsidize municipal fleet electrification, ensuring local authorities can meet targets without fiscal strain.  
SD applauds the rejection of protectionist amendments undermining air quality standards, reinforcing the directive’s alignment with SD’s climate leadership principles.

ECR firmly disputes the issue's abrupt transition mandates, citing prohibitive costs for SMEs and lack of phased incentives as inconsistent with market-driven environmental solutions.  
ECR rejects the proposal's neglect of coal-based energy integration, arguing that modernized coal plants provide low-emission electricity crucial for affordable transport electrification.  
ECR criticizes the directive for overlooking regional energy realities, particularly in member states reliant on coal, thereby undermining the feasibility of energy-efficient vehicle adoption.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 proposal (COM(2017)0653) by adopting a first-reading stance under Article 192 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing environmental policy alignment. It endorsed the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0321/2018) and incorporated input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism. The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements are made, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence. Parliament also directed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional communication and compliance with EU legislative processes.

title: Transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment in the food chain: REPORT on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment in the food chain amending Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 [on general food law], Directive 2001/18/EC [on the deliberate release into the environment of GMOs], Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 [on GM food and feed], Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003 [on feed additives], Regulation (EC) No 2065/2003 [on smoke flavourings], Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 [on food contact materials], Regulation (EC) No 1331/2008 [on the common authorisation procedure for food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings], Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 [on plant protection products] and Regulation (EU) No 2015/2283 [on novel foods]
background: Recurring food safety controversies, public demands for transparency following glyphosate reauthorization debates, and a 2018 European Citizens’ Initiative prompted the European Commission to propose reforms addressing perceived gaps in risk assessment processes under the General Food Law. The Parliament will discuss enhancing transparency and sustainability in EU food chain risk governance.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposal's requirement for immediate publication of application studies as fundamentally undermining intellectual property protection for EU agri-food industries.  
EPP opposes the issue's transparency timelines, citing failure to implement safeguards against industrial espionage from third-country competitors during risk assessment procedures.  
This fully conflicts with EPP's position that innovation competitiveness requires confidentiality until EFSA's preliminary scientific opinion is finalized (Amendment 12 rejected in committee).  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of R&D investment security, creating unacceptable risks for SMEs developing novel food additives under Regulation (EC) No 1331/2008.  
EPP condemns the absence of impact assessment on authorization delays, directly contradicting their 2019 manifesto commitment to maintaining Europe's global leadership in food innovation.

EFDD conditionally endorses the proposal but demands mandatory disclosure of all scientific studies used in risk assessments, arguing that current provisions fail to prevent corporate influence on regulatory outcomes.  
EFDD requests revisions to align the issue with ongoing PEST committee investigations, noting that premature implementation undermines parliamentary scrutiny of pesticide authorization processes.  
EFDD opposes maintaining industry confidentiality clauses for food safety data, asserting that public health transparency must override commercial secrecy claims as demonstrated in glyphosate authorization controversies.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in allowing corporate-funded research to remain undisclosed, which conflicts with their principle that scientific integrity requires full public access to risk assessment materials.  
EFDD criticizes the issue's procedural timeline as inconsistent with democratic accountability, citing the rushed adoption before specialized committees conclude their analysis of Monsanto Papers revelations.

ENF supports the issue’s focus on transparency in risk assessment processes, aligning with their advocacy for consumer access to scientific data and supply chain accountability.  
ENF endorses the integration of citizen-led concerns into regulatory frameworks, reflecting their commitment to participatory food safety governance.  
ENF advises mandating Italy’s model of origin labeling and sectoral collaboration as binding standards in the regulation’s implementation guidelines.  
ENF emphasizes the need for explicit ingredient disclosure requirements across all food products to eliminate deceptive marketing practices.  
ENF calls for strengthened enforcement mechanisms to ensure uniform application of traceability rules, preventing regulatory divergence among member states.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s mandate for full transparency from the outset of risk assessments, aligning with their demand for public access to all studies—including those critical of industry interests—to rebuild citizen trust.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of citizen-led initiatives like *Stop Glyphosate* into legislative reform, reflecting their manifesto pledge to prioritize grassroots environmental advocacy over corporate secrecy.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly require EFSA panels to independently commission or replicate high-risk studies, ensuring scientific rigor and mitigating industry bias in safety evaluations.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for open registers of all risk assessment data, emphasizing that this measure directly advances their 2023 agenda to eradicate “dirty secrets” in agrochemical approvals.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the necessity of including dissenting scientists in EFSA deliberations, framing this as a critical enhancement to democratize expertise and align with Treaty obligations on public health.

SD totally promotes the issue's mandate for immediate public access to all non-confidential application data, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transparent risk assessment processes free from corporate influence.  
SD perfectly aligns with the requirement for independent scientific validation of industry-submitted studies, ensuring food safety decisions prioritize public health over private profit motives.  
SD fully supports the elimination of post-authorization study publication delays, recognizing this as critical to restoring citizen trust in EU food safety governance structures.  
SD endorses without reservation the application of precautionary principle enforcement mechanisms, safeguarding both environmental integrity and consumer health protections.  
SD completely agrees with maintaining strict limitations on confidentiality claims, ensuring commercial interests never override fundamental rights to food chain transparency.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the issue's foundational push for industry-independent risk assessments, aligning perfectly with their commitment to prioritizing public health over corporate interests in food safety governance.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4(2) to explicitly prohibit withholding scientific studies under intellectual property claims, ensuring glyphosate-like opacity cannot recur.  
GUE_NGL applauds the mandated early public access to assessment data as a critical step toward their manifesto goal of democratizing food chain decisions.  
GUE_NGL urges extending Clause 9 to include binding EU agency funding guarantees, addressing systemic underresourcing that risks compromising assessment integrity.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes embedding the precautionary principle into all authorization procedures, requiring amendments to Annex III to list carcinogenic or ecotoxic substances as automatically inadmissible.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2018)0179), emphasizing the legal basis under Treaty provisions related to environmental, public health, and food safety policies. It endorsed the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0417/2018) and considered opinions from the Committees on Fisheries and Legal Affairs. The resolution instructs the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its initial text, ensuring legislative oversight. It also directs the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under Rule 59 of its Rules of Procedure. The resolution integrates feedback from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, dated September and October 2018, while underscoring compliance with Treaty obligations and inter-institutional consultation processes.

title: Union Civil Protection Mechanism: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 1313/2013/EU on a Union Civil Protection Mechanism
background: Recent natural disasters, including deadly wildfires in Portugal, and climate change-driven increases in simultaneous large-scale emergencies exposed limitations in the EU’s Civil Protection Mechanism established in 2013. The Parliament will discuss amendments to strengthen collective disaster response capacities and address gaps in cross-border crisis coordination under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the creation of a complementary European reserve (rescEU) that strengthens crisis response while preserving national civil protection sovereignty, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to subsidiarity-driven solidarity.  
EPP approves the budget increase for UCPM operational capacities as critical for addressing climate-related disasters, effectively advancing EPP's priority of building resilient EU crisis management frameworks.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of maintaining member states' primary responsibility for prevention and asset provision, proposing enhanced Commission oversight to ensure consistent preparedness across all national systems.  
EPP applauds the issue’s balance between centralized coordination and local implementation, which mirrors EPP’s longstanding advocacy for multi-level governance in security matters.  
EPP suggests further integration of structural funds with UCPM mechanisms as a future enhancement opportunity to optimize resource allocation for ultra-peripheral regions.

ENF firmly condemns the Commission’s authority to control the withdrawal of deployed national capacities, viewing it as an infringement on member state sovereignty.  
ENF rejects the expansion of rescEU capacities through delegated acts, arguing this enables unchecked EU parallel structures and commercializes disaster response.  
The issue’s dismissal of subsidiarity objections contradicts ENF’s commitment to preventing EU overreach into national civil protection sovereignty.  
ENF highlights the issue’s failure to address regional consultations, such as those from Oberösterreich and Vorarlberg, undermining subsidiarity principles.  
The proposal’s centralization of decision-making authority in the Commission directly conflicts with ENF’s opposition to supranational control over emergency responses.

GREEN_EFA rejects the expansion of rescEU's scope to terrorist attacks as fundamentally condemning with their principle of targeted EU disaster response.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue’s broadened mandate, which overlooks the critical need to prioritize natural disaster preparedness over security-related contingencies.  
GREEN_EFA argues that including counter-terrorism in rescEU risks member state resistance, undermining the Mechanism’s core function to address climate-driven emergencies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s inconsistency with their stance against EU overreach, emphasizing that civil protection must remain distinct from military or security domains.  
GREEN_EFA demands removal of all references to terrorist attacks in Article 2 to preserve focus on environmental disasters like wildfires and floods.

ALDE supports the prioritization of national civil protection resources before activating EU-level rescEU capacities to ensure cost-efficiency and subsidiarity.  
ALDE advises maintaining co-financing mechanisms for cross-border asset deployment to preserve member states’ operational flexibility in predictable crises.  
ALDE proposes removing prescriptive lists of rescEU equipment from the legislative text, urging expert-led procurement based on rigorous risk assessments.  
ALDE calls for an independent impact assessment to address gaps in the proposal’s preparatory analysis before finalizing rescEU’s scope.  
ALDE stresses that member states’ obligations for foreseeable disasters like wildfires must remain unequivocal under the revised mechanism.

SD strongly advocates the establishment of rescEU as a last-resort capacity, aligning with their commitment to European solidarity and proactive disaster preparedness, particularly through securing critical aerial firefighting resources like Canadair.  
SD strongly endorses the integration of climate risk mapping into prevention strategies, proposing enhanced environmental valuation criteria for the Solidarity Fund to ensure equitable support for vulnerable regions.  
SD strongly advocates maintaining subsidiarity while scaling EU-level response capabilities through rescEU, emphasizing its role in complementing national systems during extreme crises as outlined in the Sendai Framework.  
SD strongly advocates investments in local intervention groups and cross-border training programs under the UCPM, which align with their vision of decentralized yet coordinated civil protection.  
SD proposes allocating targeted MFF funds for infrastructure resilience in Eastern Europe and citizen preparedness campaigns, enhancing prevention without opposing the issue’s core objectives.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to establish binding climate refugee protections despite clear evidence of displacement drivers  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the supranational command chain model as violating national sovereignty in civil protection matters  
GUE_NGL condemns the disproportionate 10% prevention funding allocation as grossly inadequate for climate crisis mitigation priorities  
GUE_NGL challenges the budgetary redeployment approach that starves existing social programs to finance crisis management theater  
GUE_NGL demands rejection of technocratic solutions ignoring gendered violence in refugee camps and climate migration routes

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Commission’s legislative proposal on civil protection, addressing the Czech Chamber of Deputies’ subsidiarity objection, which it dismissed. It called on the Commission to avoid financing new policy priorities through budget redeployments during the current multiannual financial framework (MFF), warning this would undermine existing EU activities. The resolution stressed the need for sufficient funding for the Union Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM) under the 2021–2027 MFF, building on ongoing reforms. It emphasized that EU-level capacities (rescEU) must complement, not replace, national civil protection efforts, maintaining co-financing for transport costs of assets outside the European Civil Protection Pool. Parliament also instructed the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and forwarded its position to relevant EU institutions and national parliaments.

title: Use of genetically modified food and feed: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the use of genetically modified food and feed on their territory
background: The European Union’s centralized GMO authorization process, combined with Member States’ divergent stances on genetically modified food and feed approvals and reliance on imported GM animal feed, prompted the Commission’s proposal under 2015 political guidelines. The Parliament will discuss amending regulations to permit national restrictions on EU-authorized GM food and feed use.

stances.stance:
EPP completely promotes the issue's rejection of renationalization measures that would fragment the single market through incompatible national GMO restrictions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's defense of EU-wide scientific assessments by EFSA as the sole basis for food safety decisions.  
EPP fully supports maintaining harmonized trade rules to prevent border controls and ensure agricultural supply chain continuity across member states.  
EPP endorses the prioritization of evidence-based policymaking over ideological restrictions that undermine biotechnological innovation.  
EPP applauds the issue's reinforcement of subsidiarity principles by rejecting unnecessary EU legislation conflicting with existing authorization frameworks.

EFDD rejects the proposal’s centralization of GM food governance as entirely doubting with its core principle of national sovereignty, demanding unrestricted member state authority to prohibit GM feed based on independent health and environmental risk assessments.  
EFDD opposes the reliance on EFSA’s opaque evaluation processes, condemning the issue’s failure to mandate full transparency of data for independent scientific scrutiny as incompatible with democratic accountability.  
EFDD criticizes the Commission’s disregard for subsidiarity, citing the absence of an impact assessment and dismissing EU-level harmonization as unnecessary overreach that undermines national self-determination.  
EFDD highlights the proposal’s economic dangers, particularly for agriculture-dependent states like Ireland, where unilateral GM feed bans would destabilize livestock sectors reliant on existing import frameworks.  
EFDD condemns the undemocratic comitology procedures, insisting member states must retain veto powers over GM market approvals without interference from unaccountable EU bodies.

ENF rejects the proposal as fundamentally inadequate for permitting any member state authorization of GMOs, directly contradicting their demand for a complete EU-wide ban on cultivation and commerce.  
ENF opposes the issue’s failure to address corporate control of food systems, citing unresolved health risks like those exposed in the Séralini study and unchecked influence of agro-industrial lobbies.  
ENF condemns the proposal’s allowance for national discretion as a loophole enabling gradual GMO proliferation, demanding instead an absolute prohibition to protect “the chain of life” from patent-driven colonization.  
ENF argues the issue aligns with globalized commercial interests, mirroring TTIP-style compromises that sacrifice food sovereignty and consumer safety to multinational agribusiness demands.  
ENF emphasizes the proposal’s incompatibility with public opinion, noting citizens’ clear rejection of GMOs and the EU’s obligation to prioritize health over industry profits.

GREEN_EFA completely supports the rejection of the Commission’s proposal, as it fails to democratize GMO decision-making and instead renationalizes policy, directly contradicting Juncker’s transparency pledges and the subsidiarity principle.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on member state autonomy, highlighting the impractical enforcement of opt-outs and the Commission’s opaque documentation practices as critical flaws in the proposal.  
GREEN_EFA unequivocally supports halting GMO authorizations until comprehensive socio-environmental evaluations and mandatory labeling for animal products derived from GM feed are established, as outlined in the issue’s critique.  
GREEN_EFA champions the call for a European protein strategy to reduce GM soy imports, reinforcing the issue’s rejection of trade-driven compromises that undermine consumer trust and ecological priorities.  
GREEN_EFA affirms that the proposal’s incompatibility with WTO standards and its linkage to TTIP negotiations validate the Parliament’s decision to demand a withdrawal, aligning with demands for genuine legislative reform over procedural shortcuts.

SD absolutely promotes the issue's rejection of renationalized GMO policies, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to preserving EU-level democratic decision-making on food safety and market integrity.  
SD strongly advocates maintaining single market coherence, emphasizing that fragmented national opt-outs would undermine agricultural competitiveness—a position fully consistent with SD's 2015 manifesto priorities.  
SD applauds the issue's insistence on Commission-led reforms, proposing enhanced EU research initiatives into next-generation biotechnologies to address consumer concerns while advancing innovation.  
SD absolutely promotes the call for pan-European transparency mechanisms, urging mandatory GM feed labeling across all member states to align with SD's health accountability principles.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's demand for impact assessments, emphasizing the need for future proposals to include binding WTO compatibility reviews and protein crop diversification strategies.

GUE_NGL fully sanctions the rejection of the Commission’s proposal as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to safeguarding member states’ sovereignty over agricultural and food policies.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes that the issue’s defense of subsidiarity directly advances their core principle of empowering nations to reject corporate-driven GM impositions, reflecting citizens’ overwhelming demand for GM-free choices.  

GUE_NGL applauds the Parliament’s insistence on withdrawing the flawed proposal, which mirrors their demand for systemic reform of the European Food Safety Authority’s risk assessments to prioritize ecological integrity over biotech interests.  

GUE_NGL highlights how the issue’s alignment with 19 member states’ GM opt-outs reinforces their vision of food sovereignty, ensuring regions can protect traditional farming systems from genetic contamination.  

GUE_NGL asserts that the outright rejection strengthens democratic accountability by heeding national parliaments’ reasoned opinions, countering Commission overreach in line with their anti-corporate globalization agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Commission’s 2015 proposal (COM(2015)0177) aimed at harmonizing national measures under Article 114 of the TFEU, rejecting it outright and urging the Commission to withdraw the draft legislation. The resolution highlighted concerns over non-compliance with the subsidiarity principle, citing reasoned opinions from the Belgian, Spanish, Dutch, and Austrian parliaments, which argued that EU-level action was unnecessary. It referenced the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of 16 September 2015 and the Committee of the Regions’ opinion of 13 October 2015, both contributing to the critique. The Parliament emphasized the Environment Committee’s report (A8-0305/2015) and the Agriculture Committee’s opinion, which informed its decision to reject the proposal as incompatible with member states’ autonomy. The resolution concluded by instructing its President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing the need to prioritize subsidiarity and avoid overreach in EU legislative initiatives.

title: Veterinary medicinal products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products
background: Rising antimicrobial resistance linked to veterinary antibiotic use, fragmented EU market access for veterinary medicines, and outdated regulatory frameworks prompted the European Commission's 2014 proposal to modernize rules. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing veterinary medicinal product standards to balance public health, animal welfare, and market efficiency while combating antimicrobial resistance.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the harmonization of veterinary regulations to ensure equal standards across member states, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fair agricultural competition and crisis support for dairy sectors.  
EPP endorses enhanced antibiotic resistance measures in Articles 114 and 168(4)(b) TFEU, proposing mandatory monitoring systems with tiered consequences for excessive use while maintaining scientifically justified exceptions for preventive treatments.  
EPP applauds provisions to accelerate veterinary drug approvals, effectively advancing innovation access as demonstrated by historical delays in critical treatments like Trastuzumab.  
EPP advocates integrating complementary therapies such as homeopathic medicines through streamlined registration processes to reduce antibiotic reliance, enhancing alignment with One Health principles.  
EPP emphasizes maintaining veterinary prescription autonomy via cascade systems, ensuring animal welfare while upholding strict antimicrobial stewardship protocols across all member states.

ENF totally challenges allowing animals from clinical trials into the food chain, as the issue’s precautionary delay fails to eliminate contamination risks, conflicting with ENF’s strict food safety principles.  
ENF rejects the insufficient regulation of online veterinary medicine sales, stressing the proposal overlooks counterfeit risks and undermines veterinarians’ role in antibiotic stewardship, a pillar of public health.  
ENF opposes permitting intra-EU export of meats from animals treated by non-veterinarians, citing the issue’s inconsistency with ENF’s demand for rigorous oversight to prevent repeat food safety crises.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the ban on routine prophylactic antibiotic use in livestock, aligning with their commitment to combating antimicrobial resistance through stricter agricultural regulations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prohibition of online antibiotic sales and stricter controls on metaphylactic treatments, effectively advancing public health safeguards against resistant bacteria.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing research into alternative therapies such as bacteriophage treatments and homeopathy to reduce dependency on conventional antibiotics in veterinary medicine.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to address intensive farming practices, advocating for improved animal husbandry standards to naturally decrease infection risks and antibiotic demand.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the importance of rigorous enforcement mechanisms for antibiotic restrictions in large-scale operations, ensuring compliance aligns with ecological health priorities.

ALDE fundamentally endorses the stringent restrictions on routine prophylactic antibiotic use, which align perfectly with the party’s commitment to combating antimicrobial resistance and prioritizing targeted veterinary treatments.  
ALDE applauds the balanced framework harmonizing consumer protection, industry innovation incentives, and environmental safeguards, effectively advancing sustainable pharmaceutical practices across the EU.  
ALDE strongly agrees the cascade system preserving critical human antibiotics and the regulated inclusion of homeopathic treatments, recognizing their role in reducing unnecessary antimicrobial applications.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with provisions enabling cross-border access to veterinary medicines and maintaining genetic modification technologies as crucial tools for developing next-generation animal health solutions.  
ALDE celebrates the regulation as a landmark achievement in European public health policy, upholding decades of advocacy for science-based antimicrobial stewardship in agriculture and veterinary medicine.

SD strongly advocates the prohibition of online antibiotic sales and decoupling of veterinary prescription from commercial interests, aligning with their commitment to combat antimicrobial resistance through ethical pharmaceutical practices.  
SD applauds the mandatory antimicrobial resistance monitoring systems across member states as a critical advancement in operationalizing the "one health" framework they have long championed.  
SD endorses the retroactive market withdrawal clause for reserve antibiotics used in veterinary medicine, proposing enhanced collaboration with the European Medicines Agency to ensure harmonized implementation.  
SD approves the inclusion of environmental impact assessments throughout veterinary drug production cycles, reflecting their ecological stewardship priorities in pharmaceutical regulation.  
SD welcomes the issue’s ban on prophylactic antibiotic use in healthy animals, urging strict enforcement mechanisms to eliminate routine preventive dosing in intensive farming.

GUE/NGL strongly sanctions the issue’s stringent antibiotic regulations, recognizing their alignment with the party’s commitment to combating antimicrobial resistance and safeguarding public health.  
GUE/NGL applauds the retention of national regulatory flexibility, ensuring member states like Finland can maintain strict veterinary oversight and residue-free food production.  
GUE/NGL endorses provisions for generic veterinary medicines and small-market adaptations, crucial for breaking monopolistic practices and ensuring equitable access.  
GUE/NGL proposes enhancing Article 12’s centralized authorization system to prioritize equitable access for smaller markets and reduce multinational corporate dominance.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the need to address intensive farming models under the CAP framework to holistically reduce antibiotic dependency, complementing the issue’s goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0558) aimed at harmonizing EU legislation under Articles 114 and 168(4)(b) of the TFEU to enhance public health measures, particularly addressing patient safety and antimicrobial resistance. It emphasized alignment with its 2015 resolution on safer healthcare and combating antimicrobial resistance, stressing the need for coordinated action. The resolution endorsed the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0046/2016) and incorporated input from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance legislative proceedings.

title: Waste: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2008/98/EC on waste
background: The European Commission proposed amendments to the 2008 Waste Framework Directive in 2015 to strengthen EU waste management policies, addressing resource efficiency and environmental sustainability amid global resource scarcity concerns. The Parliament will discuss revisions to harmonize waste regulations and advance circular economy objectives within existing treaty frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely endorses the issue's harmonized definitions for recycling metrics, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to standardized circular economy frameworks across member states.  
EPP perfectly supports binding landfill reduction targets as a transformative step toward resource-efficient societies, echoing Karl-Heinz Florenz's emphasis on preserving critical raw materials for future generations.  
EPP strongly endorses prioritizing separate waste collection systems before incineration, recognizing Sirpa Pietikäinen's call to structurally address marine plastic pollution through upstream prevention.  
EPP fully approves mandatory food waste tracking across production chains, implementing Elisabeth Köstinger's vision of converting today's waste streams into tomorrow's industrial feedstocks.  
EPP unreservedly backs the issue's job creation mechanisms in reuse sectors, validating Peter Liese's analysis of circular economies as drivers of sustainable employment growth.

EFDD partly upholds the issue's recycling targets but demands amendments to prohibit waste incineration entirely, citing unresolved environmental risks.  
EFDD requests revisions to eliminate all fossil fuel subsidies in the proposal, arguing this omission firmly doubts with achieving a genuine circular economy.

title: CO2 emission standards for cars and vans: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2019/631 as regards strengthening the CO2 emission performance standards for new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles in line with the Union’s increased climate ambition | A9-0150/2022 | European Parliament

Rising transport emissions and reported growth in heavier vehicle sales influenced regulatory reassessment. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns that current CO2 emission targets for vehicle manufacturers, tied to average vehicle mass, have inadvertently incentivized the production and sale of heavier, higher-emitting vehicles like SUVs, undermining the regulation’s environmental goals. To address this, the resolution proposed eliminating mass-based adjustments to manufacturer targets, ensuring stricter emissions reductions and aligning with the EU’s decarbonization objectives. It emphasized the role of hydrogen as a carbon-free fuel for hard-to-abate transport sectors, such as light commercial vehicles, and advocated integrating ecodesign requirements to enhance vehicle energy efficiency and innovation. The resolution also called for revising the outdated Car Labelling Directive to improve consumer transparency on vehicle energy performance, particularly for electric vehicles, to drive informed choices and reduce energy consumption. Additionally, it stressed the need for linear CO2 reduction trajectories between 2025 and 2030 to accelerate progress toward a climate-neutral economy.

title: Batteries and waste batteries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning batteries and waste batteries, repealing Directive 2006/66/EC and amending Regulation (EU) No 2019/1020 | A9-0031/2022 | European Parliament

The Parliament will discuss aligning battery production, recycling, and trade with sustainability goals and strategic autonomy amid global market shifts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and proposed measures to enhance battery sustainability, safety, and transparency, focusing on restricting hazardous substances like lead and mandating a systemic review of such materials in batteries. It emphasized stricter recycling targets, requiring higher material recovery rates—particularly for lithium, cobalt, and nickel—and mandated carbon footprint declarations for electric vehicle (EV) batteries, with phased thresholds to reduce emissions. The resolution introduced due diligence obligations for supply chains to address human rights and environmental risks, particularly for critical raw materials. It prioritized circular economy principles, requiring EV batteries to be designed for repair and reuse, with manufacturers obligated to provide spare parts for at least 10 years after production ends to minimize type-approval complexities. Amendments aligned substance restrictions with the EU Chemicals Strategy, emphasizing "essential use" criteria, and proposed standardized labeling and digital passports for battery components to improve traceability. The resolution also set deadlines for phasing out non-rechargeable portable batteries and mandated stricter waste collection and recycling efficiency benchmarks, while advocating for improved consumer access to battery removal and replacement services.

title: Binding annual greenhouse gas emission reductions by Member States (Effort Sharing Regulation): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council Amending Regulation (EU) 2018/842 on binding annual greenhouse gas emission reductions by Member States from 2021 to 2030 contributing to climate action to meet commitments under the Paris Agreement | A9-0163/2022 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and proposed amendments to the Commission’s proposal (COM(2021)0555) to strengthen climate action under Regulation (EU) 2018/842, emphasizing the need for extended timelines beyond 2030 and stricter emissions accountability. resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to protect Antarctica and the Southern Ocean, emphasizing their critical role in global climate regulation, biodiversity, and carbon sequestration, with the ocean absorbing over 90% of excess heat and 30% of CO₂ emissions. It highlighted Antarctica’s rapid warming of 1.8°C since 1989—three times the global average—and the existential threat this poses to ecosystems, including keystone species like Antarctic krill. The resolution expressed strong support for establishing two Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) in the East Antarctic and Weddell Sea, covering 3 million km², to safeguard biodiversity and enhance ocean resilience, aligning with the EU’s commitment to protect 30% of its seas by 2030 (including 10% under strict protection) and global biodiversity targets. It urged the EU and Member States to intensify diplomatic efforts to secure approval for these MPAs within the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR), addressing opposition from certain members. The Parliament stressed the need to combat illegal fishing, promote sustainable Antarctic tourism, and uphold the Madrid Protocol’s ban on mineral exploitation. It linked these efforts to broader international frameworks, including the UN Biodiversity Conference (COP15) and the EU Biodiversity Strategy, advocating for legally binding global targets to protect 30% of marine areas by 2030. The resolution also underscored the necessity of expanding oceanographic research, given that over 80% of the seabed remains unexplored, and enhancing global MPA networks through improved management and enforcement.

title: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 851/2004 establishing a European Centre for disease prevention and control | A9-0253/2021 | European Parliament

The Parliament will discuss enhancing the agency’s mandate to improve EU-level health crisis prevention, surveillance, and response mechanisms.

EPP highlights the issue’s framework for cross-border health assessments as a foundation for future integration of mental health support strategies in EU crisis response protocols.  
EPP applauds the joint procurement mechanisms for medical countermeasures, which mirror their longstanding advocacy for equitable access to innovative therapies across all Member States.  
EPP endorses the reinforced ECDC governance structure, perfectly aligning with their manifesto goals to centralize epidemiological expertise and ensure coordinated pandemic preparedness.

SD fully supports the binding requirements for transparent vaccine distribution mechanisms, seeing these provisions as the materialization of their manifesto pledge to combat pharmaceutical nationalism during cross-border emergencies.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's empowerment of ECDC to coordinate pan-European antimicrobial resistance strategies, directly advancing SD's decade-long campaign against pharmaceutical market failures in antibiotic development.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue’s integration of planetary health principles, perfectly aligning with their commitment to addressing biodiversity loss and pollution as root causes of pandemics.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with provisions requiring member states to share comparable health data, enhancing crisis preparedness in line with their climate-health advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening transparency in pharmaceutical procurement by amending Article 14 to mandate public disclosure of vaccine patent agreements funded by public resources.  
GREEN_EFA completely promotes the reinforced governance review clauses, seeing them as critical to maintaining accountability in line with their democratic oversight priorities.  
 While applauding global health solidarity mechanisms, GREEN_EFA highlights an enhancement opportunity to explicitly require the ECDC to advocate for WHO-led intellectual property sharing frameworks.

ECR strongly advocates the enhanced ECDC mandate for Union-wide health coordination, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to subsidiarity-driven crisis preparedness that respects national healthcare sovereignty.  
ECR approves the issue’s emphasis on interoperable surveillance systems and microbiological safety networks as critical advancements in addressing cross-border health threats.  
ECR proposes amending Article 6 to explicitly clarify that the ECDC’s role in vaccination campaigns supplements but does not override member states’ authority to design localized public health strategies.  
ECR applauds the provisions ensuring transparent performance reviews, which directly advance ECR’s priority of institutional accountability in EU agencies.  
ECR highlights the negotiated balance in competence distribution as a model for future health legislation, particularly in maintaining functional national crisis-response mechanisms.

ID rejects the centralized health surveillance mandates in Articles 5-7, citing incompatibility with national sovereignty principles enshrined in EU treaties.  
ID opposes fundamentally the issue's data-sharing mechanisms, equating them to systemic overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
This proposal conflicts with ID's stance against pharmaceutical dependency by neglecting concrete measures for EU medical production autonomy.  
The issue's cross-border coordination clauses fail to address ID's demand for restored national border controls as primary disease prevention.  
 ID condemns the lack of transparency provisions regarding vaccine procurement processes referenced in Annex II.

GUE_NGL strongly approves the expanded ECDC mandate for Union-wide health assessments, as this aligns perfectly with their commitment to equitable pandemic preparedness and cross-border solidarity in public health crises.  
GUE_NGL approves the binding data-sharing requirements but proposes amending Article 6 to explicitly prohibit commercialization of health data, safeguarding public systems from privatization pressures.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s focus on vaccination coordination and antimicrobial resistance, which effectively advances their priority of universal healthcare access through collective EU action.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that the ECDC’s governance reforms must be complemented by treaty revisions to elevate healthcare collaboration as a core EU competence, addressing systemic gaps exposed during COVID-19.  
GUE_NGL urges faster integration of pharmaceutical legislation revisions to combat medicine inequity, transforming the issue’s surveillance mechanisms into tools for democratizing health innovation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and adopted amendments to Regulation (EC) No 851/2004 to strengthen the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), enhancing its capacity to monitor, assess, and respond to health threats. Key revisions include expanding the ECDC’s mandate to improve preparedness, surveillance, and data-sharing mechanisms, with explicit requirements for member states to provide timely and comparable health data. The resolution introduced provisions for the ECDC to coordinate Union-wide health assessments, support vaccination campaigns, and address cross-border health risks, including antimicrobial resistance. It emphasized correcting drafting errors, such as adjusting reporting timelines (e.g., replacing erroneous references to 2023 and 2028 with appropriate deadlines) and aligning financial regulations with updated EU frameworks. The amendments mandated regular reviews of the ECDC’s performance, focusing on operational effectiveness, governance, and compliance with EU objectives, while ensuring transparency and accountability through public reports. Additionally, the resolution reinforced cooperation between the ECDC, national agencies, and international bodies, ensuring the Centre’s role in crisis response and its ability to propose updates to its mandate based on emerging health challenges.

title: European Climate Law: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 (European Climate Law) | A9-0162/2020 | European Parliament

SD applauds the issue's role in setting a global precedent through ambitious 2030 targets and reinforcing the EU's position as a leader in international climate diplomacy ahead of COP26.

ECR condemns the proposal's failure to address human rights violations in third-country supply chains, directly conflicting with their stance against enabling authoritarian regimes through critical mineral dependencies.  
ECR denounces the climate law's economic impact assessments as dangerously inadequate, highlighting how integration into the EU Semester process overlooks risks of energy poverty and industrial decline in coal-dependent regions.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the legality of binding generational climate commitments, asserting the proposal silences future voters by locking policies for 30 years without exit clauses.

ID rejects the mandatory 100 EUR allowance transfer price as economically destabilizing, citing post-COVID competitiveness risks and unproven environmental benefits.  
ID opposes climate neutrality targets for threatening energy sovereignty through forced renewable transitions and unreliable energy grids.  
ID completely doubts with CO2 reduction methodologies that disregard nuclear energy's role and impose unrealistic industrial transformation timelines.  
ID condemns global climate leadership aspirations as self-defeating given non-EU nations' continued fossil fuel reliance and lack of binding commitments.  
ID disputes the issue's job creation claims, highlighting projected automotive sector collapse and middle-class energy poverty from green transition costs.

GUE_NGL entirely approves the issue's framework for climate neutrality as perfectly aligning with their commitment to science-based emissions reductions, proposing enhanced ambition by amending Article 4 to mandate 65% absolute emission cuts by 2030.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the transparency mechanisms while urging stricter national binding targets under Article 7 to eliminate accounting loopholes and ensure equitable burden-sharing across Member States.  
GUE_NGL advocates strengthening Annex III to accelerate fossil fuel subsidy phase-outs by 2025, transforming the current "net" target architecture into absolute reduction requirements.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes integrating Global South equity reparations into the EU Semester process through new clauses mandating historical emission accountability in Article 12(b).  
GUE_NGL proposes expanding the Just Transition Fund provisions in Section 9 to triple social safeguards, directly linking climate investments to worker protections and public energy ownership.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to ensure compliance by Member States with their national climate targets and enhance transparency in the use of flexibility mechanisms, notably by introducing a fixed price of 100 EUR for transfers of allowances between Member States. It mandated the Commission to monitor, analyze, and publicly report on such transactions, including their potential budgetary impacts—both positive and negative—on Member States, and to integrate this analysis into the EU Semester process to inform fiscal and policy coordination. The resolution emphasized accountability in meeting climate goals through stricter oversight of allowance transfers and transparent reporting mechanisms to uphold the integrity of collective EU climate commitments.

title: European Medicines Agency: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a reinforced role for the European Medicines Agency in crisis preparedness and management for medicinal products and medical devices | A9-0216/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic revealed EU-wide medicinal product supply chain vulnerabilities, fragmented crisis coordination, and insufficient preparedness for health emergencies, prompting scrutiny of existing regulatory frameworks. ID proposes modifying Article 8 to include strict conflict-of-interest rules for EMA experts, ensuring genuine independence from pharmaceutical lobbyists.

 While critical of EMA's pandemic performance, ID acknowledges crisis preparedness improvements through amended market surveillance protocols in Article 8.

GUE_NGL highlights the critical need for reinforced financial commitments to EMA and ECDC, proposing that sustainable funding models be prioritized over temporary project-based allocations to maintain strengthened surveillance capacities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2020 proposal (COM(2020)0725) under Articles 114 and 168(4)(c) of the TFEU, focusing on harmonizing measures to safeguard public health and the internal market. It adopted amendments to the proposed regulation, introducing new recitals and modifying articles to strengthen provisions on risk assessment, transparency, and stakeholder consultation. Key amendments included enhanced requirements for data collection (e.g., Article 3), stricter criteria for market surveillance (Article 8), and expanded obligations for member states to report on implementation (Article 14). The resolution addressed concerns over subsidiarity raised by the French Senate and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of Regions. It emphasized alignment with EU health priorities, mandated periodic reviews of regulatory effectiveness, and called for robust enforcement mechanisms, including penalties for non-compliance (Article 30). The Parliament instructed its President to forward the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended.

title: General Union Environment Action Programme to 2030: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on a General Union Environment Action Programme to 2030 | A9-0203/2021 | European Parliament
background: The European Union’s existing environmental commitments under the European Green Deal and Sustainable Development Goals, alongside escalating climate crises and biodiversity decline, prompted the need for a renewed strategic framework. resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal COM(2020)0652, adopting a stance that underscores the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it intends to substantially amend or replace it, thereby safeguarding parliamentary oversight. The resolution, informed by consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and relevant parliamentary committees on transport, tourism, agriculture, rural development, environment, public health, and food safety, mandates the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. This decision reinforces procedural accountability under EU treaties, particularly Articles 192(3) and 294, while emphasizing adherence to legislative coherence and the integration of stakeholder input from key advisory bodies.

title: A WTO-compatible EU carbon border adjustment mechanism: REPORT towards a WTO-compatible EU carbon border adjustment mechanism | A9-0019/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU's climate commitments under the Paris Agreement, reinforced by the European Green Deal and 2030/2050 emissions targets, coincided with rising embedded emissions in imports and critiques of the EU ETS's carbon leakage protections. The Parliament will discuss a carbon border adjustment mechanism to align trade policy with climate goals under WTO rules.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the CBAM's alignment with WTO rules as a strategic tool to protect EU industries from carbon leakage while advancing global climate standards.  
EPP proposes adjusting the phase-out timeline of free ETS allowances to synchronize with CBAM implementation, ensuring no double penalties for energy-intensive sectors during the transition.  
EPP applauds the focus on targeting 94% of industrial emissions through sector-specific measures, reinforcing their commitment to maintaining Europe's competitive edge in clean manufacturing.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for WTO-compatible design to prevent retaliatory trade measures, aligning with their principles of fair global competition and multilateral cooperation.  
EPP endorses directing CBAM revenues to support SMEs and vulnerable nations, enhancing the mechanism's role in equitable climate financing without distorting single market integrity.

SD firmly supports integrating CBAM with circular economy policies, reflecting SD's holistic vision of combining trade measures with systemic sustainability transformations.

GREEN_EFA rejects the phased approach to ending ETS exemptions as incompatible with their "polluter pays" principle.

GREEN_EFA challenges the WTO compatibility arguments as prioritizing trade rules over planetary boundaries, contrary to their degrowth principles.

ECR opposes the mechanism's impractical carbon accounting requirements, warning of prohibitive administrative costs and retaliatory trade measures that could exacerbate global poverty.

ECR criticizes the proposal's lack of alignment with ongoing WTO reforms, arguing that unilateral carbon pricing adjustments could breach international trade rules.

ID entirely disapproves with the CBAM's protectionist approach, which undermines entrepreneurial freedom and EU competitiveness.  
The proposal overlooks the risk that reducing free allowances will accelerate carbon leakage, contradicting global climate goals.  
ID argues that the CBAM fails to address the root causes of carbon leakage, incentivizing production shifts to regions with lower environmental standards.  
This mechanism contradicts ID's principles by prioritizing market distortions over global cooperative solutions to climate challenges.  
ID demands revisions to eliminate double penalties on industries already burdened by stringent EU climate regulations.

GUE_NGL rejects the CBAM proposal for maintaining free ETS allowances that subsidize polluting industries instead of accelerating their decarbonization, directly contradicting climate justice principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the exclusion of agricultural products and international transport from the mechanism’s scope, which undermines comprehensive carbon accountability across sectors.  
GUE_NGL absolutely disapproves with the revenue model that lacks binding allocations to fund green transitions in Global South nations, perpetuating climate inequality.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to mandate full lifecycle carbon accounting, enabling corporations to externalize emissions through supply-chain loopholes.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal’s silence on overhauling EU trade deals that incentivize ecological dumping and human rights abuses abroad.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the escalating climate crisis, citing a 1.1°C global temperature rise, projected 250,000 annual climate-related deaths by 2030, and the inadequacy of current climate pledges to meet the Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C goal. It emphasized the EU’s 24% GHG reduction since 1990 but highlighted the rising embedded emissions in imports, with a 3:1 ratio of imported to exported CO2, undermining global climate efforts. The resolution endorsed a WTO-compatible Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) to address carbon leakage, initially targeting energy-intensive sectors (cement, steel, etc.), representing 94% of EU industrial emissions, while phasing out free EU ETS allowances to avoid double protection. It urged aligning the CBAM with the EU’s enhanced 2030 target of 60% emissions reduction (vs. 1990) and climate neutrality by 2050, integrating it with renewable energy investments, circular economy policies, and stricter product standards. Revenues (€5-14 billion annually) should fund climate action, support vulnerable nations, and avoid trade distortions, with special considerations for Least Developed Countries and SMEs. The CBAM must mirror EU ETS carbon prices, incentivize global decarbonization, and comply with WTO rules through non-discriminatory design, while promoting multilateral cooperation and reforms to align trade policies with climate goals.

title: Land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council Amending Regulations (EU) 2018/841 as regards the scope, simplifying the compliance rules, setting out the targets of the Member States for 2030 and committing to the collective achievement of climate neutrality by 2035 in the land use, forestry and agriculture sector, and (EU) 2018/1999 as regards improvement in monitoring, reporting, tracking of progress and review | A9-0161/2022 | European Parliament
